Japanese police arrested 64-year-old former school principal Yuhei Takashima on Wednesday, charging him with photographing obscene acts with a 13 or 14-year-old girl and producing pornography in a Manila hotel room. Police officers seized 147,600 photos documenting his activities, as Takashima admitted to paying for sex with more than 12,000 women and girls as young as 14 during repeated visits to the Philippines over 25 years. Takashima's case had been under police investigation since 2013, and he now faces criminal charges for his actions in Manila.

A Brazilian online football store claims to have next season's Chelsea kit for sale on its website, which can be purchased with Gareth Bale's name on the back. The website has published three Chelsea kits featuring the new 'Yokohama' sponsor but without the Adidas emblem, and offers the alleged new kit with 'Bale 9' printed on the back. This comes amid reports linking the Real Madrid striker with a potential return to the Premier League following his struggles in Spain.

Police say Clarence Taylor, 44, faked his own kidnapping in a bizarre incident last fall in Akron, Ohio, where he duct-taped his mouth and tied himself to a tree after his 45-year-old girlfriend called police reporting him missing. Taylor claimed he was abducted and robbed of $2,500, but police found inconsistencies in his story and charged him with falsification. A warrant was issued for his arrest last month, but Taylor remains at large.

Rita Wilson appears with an ensemble of actresses in a satirical new video promoting gender equality created by the Make it Fair Project, which ironically proclaims "It's only fair that men should have it all." In this new gender-equality PSA, Rita Wilson pretends to be distressed while the actresses highlight gender inequality by sarcastically noting statistics showing men dominate 70-95% of influential positions in Hollywood and other industries. The video uses tongue-in-cheek humor to draw attention to the disproportionate representation of men in leadership roles across film, government, and corporate sectors.

Spanish researchers have found that a warming climate may have enabled the earliest humans to venture into Western Europe 1.4 million years ago, suggesting that climate change significantly impacted human migration patterns. The study indicates that the spread of our distant human ancestors, the hominins, had been previously halted by colder and drier conditions, but as the climate warmed above 13°C and became more humid, these early humans were able to branch out from Africa into Spain and eventually across Europe. The paper, published in the Journal of Human Evolution, suggests that climate change affected the availability of resources and enabled the earliest known hominins to inhabit new regions 1.4 million years ago, as evidenced by Oldowan tools found at archaeological sites in southeast Spain.

Former NFL running back Lawrence Phillips, who played for Nebraska and was jailed in 2005 on a 31-year sentence for assault charges, is suspected of killing his cellmate Damion Soward at a Central California prison. Soward, a 37-year-old inmate serving 82 years to life for first-degree murder, was found dead Saturday morning in the cell he shared with Phillips at Kern Valley State Prison. Prison officials are investigating the death along with the Kern County Coroner and District Attorney.

Liverpool's FA Cup semi-final defeat to Aston Villa has put the club under intense scrutiny, with manager Brendan Rodgers looking dejected after the 2-1 loss that saw Villa's second goal from Fabian Delph secure their place in the final. The article highlights Liverpool's struggles this season, including poor signings by their transfer committee, with only three of 17 recent acquisitions proving successful, while managing Liverpool comes with great expectations that Rodgers has failed to meet. With the club's ambition to be Champions League regulars and compete for the Barclays Premier League title looking increasingly distant, Liverpool's players face questions about their character and resolve as they prepare for a crucial summer rebuild.

Google launched an April Fools' Day prank on Tuesday by combining Google Maps with Pac-Man, continuing the tech company's tradition of impish April Fools' Day pranks that have previously included features like a Pokemon Challenge and treasure map. Users can easily play by opening Google Maps on their desktop browser and clicking the Pac-Man icon, which transforms their map into a Pac-Man course. The game has delighted Twitter users who have been playing Pac-Man in real-world locations like Manhattan, London, and San Francisco streets.

Rangers boss Stuart McCall has been reassured that the club's removal from the London Stock Exchange's AIM market will not affect his squad's promotion charge, despite the club announcing six-month losses of £2.6million this week. McCall oversees his Rangers players while focusing on their upcoming match against newly-crowned Scottish Championship winners Hearts, stating he expects no negative impact from AIM's decision to de-list the club after chairman-in-waiting Dave King failed to find a new nominated advisor. The manager was also surprised to learn that Rangers will owe Newcastle United £500,000 if they achieve promotion, as part of their January loan deal for five Magpies youngsters.

The US Internet regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for allegedly running a "coercive scheme" using the new '.sucks' domain name to extract high fees from celebrities and companies seeking to protect their reputations. Celebrities like Kevin Spacey have reportedly paid to have their '.sucks' domains removed, while Taylor Swift has previously had to spend defensively to remove her name from '.porn' and '.adult' domains. Industry groups are calling this a "shakedown scheme" as Vox Populi charges around $2,000 annually for these domains while threatening to later release them to the general public for just $10.

Edinson Cavani's poor performance in PSG's 2-0 defeat to Barcelona may well have ended any chance of him joining Manchester United, as the striker failed to impress during the Champions League quarter-final. United manager Louis van Gaal is likely wary of signing another struggling South American striker following Radamel Falcao's nightmare loan spell at Old Trafford. Cavani has underperformed this season with only 11 domestic goals, and his lackluster display against Barcelona suggests he may not be the solution to United's striker problems.

The Premier League relegation battle is extremely tight with seven points separating Sunderland in 15th from Leicester in 20th place, and Steve Bruce's Hull facing what appears to be the hardest run-in of all the teams fighting to avoid relegation. The article predicts that Hull could survive on goal difference despite their difficult fixtures, while QPR may be relegated due to their poor goal difference compared to Hull's, and Leicester and Burnley are predicted to go down despite having more manageable opponents. Key factors include teams having crucial home games, with Aston Villa benefiting from Tim Sherwood's impact after Paul Lambert's departure, and several direct clashes between relegation-threatened sides that will likely determine who stays up.

Real Madrid star Karim Benzema showed his talents extend beyond football by posting a video of himself singing along to Tupac's classic track "Check Out Time" while cruising in his Bugatti Veyron, as the team prepares for their La Liga clash against Granada at the Bernabeu. The France forward, who has scored 20 goals this season, also expressed confidence that he can win the Ballon d'Or award in the future, despite the recent dominance of his Real Madrid teammate Cristiano Ronaldo and Barcelona's Lionel Messi.

Vatican medics have told Pope Francis that he must lose weight due to considerable weight gain since taking office two years ago, which is aggravating his sciatica condition. Doctors have advised the 78-year-old pontiff to cut his pasta intake to just two servings per week and take daily walks like his predecessor Pope Benedict XVI did. However, the Pope, who jokingly refers to himself as "the undisciplined one," continues to ignore the medical advice and eats pasta daily.

Google has released an update to its Android software that allows owners to unlock their phone with their voice using a feature called "trusted voice," which works by simply saying "OK Google." While the voice unlock feature has begun appearing on some Android handsets, Google warns that this method is less secure than traditional password options since someone with a similar voice could potentially unlock the device. Additionally, Android phones running Ice Cream Sandwich or higher also offer Face Unlock as an alternative biometric security option.

The lawyer for Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve deputy charged with second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting a man he intended to subdue with a Taser, on Saturday released documents that he says verify Bates' law enforcement training. The documents show Bates had one Taser training class over a six-and-a-half-year period, took three firearms training classes, and qualified 10 times to use a handgun from 2009 to 2014. Bates' training has become a central issue in the case, with questions raised about whether he received proper qualifications or preferential treatment due to his donations to the sheriff's office.

Peter Tait, headmaster of Sherborne Preparatory School, claimed parents have become "dervishes ready to battle with anyone and anything on behalf of their child" and need to keep their distance and trust schools and teachers instead of interfering with their children's education. The president of the National Association of Head Teachers also attacked parents, saying pushy parents are forcing children through unnecessary extra tuition and competing with one another rather than allowing natural development. Both educators argue that excessive parental involvement is hindering children's growth and that parents should step back and trust educational professionals.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu criticized the nuclear deal that six world powers struck with Iran to thwart Iran's nuclear ambitions, calling it a "bad deal" and arguing for a third alternative of maintaining pressure to get a better agreement. While President Barack Obama endorsed the deal as better than the alternatives, Netanyahu argued that Iran cannot be trusted and that the deal gives Iran too much flexibility by allowing thousands of centrifuges to keep operating and not shutting down any nuclear facilities. The framework agreement would lift Western sanctions on Iran in exchange for reducing active centrifuges from 19,000 to 5,060, limiting highly enriched uranium, and increasing inspections.

Catalans Dragons have suffered a major blow after France international winger Vincent Duport was ruled out for the rest of the season with a shoulder injury that requires surgery. Duport suffered a ruptured tendon during the Dragons' defeat at Hull FC on March 20, having scored three tries in the first six rounds of Super League XX. The sixth-placed Catalans will now have to cope without the key player as they continue their campaign, with their next match being a trip to Wigan on Sunday.

Indiana woman Samantha Fleming was reported missing with her newborn daughter Serenity weeks ago after leaving with a woman claiming to be from Child Services, and police have now discovered a body they believe to be Fleming's in Gary, Indiana, 180 miles from her home. The three-week-old infant was discovered unharmed at the same location and will be returned to relatives, while the alleged kidnapper, who had prepared a nursery and told neighbors she was pregnant with twins, asked her sister to care for the baby she was passing off as her own. Police were led to the location after Fleming's cell phone signal was detected in Gary, and they believe the kidnapper was very familiar with Fleming to have convinced her she was with Child Protective Services.

A geologist claims that a structure hidden beneath rubble in West Java could be a 20,000-year-old pyramid, which would make it the world's oldest pyramid—four times older than Egypt's oldest pyramid that was built almost 5,000 years ago. If verified, this ancient pyramid would predate even the Brazilian pyramids discovered in 1996 that date to around 3,000 BC, and would provide evidence of an advanced ancient civilisation capable of sophisticated engineering between 9,000 and 20,000 years ago. However, the controversial findings are disputed by other experts who question whether such a primitive civilization could have built such a complex structure.

Shocking footage has emerged showing a man stabbing a bouncer outside a Melbourne nightclub after being ejected, with the 29-year-old security guard suffering non-life threatening injuries when attacked from behind. In a separate incident on Good Friday, a 24-year-old man allegedly slashed another bouncer in the leg after being refused entry to a different Melbourne nightclub. Police have expressed disgust over both stabbings and are asking anyone with information to contact Crime Stoppers.

Carlisle United manager Keith Curle launched a scathing attack on his players following their dismal 3-1 defeat away at Accrington Stanley, claiming some "don't deserve to be professionals" and criticizing the lack of character and spirit in the changing room. The Cumbrians, who were relegated from League One last season, are currently struggling in League Two with just five games remaining to avoid another relegation, sitting only three points above the relegation zone. Curle even suggested staging an open forum where supporters could directly confront the players about their poor performances.

Victoria's Secret Angels Candice Swanepoel, 26-year-old Elsa Hosk, and Jasmine Tookes star in the lingerie brand's new Dream Angels campaign, where Candice leads her fellow models through an energetic routine showcasing the romantic collection in blush pink and white tones. The campaign promotes Victoria's Secret's Dream Angels push-up bras and features the models carrying pink striped umbrellas that customers receive free with purchase, while the article also highlights alternative options like DKNY Intimates lace bras. Despite her confident appearance in campaigns today, Candice admits she had to overcome shyness and create a persona to cope with the spotlight after being discovered at age 15.

Wannabe singer Kristina Karo is suing actress Mila Kunis for $5,000, alleging that Kunis stole her pet chicken named "Doggie" when they were children in Ukraine 25 years ago. Karo claims the theft of her pet chicken traumatized her and that being in close proximity to Kunis in Los Angeles has brought back bad memories, forcing her to seek therapy again. The bizarre lawsuit seeks compensation for emotional distress and therapy bills, with Karo alleging the incident has prevented her from pursuing the American dream.

Richard Howarth, a 35-year-old father from Milton Keynes, claims he has developed an "allergy" to Ukip leader Nigel Farage that causes him to sweat, shake, and become physically sick whenever he sees Mr Farage on television or hears his voice. Howarth says he must immediately change the channel when Farage appears to avoid becoming ill, with his symptoms sometimes lasting for hours. A phobia expert suggests Howarth's reaction is more likely a phobia than an allergy, explaining that it's possible to have such an avoidance reaction to a politician whose views are fundamentally opposed to your own.

Intoxicated 17-year-old Rahul Kumar climbed over the enclosure fence at a zoo in Ahmedabad, India, and ran toward the lions shouting "Today I kill a lion or a lion kills me!" Fortunately, zoo security was able to rescue him after he fell into a moat before reaching the animals, and he was later handed over to police for psychiatric evaluation.

This Easter article reveals that one Crème egg will take 19 minutes of skipping to burn off and contains almost seven teaspoons of sugar - more than half the 50g the World Health Organisation recommends per day. A nutritionist warns that consuming too much sugar can overstrain the insulin system and trigger insulin resistance, with Dr Christie explaining that "insulin resistance puts you at a metabolic disadvantage to lose weight" and can eventually lead to type 2 diabetes over time.

The Havasupai tribe, consisting of more than 600 people, represents the smallest Indian nation in America and lives in the secret village of Supai, hidden at the bottom of Havasu Canyon within the Grand Canyon. This remote Indian village is accessible only by foot, helicopter, or mule, being located eight miles from the nearest road. The canyon settlement relies primarily on tourism for income, with about 20,000 visitors annually coming to experience the tribe's culture and the area's stunning natural features like Havasu Falls.

A new jab against malaria called RTS,S, the first malaria vaccine to reach advanced trials, could prevent millions of cases of the disease that kills over 580,000 people annually. In clinical trials, the vaccine prevented an average of 1,363 cases of malaria over four years for every 1,000 children vaccinated, with even better results for those who received booster shots. While the vaccine's effectiveness diminished over time and was less effective in younger children, researchers believe RTS,S could make a substantial contribution to controlling malaria, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa where children are most at risk.

Chilean pickpockets have become the most effective thieves operating in central London, with gangs of up to six members targeting wealthy shoppers and tourists in the West End before stealing their cash and belongings. Plain-clothes officers tasked with reducing theft in the area report that these organized international gangs operate strategically, often disguising themselves as families or businesspeople to avoid detection. While statistics show that about 70% of arrested pickpockets are Romanian or Bulgarian, the Chilean gangs are considered particularly sophisticated in their intelligence-led approach to theft.

National Grid has revealed the UK's first new electricity pylon design in nearly 90 years, called the T-pylon, which is about a third shorter than traditional lattice pylons but can carry the same 400,000 volts of power. The new T-shaped design with distinctive "hanging baskets" is being built and tested at a training facility in Nottinghamshire and is intended to be less obtrusive than the current 88,000 lattice pylons across the UK. National Grid plans to use these new T-pylons for future transmission routes, including connecting the Hinkley Point C nuclear power station, rather than replacing existing infrastructure.

Holly Nicole Solomon, now 31, has pleaded guilty to aggravated assault after admitting to running over her husband Daniel with their SUV in a Mesa parking lot following an argument about his failure to vote in the 2012 presidential election. Solomon was upset about Barack Obama's reelection, telling police she believed her family would face hardship as a result, and chased her husband around the parking lot with the vehicle before hitting him. She will serve three and a half years in prison as part of a plea deal, while her husband suffered critical injuries including a shattered pelvis.

Student Drew Hollinshead, 21, received a £70 parking ticket after he stopped his car in a disabled bay to help an elderly woman who had collapsed on the pavement. Despite helping the woman for less than a minute, a traffic warden issued the ticket while Hollinshead was assisting her, leading him to call the situation "ridiculous." Bournemouth Council's Parking Services suggested he could appeal the ticket, with officials stating they consider mitigating circumstances in individual cases.

Builders in China are constructing a mountain road thousands of feet above the ground in Pingjiang County, Hunan province, working without safety harnesses or ropes and using only hard hats for protection as they carry heavy materials across rickety wooden walkways. The workers are building these precarious walkways as tourist attractions, with Chinese officials hoping the dangerous-looking scenic routes will draw thousands more visitors to the mountainous area. The construction involves workers balancing on rusty scaffolding poles and wooden planks while hammering supports into the mountainside to extend the walkway around steep cliff faces.

Independent investigators uncovered significant failings at two NHS hospitals operated by North Pennine Acute Hospitals NHS Trust after seven babies and three mothers died within eight months, including four babies and two mothers at Royal Oldham and three babies and one mother at North Manchester General. The investigation found notable problems with clinical leadership, care planning, and risk management in the maternity services, including the case of Lisa Parkisson who died 48 hours after giving birth at Oldham Royal. The trust is now developing an action plan to address the identified issues and improve maternity care safety.

In Ferguson's first city election since white police officer Darren Wilson shot and killed unarmed black teenager Michael Brown, voters turned out in higher-than-normal numbers at the polls to elect a new City Council that now reflects the city's demographics, with two African-American candidates winning seats to make the six-member council 50% black in a city that is 70% black. Brian Fletcher, a former mayor who launched the "I Love Ferguson" campaign, won his council seat despite critics claiming he was part of the old guard, while winning candidate Wesley Bell said he wants Ferguson's police officers to be judged by community relationships rather than ticket quotas. The election marked a significant change for Ferguson, as candidates actively campaigned door-to-door and the community showed unprecedented engagement in local politics following months of protests and calls for reform.

Australia's World Cup-winning batsman Aaron Finch underwent surgery on his left hamstring and will be sidelined for up to three months after sustaining a high grade hamstring injury while playing for the Mumbai Indians in the Indian Premier League. The Australian opener and T20 captain had the operation on Tuesday in Melbourne, with team physiotherapist Alex Kountouris confirming that Finch's rehabilitation is expected to take up to 12 weeks.

AP McCoy won the Melling Chase at Aintree on Friday riding Don Cossack, trained by Irishman Gordon Elliott, defeating Cue Card by 26 lengths in his penultimate race before retirement. Ironically, Elliott also trains Cause of Causes, one of the horses McCoy could have ridden in Saturday's Grand National instead of his chosen mount Shutthefrontdoor. The victory marked McCoy's second win of his final Aintree meeting as he prepares for his last Grand National appearance.

Vince Cable prides himself on being the Tories' least popular Cabinet member, with David Cameron and George Osborne privately describing him as a "closet Labour politician" in contrast to how they regard Nick Clegg as a "closet Conservative." Despite years of fighting Conservatives and acknowledging their "nasty and vicious" behavior, Business Secretary Cable says he is willing to work with the Tories for another five years and even wants to replace George Osborne as Chancellor, believing his economic expertise would reassure voters who worry that "would-be PM Red Ed might do something barmy."

A survey found that the average British worker will sit through 6,239 meetings in their career, with 60 per cent saying they find most meetings 'pretty pointless'. One in five workers confessed to messing something up due to zoning out in a work meeting, and the same proportion admits to falling asleep during meetings. The research reveals widespread disengagement, with 70 per cent of workers constantly zoning out and many thinking about dinner plans or what they'll watch on TV that night instead of focusing on the meeting content.

A math puzzle from the Singapore and Asian Schools Math Olympiad asking "When is Cheryl's birthday?" went viral after baffling people worldwide, despite being designed for 14-year-olds. The puzzle involves Albert and Bernard trying to determine Cheryl's birthday from a list of 10 possible dates, with Albert knowing only the month and Bernard knowing only the day, leading them through logical deductions based on their statements. Through a series of reasoning steps that eliminate dates based on what Albert and Bernard reveal they know, the answer is determined to be July 16.

Army Major John Jackson and his wife Carolyn are on trial for allegedly abusing their three young foster children over several years, causing broken bones, bruises, and other serious health problems through withholding food and water and physical punishment. This is their second trial after the first ended in a mistrial when a prosecutor improperly mentioned the death of one of their sons, and while the couple had three biological children who showed no signs of abuse, they are charged only with abusing the foster children. The defense argues that while their parenting methods may be objectionable, they don't constitute criminal behavior since the couple believed they were acting in good faith as parents.

Spanish newspapers report that Real Madrid will likely be without Karim Benzema for their Champions League quarter-final second leg clash against rivals Atletico Madrid on Wednesday, as the French striker continues to struggle with a knee injury that caused him to miss Madrid's 3-1 victory against Malaga. Despite coach Carlo Ancelotti's earlier optimism about Benzema's return, Marca headlines "Benzema still doubtful" and reports that Madrid may also be without Modric and Bale for the crucial Champions League match. The uncertainty over key players has put pressure on Ancelotti as he searches for the right formation for Madrid's Champions League clash against their city rivals.

The culprits behind the £60m Hatton Garden heist in London may have carried out a similarly audacious burglary two years earlier in Berlin, where thieves targeted 294 security vaults at the Volksbank in Steglitz in January 2013. Both robberies share striking similarities, including the use of heavy-duty drills to break through concrete walls, tunneling techniques, disguising as workmen, and timing the raids over weekends when buildings were empty. While the Berlin tunnel bank robbery netted £8.3m from 294 vaults, the London heist saw robbers raid 71 security boxes, with both crimes remaining unsolved and showing nearly identical methodologies.

A father captured his toddler daughter Viktoria's crestfallen reaction on camera as she watched The Lion King for the first time, specifically the haunting scene where Mufasa is murdered by his evil brother Scar, leaving Simba fatherless. The emotional video shows Viktoria's bottom lip trembling and tears filling her eyes as she witnesses one of Disney's most tear-jerking spectacles. The footage, posted to Facebook, has garnered over four million views as viewers connect with the little girl's genuine emotional response to the tragic scene.

A couple in their 40s became unusual victims of age discrimination when HSBC rejected their £250,000 mortgage application because the husband would be over 65 when the 18-year loan term ended. The Financial Ombudsman Service found HSBC guilty of unfair treatment, ruling that the bank "relied on untested assumptions, stereotypes or generalisations in respect of age," and ordered the bank to pay £500 compensation and reconsider the loan application. This marked the first time the ombudsman has upheld a mortgage complaint specifically on the grounds of age discrimination.

Dr. Kristen Lindsey, a Texas veterinarian, allegedly shot a cat with an arrow and posted a photo on Facebook showing herself holding the animal's body by the arrow's shaft, calling it her "first bow kill." The social media post sparked massive public outrage, leading to her firing from the animal clinic where she worked, and sheriffs' dispatchers being overwhelmed with complaint calls. An investigation is underway and Lindsey could face charges for the shooting.

Professor Ninian Peckitt, a pioneering facial surgeon who specializes in treating disfigured patients with titanium implants, is accused of repeatedly punching a patient in the face in an attempt to correct a fracture caused by an industrial accident during surgery at Ipswich Hospital in 2012. The 63-year-old world-renowned surgeon faces being struck off the medical register after being accused of failing three patients, including Patient C who was treated for a complex facial deformity without seeking advice from another surgeon. Peckitt denies the allegations, claiming he only "digitally manipulated" the patient's face, but witnesses testified they saw him actually hitting the patient.

Actor Ben Powers, best known for playing Thelma's husband Keith on the CBS sitcom "Good Times" during its final season (1978-1979), died April 6 at the age of 64 at his New Bedford, Massachusetts home. Powers also played the character Moochie on "Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer" and appeared in various films and TV shows throughout his career. His on-screen wife from "Good Times," Bern Nadette Stanis, paid tribute to the actor's death on social media, calling him "a great actor and great friend who is gone too soon."

Derby went into the game knowing they needed to win to keep their automatic promotion hopes alive, but fell behind to Alex Pritchard's brilliant strike in the 21st minute that put Brentford ahead. Brentford controlled large portions of the match and missed several second-half chances to extend their lead. However, Derby grabbed a dramatic equalizer in stoppage time when Darren Bent pounced to score his 10th goal of the season, rescuing a 1-1 draw that was harsh on Brentford who had dominated the game.

A gang of armed robbers used pink umbrellas to conceal their identities during a two-month crime spree in which they stole £145,000 from 13 shops across the West Midlands. The four-man gang, including 21-year-old Marcus Morgan and 26-year-old Ashleigh Evans, threatened staff with weapons including hammers, knives, and screwdrivers while targeting supermarkets, convenience stores, and electrical shops. All four members were eventually arrested and sentenced to a combined total of more than 27 years in prison after pleading guilty to conspiracy to rob.

Italian explorer Alex Bellini is seeking funding for his project called "Adrift," which involves spending a year living alone inside a ball-shaped survival capsule on top of a melting iceberg in Greenland starting in November 2016. The daring stunt aims to raise awareness about global warming and climate change theories by demonstrating how icebergs melt around the world, with Bellini facing extreme dangers including the possibility that the iceberg could flip and dramatically change its center of mass. Despite the risks of isolation, falling into cracks, or being trapped under ice, Mr. Bellini believes this extreme endurance challenge will bring important attention to climate change issues and inspire more sustainable living.

A photograph circulating on Snapchat is believed to show disgraced principal Andrew Barr watching pornography in his office at the elite private school Geelong College. The image, allegedly taken by a student through a window, shows a man at a computer with graphic content on the screen. Mr Barr tendered his resignation after the school conducted an investigation following the photograph's circulation on social media, with school officials calling it a serious breach of standards.

Thirty-year-old Francis Pusok was beaten by police officers more than 80 times after fleeing his California home to avoid arrest on identity theft charges, with helicopter cameras capturing the assault that continued even after he was handcuffed and tased. Pusok claims he was handcuffed within 15 seconds but the beating continued with officers yelling "stop resisting" while he lay face down, and his girlfriend Jolene Bindner expressed concern about a deputy's whispered threat that "this isn't over." The incident has prompted an FBI investigation into excessive force, with 10 officers placed on paid administrative leave following the disturbing footage.

The extremist group Hizb ut-Tahrir (HT) has reportedly joined forces with al-Qaeda in Syria, with several British men linked to ISIS including Mohammed 'Jihadi John' Emwazi known to have been in contact with the group while studying at UK universities. Liberal Democrat parliamentary candidate Maajid Nawaz, who was a member of HT for 13 years before renouncing his views, has been caught on video attempting to touch a lap dancer at an East London strip club during Ramadan, with the club owner criticizing the way Nawaz portrays himself as a feminist while acting hypocritically. Other British connections to HT include 21-year-old Waheed Ahmed, son of a Labour councillor, who was arrested trying to cross into Syria and is said to be a member of the group.

Marks & Spencer is introducing a new tropical fruit called the Bouea macrophylla, nicknamed the "plango" or mango plum, which features bright orange edible skin and tastes like an Alphonso mango but with a softer texture. The fruit offers all the delicious flavor of a mango without the preparation hassle since customers can eat the skin directly. This interesting fruit, developed through years of work with Thai growers, will be available in M&S stores starting this weekend.

The University of Cape Town in South Africa is set to remove a defaced statue of British colonialist Cecil Rhodes today, following a month of student protests against the monument that black students viewed as a symbol of historical white oppression. The removal has sparked counter-protests from white solidarity groups who are demanding protection for their heritage, while other historical statues have also been vandalized during the campus demonstrations. The controversial decision marks what the government calls a significant shift in how South Africa deals with its colonial past.

Hannah Bluck, an 18-year-old Welsh international footballer, has been sidelined for two years after being diagnosed with avascular necrosis, an ultra-rare condition causing bone death due to poor blood supply in her shin bone. Doctors warned that her leg could collapse into her ankle if she returns to physical activity too soon, effectively halting her promising career after she had represented Wales at multiple youth levels. Despite the devastating diagnosis, Manchester United supporter Hannah continues training and coaching while hoping to eventually return to professional football and earn a senior Wales cap.

Paris Saint-Germain forward Edinson Cavani has rejected rumors of a poor relationship with team-mate Zlatan Ibrahimovic, insisting they respect each other professionally despite not being close friends. The former Napoli forward admits his only frustration is being played out of his preferred striker position alongside Ibrahimovic, rather than any personal issues with the Swedish star. This comes after PSG's 3-2 win against Marseilles, where both players featured as the team continues to manage the partnership between their two star forwards.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for next month's UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, with the defending champions having beaten Holland on penalties in last year's final. The squad includes Chelsea youngster Jay Dasilva and Arsenal's Chris Willock, who receives his first call-up, as England prepares to face Italy, Holland, and Ireland in Group D. England will open their campaign against Italy on May 7 as they look to defend their title.

Fireball Cinnamon Whisky has become America's fastest-growing liquor brand and the sixth-most popular by retail sales, transforming from modest beginnings when the Sazerac Co. rebranded it in 2006 and hired a national brand ambassador to promote it in college towns and bars. The sweet, cinnamon-flavored whisky gained massive traction through social media marketing and word-of-mouth, with retail sales jumping from under $2 million in 2011 to $130 million last year, though Fireball's skyrocketing growth has recently slowed amid increased competition and questions about whether it's just a fad.

A study led by the University of Montana and published in the International Journal of Sport Nutrition and Exercise Metabolism found that eating fast food after a workout may be just as beneficial as dietary supplements during recovery periods. Researchers tested 11 male athletes who completed a 90-minute endurance workout, then were fed either fast food or sports supplements, and found that performance remained the same regardless of which food was consumed during the recovery period between exercise sessions. The study suggests that during recovery periods between periods of exercise, it didn't matter what food was eaten, as both groups showed similar glycogen levels and exercise performance.

Frenchman Gael Monfils knocked Roger Federer out of the Monte Carlo Masters with a thrilling 6-4, 7-6 victory in the last-16, displaying breathtaking athleticism and focused play that showcased his potential. The world No 18 Monfils hit 22 winners to Federer's 17 in the straight-sets upset, with his loss putting Monfils through to his first quarter-final in Monaco. Monfils celebrated after the impressive win over the 17-time Grand Slam winner, advancing to face Grigor Dimitrov in what promises to be an explosive quarter-final match.

Reverend Al Sharpton delivered a sermon at Charity Missionary Baptist Church in North Charleston on Sunday, addressing the Walter Scott shooting case and calling for national policing reform, with North Charleston Mayor Keith Summey and Police Chief Eddie Driggers in attendance. Scott, a black driver, was fatally shot by white police officer Michael Slager during a traffic stop, and Slager has been charged with murder and dismissed from the force. Sharpton praised the mayor's swift action in firing the officer and suggested that North Charleston could set a new tone for policing across the United States.

Stewart Brand argues that despite warnings the planet is facing a sixth mass extinction like the five mass extinction events in Earth's history, widespread extinctions may actually be overstated as many threatened species are recovering and the current extinction rate of one percent per decade is lower than the species discovery rate. He believes the focus on extinction threats is harmful and simplistic, noting that biodiversity is actually increasing, and advocates for using biotechnology to reintroduce extinct species rather than viewing conservation issues as overwhelming global problems.

ISIS has created an extensive bureaucratic system with many official documents relating to matters like birth certificates, vaccination schedules, and rent disputes, demonstrating how the group sees itself as a legitimate government operating under Sharia law conditions. After ISIS fighters swept through areas like Mosul, they preserved existing systems like universities and hospitals but imposed strict Islamic interpretations, banning subjects like archaeology and democracy while maintaining services like healthcare and education. What distinguishes ISIS from groups like the Taliban is their more pragmatic approach to governance - they allow girls' education until age 15, permit vaccinations, and focus on winning over populations by lowering bread prices and addressing local complaints, all while using religious justification to present themselves as a moral authority.

Milwaukee police say that Archie Brown Jr., who struck and killed a 2-year-old with his van on Sunday evening, was shot dead at the scene by an unidentified gunman in what appears to be a revenge killing. A 15-year-old boy was also shot during the incident and later died at the hospital, though his connection to the tragedy remains unclear. Brown Jr., a father of four and real estate entrepreneur, was murdered while waiting at the accident scene for police to arrive.

Betting odds strongly favor the Duchess of Cambridge giving birth to a baby girl soon, with 90% of wagers placed on a female child and popular birth dates being April 18th-20th despite the official due date of April 25th. Top name choices include Alice and Victoria for a girl (with Victoria sharing lineage to Queen Victoria and Sweden's Crown Princess Victoria) and James for a boy (honoring both the Duchess's brother and historical monarchs like James II). A Ladbrokes spokesman notes that "punters all over the UK are convinced Kate will give birth to a baby girl soon," with perhaps only "the bookies, and maybe Prince George" hoping for a boy.

Presenters Holly Willoughby, 34, and Davina McCall have joined forces in their first campaign together for Garnier Nutrisse, which celebrates finding the perfect hair shade. This Morning presenter Holly said she "absolutely loved shooting with Davina" and that they are working together to help UK women find their perfect shade. The campaign features the two television personalities showing off their glossy locks and playfully posing together in the promotional shoot.

A New York judge has ruled that Ellanora Arthur Baidoo can serve her husband with divorce papers through Facebook after she has been trying to divorce him for several years but couldn't locate him through traditional means. Before allowing her to use Facebook, Baidoo had to prove the Facebook account belongs to her husband and that he regularly uses it, after her husband refused to make himself available to be served with the summons. This landmark decision establishes social media as an acceptable legal method for serving divorce papers when conventional service methods have been exhausted.

The Turin Shroud, believed by devotees to be the burial cloth that wrapped Jesus Christ's body, went on public display for the first time in five years, with more than one million people having already booked slots to view it until June 24. The Holy Shroud bears the image of a crucified man, though researchers have been unable to determine exactly how the image was created, and while some date it to medieval times, it retains mystical significance for many believers. Pope Francis decreed this latest exhibition to commemorate the 200th anniversary of St. John Bosco's birth, and the Pope himself is scheduled to visit the display in June.

A recently built luxury mansion on central London's Farm Street, constructed on the site of a former milking parlour, has gone on the market for £25 million. London's milking parlours date back to Tudor times, with Farm Street serving as a hub of agricultural trade where cows were brought for milking and sold to local butchers. The four-bedroom property features modern amenities including an indoor swimming pool, gym, cinema room, and a master suite that takes up the entire second floor, representing contemporary living in historic Mayfair.

As the final episodes of the current Poldark series approach, BBC1 boss Charlotte Moore confirmed that heartthrob Aidan Turner's broody Ross would return for a second series of the BBC period drama, which has captured the nation's hearts with an average of 8.1 million viewers per episode. The series, based on Winston Graham's 12 Poldark books, follows Ross Poldark after he returns from the American War of Independence to find his life dramatically changed, and has helped BBC1 achieve its strongest start to a year in a decade.

A gastrointestinal illness outbreak has affected 100 people aboard the cruise ship Celebrity Infinity, with 95 of the ship's 2,117 passengers and 5 crew members suffering from symptoms including vomiting and diarrhea, according to the CDC. Celebrity Cruises has implemented increased cleaning procedures and is cooperating with the Centers for Disease Control, which is sending staff to investigate the cause when the ship returns to San Diego. This marks the third such outbreak on the Celebrity Infinity, following previous incidents in 2006 and 2013.

UltraHaptics is developing revolutionary technology that enables "feeling without touching" by using ultrasound to create tactile three-dimensional shapes and invisible interfaces in mid-air through controlled air pressure changes. While virtual reality seems unstoppable with companies like Facebook's Oculus Rift leading the charge, current VR technology completely bypasses the sense of touch, making UltraHaptics' innovation particularly valuable for creating more immersive experiences. The technology has broad applications beyond VR, potentially transforming how we interact with electronic devices by creating invisible buttons and controls that users can feel and manipulate without physical contact.

Jodie Barden, 28, faces the heartbreaking reality of planning funerals for her two daughters, eight-year-old Ella and one-year-old Chloe, who both suffer from the rare genetic disorder Cockayne Syndrome (CS), which gives patients a life expectancy of just 12 years. Ella was diagnosed at Great Ormond Street in 2012, and CS sufferers usually don't live to see their teenage years, with those affected at birth having a life expectancy of only 3-7 years. Despite the devastating prognosis, the family is making the most of their time together while raising money for charity, with Essex charity Wipe Away Those Tears sending them to Disneyland Paris, and Ella currently experiencing symptoms like tremors that make daily activities difficult.

Eleven-year-old Damon Muller was diagnosed with Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM), a rare life-threatening autoimmune disease that causes severe rashes when exposed to sun and muscle weakness throughout his body. Since his November diagnosis, Damon has nearly doubled in size due to swelling from high-dose steroid treatments and can no longer play outside freely, as sun exposure triggers dangerous reactions including throat swelling that nearly closed his airway. The disease has transformed him from an active child to someone who can barely move and must stay indoors most of the time to avoid potentially life-threatening flare-ups.

Prince Harry's former girlfriend Chelsy Davy debuted a sophisticated and glamorous style at the launch party for new London restaurant The Ivy Chelsea Garden on Tuesday. The 29-year-old Zimbabwean socialite wore a white chiffon top with navy trousers and appeared in high spirits as she mingled with friends at the event. Davy, who dated Prince Harry for six years until 2010, showcased a more mature fashion sense as she approaches her thirties.

Hundreds attended the funeral ceremony in France for nine-year-old Chloe, who was raped and murdered by Polish migrant Zbigniew Huminski after he abducted her from a playground outside her home. Huminski, a career criminal who confessed to the crimes, was arrested near Chloe's lifeless body in woodland and has been formally charged with kidnapping, rape and murder. The tragic killing sparked national outrage in France, with over 6,000 people participating in a memorial march for the young victim.

A lack of iron, particularly low ferritin levels (stored iron rather than iron in blood), is known to trigger hair loss in women, with some experts recommending iron pills that contain iron to address this deficiency, though the evidence for supplementation remains mixed. Since hair consists of protein, maintaining adequate protein intake and eating protein with meals is vital for strong, healthy hair, as insufficient protein can cause people to shed hair. However, dietary changes and supplements typically take 2-6 months to show noticeable improvements in hair growth and thickness.

Meet Suma, a 36-year-old orangutan at Melbourne Zoo who suffers from arthritis, a painful condition first diagnosed in 2013 that initially required giving Suma daily pain medication. Suma was recently treated by orthopaedic surgeon Associate Professor Marino Pirpiris and senior vet Dr. Helen McCracken, who performed X-rays and administered a steroid injection to reduce her pain for months or potentially years. The comprehensive health examination allowed doctors to assess how her arthritic condition has progressed over the past two years while also conducting a full check-up of her overall health.

New pictures and Snapchat videos have emerged showing One Direction's Louis Tomlinson partying with five girls at London's Soho Hotel, where he was photographed in his hotel room appearing to roll a suspicious cigarette. The Snapchat video shows Louis back in his room with female friends who jokingly pretended not to know which member of One Direction he was, with the partying continuing until at least 5:48am. Although Louis was seen returning to the Soho Hotel in the same Brooklyn-emblazoned jumper from earlier photos, the original picture showed Louis perching on the edge of a sofa in the hotel room next to what appeared to be drug paraphernalia.

Photos taken between 1900 and 1911 during the Qing dynasty show Beijing's famous landmarks, including the Temple of Heaven, Western Qing Tombs, and Summer Palace, with barely any visitors present. These century-old images offer a rare glimpse of popular tourist attractions like Beijing's Summer Palace and other sites that are now UNESCO World Heritage Sites, captured at a time when they had virtually no foreign tourists. The quiet scenes contrast sharply with modern-day Beijing, which is now visited by tens of millions of domestic and international tourists every year.

Australian capital cities can expect record-breaking profits at property auctions this weekend, as a CoreLogic report reveals that home resales recording a gross loss hit an all-time low of just 8.6 percent, with more properties making substantial profits than ever before. Melbourne properties performed particularly well, experiencing extremely low resale losses of only 5.6 percent, while some homes sold for more than double their original purchase price. The strong performance in capital cities contrasts with regional markets, where the profit trend has not yet taken hold, making it an excellent time for sellers but challenging for buyers in major metropolitan areas.

West Brom manager Tony Pulis led his side to a 2-0 victory over his former employers Crystal Palace in a typical Tony Pulis performance, with West Brom midfielder James Morrison scoring within two minutes and Craig Gardner adding a stunning second-half strike. Despite Alan Pardew's Crystal Palace dominating much of the game, they were unable to break down West Brom's stubborn defensive display. The victory moved West Brom to 36 points, virtually guaranteeing their Premier League survival under Pulis's management.

Crystal Palace co-chairman Steve Parish described a "great moment" after his club's 2-1 victory over champions Manchester City, posing for a celebratory photo with Palace manager Alan Pardew, England boss Roy Hodgson, and Bill Wyman, an original member of The Rolling Stones and devoted Palace fan for 68 years. Parish shared the Instagram photo highlighting the presence of the legendary Rolling Stones bassist, who has been supporting the club since age 10 despite his decades-long rock career.

The Solar Impulse 2, an experimental single-seater aircraft attempting to fly around the world using only solar power, has been grounded in China for over two weeks due to unfavorable weather conditions that don't meet the aircraft's need for near-perfect flying conditions with crosswinds under 4 knots. The solar-powered plane, which stores energy during the day to fly through the night, had its Thursday takeoff canceled because crosswinds at the expected landing time in Nanjing were forecast to be too strong. While the team waits for better weather, pilot Bertrand Piccard continues training for the upcoming Pacific and Atlantic Ocean crossings, which are considered the most critical parts of their 12-year mission to prove the power of renewable energy.

Fresh from his Masters triumph, Augusta record-equalling champion Jordan Spieth visited the Empire State Building while proudly wearing his green jacket, having broken several scoring records including equaling Tiger Woods' 18-under total from 1997. Spieth faced a crucial moment on the 16th hole where Justin Rose praised his par-saving putt as "one of the best," helping secure his four-stroke victory and positioning him as world No. 2 behind Rory McIlroy. The Masters champion's dominant performance, particularly when his shot came up perfectly on key holes unlike his disappointing finish the previous year, has sparked discussions about a potential rivalry with McIlroy as golf craves new stars.

Etiquette expert William Hanson has created a household audit to determine how "posh" people's homes really are, inspired by the recent scrutiny of current Prime Minister David Cameron's kitchen and Britain's ongoing obsession with class. The audit includes specific requirements like using bar soap instead of liquid, choosing fabric over leather sofas, and avoiding the "pesky middle-middle classes'" preference for fancy coffee machines over simple cafetieres. Hanson's scoring system rates homes from upper class (14-18 points) down to lower-middle class (1-4 points), with Samantha and David Cameron's home serving as a benchmark for upper-class living standards.

Andy Murray tied the knot with Kim Sears on Saturday at the historic 12th century Dunblane Cathedral, with thousands of Murray fans gathering outside to celebrate the wedding day. The tennis star tweeted his wedding day plans using emojis showing his excitement, while extensive wedding preparations included florists decorating the cathedral with bouquets and cherry blossom trees despite challenging weather conditions. The ceremony took place around 4:00pm with family and close friends in attendance, marking a joyous occasion for the couple who have been together for over nine years.

Alastair Cook has been working on a new, more open batting stance with former England batting coach Graham Gooch, but appears to have overdone the adjustment during the first Test against the West Indies. The article compares pictures showing Cook playing against India in 2007 with a near-perfect stance versus his overly open stance against the West Indies, where his front foot positioning made it difficult to reach deliveries and led to his dismissal for just 13 runs. Despite the technical struggles, Cook showed promise in recent net sessions under England head coach Peter Moores, suggesting he shouldn't be written off yet.

Dani Alves looks set to leave Barcelona this summer after his representative confirmed the Brazilian right-back had rejected the club's final contract offer. The 31-year-old has been unable to agree a new deal with the Catalan club, with his agent confirming he turned down a three-year contract extension that required him to play in 60 percent of matches. Alves, who has won multiple titles during his seven years at Barcelona, is now being linked with clubs including Manchester United, Manchester City, and Paris Saint-Germain.

Robin Ellis, who shot to fame in the 1970s as the original Ross Poldark, was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes by chance in 1999 at aged 58 and is now 73. Despite being slim all his life, Robin developed type 2 diabetes (where the body's cells fail to react to insulin properly), though his mother had the entirely different type 1 diabetes condition. Through strict dietary changes eliminating refined carbohydrates and regular exercise, Robin managed his condition without medication for ten years before recently needing drugs, proving that diabetes can be successfully managed with lifestyle modifications.

Former New England Patriots tight end Aaron Hernandez, who was convicted of first-degree murder for killing 27-year-old Odin Lloyd in 2013, has been transferred from Cedar Junction prison to the maximum-security Souza-Baranowski Correctional Center in Massachusetts. A state prisons official confirmed that Hernandez was moved to his new prison on Wednesday, about a week after being sentenced to life behind bars. It remains unknown which cell block Hernandez will be placed in at the maximum-security facility, with options including solitary confinement, general population, or the "lifers block" for those serving life sentences.

Jamie Robbins, a robber who stole £1,600 from a convenience store in Birmingham with an accomplice using a weapon, handed himself into police a year after the crime because he preferred life in jail. The 35-year-old walked into a police station and asked to be arrested, providing full details of the planned robbery that police had been unable to solve. Robbins was subsequently jailed for four-and-a-half years after pleading guilty to robbery and possession of a bladed article.

The world's first cloned camel, Injaz, who was created from ovarian cells of a slaughtered camel in 2009 and born via surrogate mother, is now pregnant after conceiving naturally at six years old. This pregnancy proves that cloned camels are fertile and can reproduce like naturally-born camels, marking a significant milestone since the first mammal was cloned 19 years ago with Dolly the sheep. Camels are valuable in Gulf states for racing, transport, and beauty contests, making cloning technology important for preserving their genetics.

Former Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson revealed why he rates Cristiano Ronaldo above Lionel Messi while speaking to 1991 World Snooker Champion John Parrott over a frame of snooker during BBC's coverage of the World Championship. Ferguson believes his former United player Ronaldo is superior because "Ronaldo could play for Millwall, QPR, Doncaster Rovers, anyone, and score a hat-trick," arguing that Messi is more dependent on Barcelona's system. Although Ferguson struggled to impress against Parrott at snooker, he shared anecdotes about his playing days and revealed he had previously beaten former player Paul Ince at the game.

On Saturday night, the team bus carrying Fenerbahce players and coaching staff was shot at after their away game, with the driver being hit by a bullet and injured, requiring hospitalization. None of the players were hurt in the attack, which occurred near the city of Trabzon as the bus was heading to the airport. Separately, Caykur Rizespor midfielder Ludovic Obraniak was taken to hospital with a suspected heart problem during the match, though he was later given the all-clear after fears of a heart attack.

Nicola Ferguson Sturgeon clearly revelled in her TV debate performance, addressing a nationwide British audience rather than just the usual five million Scots, with many people outside Scotland getting their first proper view of the First Minister who was dubbed "Scotland's Queen" by young fans. Judy Murray tweeted "GSM Sturgeon" (Game, Set and Match) after the beguiling Sturgeon's strong showing, which led to widespread Google searches about whether non-Scots could vote for the SNP. The article argues that Sturgeon poses a significant threat to British politics, as her party could hold the balance of power after the election and potentially force through left-wing policies that could destabilize the union between England and Scotland.

Ireland prop Declan Fitzpatrick, 31, has been forced to retire from rugby on medical grounds after experiencing multiple concussions in recent seasons. Ulster said that Fitzpatrick had suffered a number of concussive episodes with symptoms that were progressively slower to resolve, leading medical experts to recommend retirement in his long-term interests. The veteran player, who earned seven caps for Ireland and made 98 appearances for Ulster Rugby, accepted the medical advice despite the difficulty of the decision.

Oregon-based defense contractor FLIR Systems Inc. has agreed to pay $9.5 million to settle bribery charges filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission involving expensive trips and gifts given to Middle Eastern government officials. The SEC found that two employees in FLIR's Dubai office gave luxury watches to five Saudi Arabia Ministry of Interior officials in 2009 and arranged lavish travel for them, including a 20-night trip with stops in multiple international cities. The two former sales employees, Stephen Timms and Yasser Ramahi, also agreed to settle SEC charges against them and pay financial penalties.

Showtime has released a short promotional video that takes viewers inside Floyd Mayweather Jr's training camp ahead of his $300 million mega fight against Manny Pacquiao on May 2 at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas. The video shows Mayweather working intensively in preparation for what's being called the "Fight of the Century," with the undefeated boxer stating he has "never wanted to win a fight so bad in my life." Mayweather is currently down to within three-and-a-half pounds of the 147 lbs welterweight limit as he prepares for the highly anticipated bout.

Diwalinen Vankar, 58, heroically saved her 19-year-old daughter Kanta from a 13ft mugger crocodile that attacked and clasped onto her leg while they were washing clothes at the Vishwamitri River in west India. Using a wooden washing paddle, Vankar fought the crocodile for 10 minutes until she freed her daughter from its jaws. Kanta suffered a leg injury but has since recovered and been discharged from the hospital.

This article counts down the 20 greatest shots in Masters history (numbers 20-11), featuring memorable moments like Mark O'Meara's winning 20-foot putt in 1998 after shooting two birdies in his final three holes, and Charl Schwartzel's incredible victory three years ago that included remarkable shots like a 100-foot chip-in for birdie and a slam-dunk eagle. The countdown also highlights other legendary Masters moments, including Billy Joe Patton's near-upset as an amateur who came within a stroke of forcing a playoff, and Seve Ballesteros's second Masters victory that featured spectacular shot-making throughout his dominant performance.

The stars of Married at First Sight embark on their honeymoons in tonight's episode, but all three couples face serious relationship troubles during what should be their 'honeymoon' period. Jaclyn Methuen, who nearly left husband Ryan Ranellone at the altar due to his appearance, continues putting him in the friend zone during their Puerto Rico trip and confesses in a web exclusive clip that she wanted to be a runaway bride, though she does allow some small intimacy like letting Ryan rub sunscreen on her. The other couples, including Davina Kullar and her new husband Sean Varricchio, also struggle with various marital problems during their romantic getaways.

The Taliban has released an 11-page biography of their reclusive leader Mullah Mohammed Omar, aimed at dispelling rumors of Omar's demise after he disappeared following the U.S.-led bombing campaign that routed the Taliban from Kabul in 2001. The biography details Omar's early life, including how he studied at a religious school and later commanded rebel groups against Soviet forces during the 1980s, losing sight in his right eye during the fighting. Afghan observers believe the publication is intended to reassure followers that Omar is still alive and leading the movement, especially as speculation about his death has grown due to years without any video or audio recordings from the fugitive leader.

The New England Patriots are awaiting results from the NFL's "Deflategate" investigation, which has lasted over three months, into allegations that 11 of 12 game balls were underinflated during their AFC Championship game victory. The league hired attorney Ted Wells, who previously investigated the Miami Dolphins bullying scandal, with assistance from NFL executive Jeff Pash to conduct the investigation. Patriots quarterback Tom Brady called the accusation of using deflated footballs "ridiculous," while head coach Bill Belichick maintained the team follows all rules, though the Patriots could face fines or lose draft picks if found guilty of wrongdoing.

Former model Bianca Gascoigne, daughter of ex-England footballer Paul Gascoigne, was targeted and mugged by a gang of eight attackers on bikes in central London who stole her phone containing private texts from her father. The 28-year-old fought back when the muggers attempted to snatch her bag, causing them to flee, but she was left devastated by the theft of her phone with its personal messages. Following the incident, Bianca took to Twitter to brand her attackers "lowlifes on bikes" and expressed her fury that they would be able to access her private communications.

Aberdeen striker Adam Rooney, who has scored 27 goals this season including the winning goal against Dundee United last Saturday, does not want to see Celtic win the league title at Aberdeen's home ground on May 11. With Aberdeen currently eight points behind Celtic, Rooney hopes his team can prevent Celtic from celebrating on their patch and believes Aberdeen could challenge for the title next year if Celtic drop off and they continue building their squad.

Former rap mogul Marion "Suge" Knight was ordered Thursday to stand trial for murder and other charges stemming from a deadly hit-and-run incident, with Judge Ronald Coen also lowering Knight's bail from $25 million to $10 million. Knight, who suffers from diabetes and blood clots, will face trial on one count of murder, one count of attempted murder, and one count of hit-and-run after the judge dismissed one of the original two hit-and-run counts. The case involves Knight allegedly running over two men with his vehicle, killing one, while survivor Cle Sloan refused to testify against Knight, and Knight's defense argued he was acting in self-defense.

Hillary Clinton's campaign staged what appeared to be a spontaneous coffee shop meeting in Iowa by having campaign staffer Troy Price recruit three Democratic Party insiders, including Austin Bird (who had worked on President Obama's 2012 presidential re-election campaign and frequently participates in Iowa Democratic Party events) and Iowa College Democrats president Carter Bell. Bird revealed that Price called them to what they thought was a strategy meeting, then drove them to the coffee house where they participated in a "roundtable" with Clinton during her brief Iowa campaign swing. This staging contradicts Clinton's carefully crafted image as a spontaneous, populist candidate connecting with ordinary Iowans.

The UK's first HIV self-testing kit, the 99.7 per cent accurate BioSure HIV Self Test, is now available online and enables people to test themselves privately using a finger-prick blood sample that detects HIV antibodies within 15 minutes. This development is significant given that an estimated 26,000 people in the UK have HIV but are unaware of it and may be transmitting the disease to others, while treatments available mean HIV is now a manageable disease if diagnosed early. Positive test results need to be confirmed by a healthcare professional, and knowing your HIV status is critical for effective treatment and preventing transmission.

The California Department of Corrections, which houses approximately 162,000 inmates, offers several Sensitive Needs Housing Units at facilities like Calipatria State Prison to protect former gang members who have dropped out of prison gangs. These units allow prisoners from different racial and gang backgrounds to interact safely, in stark contrast to the segregated general population where gang affiliations still dictate daily life and can lead to murders and violence. While inmates in these special units can participate in programs and earn minimum wage, those who remain gang-affiliated continue to live under strict rules in solitary confinement, with some waiting in holding cages for transport to their cells.

A personal injury claims company called Direct Assist has collapsed after being fined £80,000 by the Information Commissioner's Office for plaguing households with nuisance calls. The company, based in Bolton, Lancashire, generated 801 complaints between January 2013 and July last year for making unsolicited phone calls to people registered with the Telephone Preference Service, with one complainant being told they would be called for three years until they made a claim. Despite receiving 525 warnings from regulators, Direct Assist continued its illegal marketing practices and has now gone into liquidation.

Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho holds the best clean sheets percentage record in Premier League history, achieving 101 clean sheets from 189 Premier League matches (53.4%), which has twice helped him and Chelsea win Premier League glory with a third title likely in 2014-15. Mourinho's defensive record edges out former Chelsea manager Rafa Benitez, who kept clean sheets in 44.9% of his games, while other notable managers like Arsene Wenger rank lower in the defensive statistics despite their long tenures.

South African authorities detained a 15-year-old girl at Cape Town International Airport after receiving information that she was attempting to leave the country to join the terrorist group ISIS. Airport security located the girl on a Johannesburg-bound flight following an investigation that revealed she had been using social media to interact with suspicious individuals and consume ISIS-related material. The incident highlights the growing global concern about ISIS recruitment of young people, similar to cases like a Virginia teen accused of being an ISIS recruiter and Australian teens who were also stopped at airports while trying to join ISIS.

Ben Powers, who played Thelma's husband Keith Anderson on the final season of the classic CBS sitcom "Good Times" from 1978-1979, has died at age 64. Powers died April 6 in New Bedford, Mass., with no cause of death revealed by his family. Powers also had roles in other TV shows and films, and attended the Rhode Island School of Design before pursuing acting and stand-up comedy.

A 39-year-old man, known on Facebook as Karl Kay, was shot numerous times in an execution-style shooting while sitting in a car in his mother's Altona Meadows driveway at 2am on Sunday, leaving six children without a father. Police believe the incident was targeted and the shooting victim was known to authorities, though they have refused to comment on whether it was gang-related. The man died at the scene despite emergency treatment, and no arrests have been made in connection with the shooting.

Alexander Kutner had a thrilling close encounter with a 4,500lb horned rhino and three others while crawling under a Land Rover at the luxurious Ulusaba Game Reserve, Sir Richard Branson's private reserve in South Africa's Sabi Sands. With 1,000 rhinos killed by poachers in South Africa last year alone, these magnificent animals are increasingly difficult to view, making the sighting with tracker Danny particularly special. The safari experience at this exclusive reserve provided incredible wildlife photography opportunities amid ongoing conservation efforts to protect these endangered species.

George Lucas dropped plans for a Lucasfilm Ltd studio complex in 2012 after facing opposition from neighbors, but now proposes to build the largest affordable housing development in the area on the same land. The complex would provide homes for 224 low-income families across 52 acres of his Lucas Valley estate, costing around $200 million and funded entirely by Lucas himself.

A stunning series of photographs captured the moment a great grey owl with a five-foot wingspan swooped down on a tiny field mouse in the snowy fields of Ontario, Canada. The predatory bird stalked its prey from treetops before launching a silent attack, using its superior sense of hearing and soft feathers to glide undetected. The dramatic hunt was photographed by Marc Latremouille during one of his wildlife photography workshops, showing the owl's impressive hunting skills as it made an inelegant but successful landing to capture the rodent with its sharp claws.

Author Martin Fletcher claims in a new book that the deadly fire that broke out during Bradford's game at Valley Parade in 1985, which killed 56 people, was not an accident as officially ruled. Fletcher alleges that Bradford City's then-chairman Stafford Heginbotham was linked to eight other fires at his business premises over 18 years before the Valley Parade blaze, resulting in insurance payouts totaling around £27 million in today's terms. West Yorkshire police have said they will review any fresh evidence surrounding the tragedy, though the original inquiry concluded the fire was caused by a discarded cigarette.

Manchester City defender Bacary Sagna insists he has no regrets about leaving Arsenal for City last summer, despite facing a potentially trophyless season and City sitting fourth in the Premier League while Arsenal are second. Sagna departed Arsenal after winning the FA Cup but joined the Premier League holders City, who now face losing their title to Chelsea this season. Despite the disappointing campaign, Sagna believes Manuel Pellegrini's City side will return to winning ways and finish the season well, dismissing concerns that City could lose their Champions League qualifying position.

Nigel Farage suggested today that David Cameron has been secretly using hair dye to turn back the years and reverse the greying process while in Downing Street. After shaking Mr Cameron's hand following last week's televised leaders debate, Farage said he was "jealous" of how the Prime Minister has been accused of maintaining his youthful appearance. When asked if he thought Mr Cameron was too vain, Farage replied that politicians "to a certain extent they all are," while a Tory party spokesman refused to comment on whether Mr Cameron dyes his hair.

Australian woman Evita Nicole Sarmonikas, 29, died while undergoing buttock augmentation surgery in Mexico in March, performed by plastic surgeon Dr Victor Ramirez at Hospital Quirurgico del Valle in Mexicali. It has been revealed that Dr Ramirez had lost another patient just a year before Sarmonikas' death, and the clinic attempted to pressure her family to have her body cremated before an official autopsy could be conducted. Her family flew to Mexico to bring her body home and ensure a proper investigation, discovering irregularities in the clinic's documentation and procedures.

Help for Heroes has launched a fundraising drive and provided an emergency grant to keep 96-year-old World War II veteran Robert Clark in his own home after Brent Council refused to continue funding his live-in care, instead wanting to move him to a cheaper care home. Clark, who suffered severe anxiety as a prisoner of war and survived Hitler's death march, has spent his £50,000 life savings on care costs and fears that being forced into residential care would remind him of being a prisoner of war. The charity is seeking public donations to secure his future home care, as Clark's family says moving to a care home would cause him to "give up on life."

FC Chernomorets Odessa, a Ukrainian Premier League club facing severe financial plight, is offering their players luxury houses worth around £67,000 near the sea to cover unpaid salary debts. The club's dire financial situation has forced them to sell their best players and slash remaining players' salaries from over £7,000 to £2,000 per month. If they fail to settle their outstanding debts, the club could face relegation and disqualification from UEFA competitions.

Lithuanian gangster Kestutis Martuzevicius, who is wanted for 22 crimes including two murders in his home country, repeatedly stalled extradition efforts for nearly five years by claiming depression and arguing that deportation would breach his human rights. The 52-year-old's legal battle cost British taxpayers hundreds of thousands of pounds before the European Court of Human Rights finally rejected his "manifestly ill-founded" case and ruled he should be sent back to Lithuania to face charges including murder, robbery, and extortion from his time with the Daktarai gang.

Police are searching for a gang of vigilante paedophile hunters accused of posing as children online to lure men into meetings, then beating them up and filming the attacks. One teenager told Greater Manchester Police he was beaten and attacked by the gang after being tricked into meeting what he thought was a 14-year-old girl in a church car park, while a second victim, Andrew O'Neill, 25, was assaulted in Wigan town center and lost two front teeth before both men were subsequently charged with grooming offenses after reporting the assaults to police.

After Real Madrid's 0-0 Champions League draw with rivals Atletico on Tuesday, the squad's starters took a break while fringe players returned to training on Wednesday at the Valdebebas complex. Real Madrid will return to La Liga action on Saturday against Malaga before facing Atletico again in the second leg, while defender Dani Carvajal was forced to deny accusations that he attempted to bite Atletico striker Mario Mandzukic during Tuesday's heated derby.

David Hibbitt, 33, was diagnosed with stage-three bowel cancer in 2012 and told he had just 18 months to five years to live after the advanced cancer spread to his lymph nodes. The bowel cancer patient claims he has been cured after using cannabis oil as a last resort, with his latest scan in January showing he is cancer-free. However, Cancer Research UK emphasizes there is no good clinical evidence that cannabis extracts can safely and effectively treat cancer in patients, despite some patients choosing to treat themselves with these substances.

President Barack Obama visited Everglades National Park on Earth Day to highlight how climate change is threatening America's national treasures, using the shrinking Florida Everglades as proof that climate change poses a real and immediate threat to both natural landmarks and local economies that depend on tourism. Despite criticism that his gas-guzzling trip to Florida would undermine his Earth Day message, the White House reaffirmed Obama's efforts to reduce pollutants and lead global efforts to combat climate change. Obama emphasized that climate change "can no longer be denied" and called for immediate action to preserve these natural treasures for future generations.

Real Madrid failed to activate their first option to buy 26-year-old Manchester United striker Javier Hernandez outright, as the midnight deadline passed without Madrid making a formal offer. Despite Hernandez's impressive recent form, scoring three times in his last two games including a decisive strike against Atletico Madrid, Real Madrid allowed their exclusive purchasing window to expire. This opens the door for other clubs like West Ham, Southampton, and Newcastle to bid for the Mexican striker, who is valued at around £10million.

Bonnie Doll, a Brisbane-based gamer originally from Sweden, has become Australia's answer to Lara Croft by turning her skill at playing Call of Duty into a lucrative career through live streaming on Twitch.
