After starting to live stream Call of Duty, she was able to quit her job working in hospitality as followers of her live stream pay subscriptions and donations, allowing her to earn a comfortable living from home. Bonnie's Twitch channel has garnered almost one million views and over 52,000 followers, with her mostly using Xbox 1 and Xbox 360 consoles during her streaming sessions from 8am to 2pm, Monday to Friday.

YouTube is set to offer an ad-free, subscription-based service for the first time, as revealed in an email sent to YouTube Partners outlining updated Partner Program Terms that will pay creators 55% of subscription revenue. The Google-owned video giant has also announced YouTube Music Key beta, a paid music service that allows users to watch videos offline and without ads for a monthly fee. This represents YouTube's expansion beyond its previous limited paid subscription channels into a broader ad-free viewing experience.

Marion 'Suge' Knight was rushed to the hospital for an unspecified medical emergency on Thursday after a judge ruled he will stand trial on murder and attempted-murder charges for striking two men with his pickup truck in January. The incident killed Terry Carter and seriously injured Cle 'Bone' Sloan, who testified that he had attacked Knight but refused to cooperate as a witness, saying he would not be used to send Knight to prison. Security footage showed Knight struggling with Sloan through his truck window before striking Sloan with his vehicle and running over Carter while fleeing the scene.

Bailey Murrill, a young patient from Denton, Texas, had been inexplicably paralyzed from the waist down for 11 days while being cared for in the hospital. When her favorite nurse came on shift, Bailey surprised the shocked healthcare worker by suddenly getting up from her wheelchair and walking toward her for the first time since losing movement in her legs. The emotional moment, captured on video by Bailey's mother, shows the nurse screaming with joy and bursting into tears as she hugged her patient, though the cause of Bailey's unexpected paralysis remains unknown.

WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has agreed to be interviewed by Swedish prosecutors at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London, where he has been staying since Ecuador granted him political asylum in 2012. Assange's lawyer confirmed that Swedish authorities will need permission from British and Ecuadorian officials to conduct the interview regarding 2010 sexual assault allegations, as some of the alleged crimes face a statute of limitations in August 2015. Assange fears that Sweden would extradite him to the United States, where he could potentially face the death penalty for publishing government secrets through WikiLeaks.

Big Brother star Pete Bennett, who won the show in 2006, appeared on Jeremy Kyle to reveal he is now homeless and broke despite winning £100,000 prize money nine years ago. Pete's drug addiction to ketamine, which developed after his reality TV fame, led to the loss of his money and has severely impacted his personal life and career prospects. After losing seven friends to drug-related deaths and going through a failed marriage, Pete finally decided to seek help and is now clean, attempting to rebuild his life through acting while his Tourette's syndrome has also improved significantly.

Borussia Dortmund bounced back from their two previous Bundesliga defeats with a convincing 3-0 victory over relegation-threatened Paderborn, just three days after manager Jurgen Klopp announced he will quit the club at the end of the season. Henrikh Mkhitaryan headed the home side in front three minutes after half-time when Paderborn goalkeeper Lukas Kruse failed to keep out his near-post header, before Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang and Shinji Kagawa added further goals to complete the comfortable win. Despite the shocking news about their departing manager, with Borussia Dortmund fans holding up signs thanking Klopp for his achievements, the players showed no signs of being affected as they moved up to eighth in the table.

North Korean defector Lee Min-bok is sending thousands of copies of "The Interview" movie via balloons from South Korea into North Korean territory, despite calling the Hollywood comedy "vulgar," because he believes it shows Kim Jong Un as human rather than the godlike figure portrayed by Pyongyang's tightly controlled state media. The balloon launches occur under cover of darkness to avoid confrontation with both North Korean forces and South Korea's local residents, who have tried to stop the launches since Pyongyang fired on similar propaganda balloons last October, putting border communities in danger. Pyongyang acts with fury against these balloon campaigns, suggesting the information may be reaching ordinary North Koreans despite the regime's efforts to control what its people see.

Israeli developers have created the Optimal thermal protection case that prevents phones from overheating during intense usage and protects them in extreme cold weather by using micro-fans to cool the device when it gets too hot and resistance coils to heat the phone when temperatures drop too low. The case monitors phone temperature via Bluetooth and automatically activates cooling or heating modes as needed, since exposure to hotter temperatures causes batteries to lose their ability to store energy faster. Optimal cases will be available for pre-order for major phone brands including Apple, Samsung, Nexus, HTC, and Xperia, though prices have not yet been announced.

At least 54 people have died and 15 others are missing after a Russian commercial fishing vessel sank off the Kamchatka Peninsula, with more than 60 people rescued from the waters. The Dalniy Vostok freezer trawler was carrying 132 people when it went down within 15 minutes in the Sea of Okhotsk, with the 54 deceased including foreign nationals from Myanmar, Ukraine, Lithuania and Vanuatu. More than 20 fishing vessels are currently searching for the 15 people still thought to be missing from the shipwreck.

This article reviews ten essential food apps that make meal planning easier, including Where Chefs Eat which features over 3,000 chef recommendations from top culinary professionals, and Love Food Hate Waste, a free meal planning app that tracks your fridge contents and prevents duplicate purchases. Other notable apps include British Street Food, which uses GPS to locate the best street food vendors in Britain, and various other free and paid apps covering everything from restaurant reservations to wine selection and recipe planning.

While Jeremy Clarkson continues to battle to save his career after being sacked from Top Gear for an incident where he left producer Oisin Tymon needing hospital treatment, his estranged wife Frances Clarkson, 53, has been enjoying a family holiday in Barbados. Frances, who married Jeremy in 1993 but has been living apart from him for years, was spotted relaxing on the beach in a white bikini accessorized with a Help For Heroes wristband. Clarkson has been accused of having affairs, including with events organizer Phillipa Sage, and has faced multiple controversies throughout his career.

Discount supermarket Aldi is facing criticism for failing to properly notify customers of a 0.5 percent surcharge on credit card transactions and tap-and-go payments, six months after promising ASIC (Australian Securities and Investments Commission) it would disclose these fees. ASIC took action against Aldi last year when investigations revealed the company was not adequately informing customers about the surcharge that applies to all credit card transactions and contactless payments in its stores. Despite Aldi's commitment to install proper signage and have cashiers inform customers, many stores still lack adequate disclosure, with some having no entrance signs and others displaying warnings in tiny print at registers.

In 1942, Russian bullion worth millions of pounds was loaded onto HMS Ulster Queen, a former Irish Sea ferry converted to a battle cruiser, to be transferred to the U.S. as payment for weapons during WWII. After arriving in Greenock following a dangerous Arctic convoy where two ships were sunk by German U-boats, disaster struck during the unloading process when one case of precious metals slipped and fell overboard into the river Clyde. This wartime blunder has only recently come to light through the secret diary of engineer Leonard H. Thomas, and it remains unknown whether the lost bullion was ever recovered.

Luis Suarez's wife Sofia revealed that the Uruguay striker initially denied biting Italy defender Giorgio Chiellini during their World Cup match in Brazil, telling her he hadn't done anything wrong. Suarez was handed a four-month ban for the biting incident, but only admitted the truth to his wife 10 days later after initially maintaining his innocence despite clear television evidence of him biting down on Chiellini's shoulder.

Ranulfo Perez, 48, who dresses as the Cookie Monster in New York's Times Square, was arrested by police for allegedly groping the breasts of a 16-year-old teenager outside a Toys R Us store. However, Perez was later released by the Manhattan District Attorney because the teenager lost sight of her attacker and could not be certain it was him. This incident adds to growing concerns about costumed characters in Times Square causing disturbances and engaging in inappropriate behavior with the public.

Marc Wabafiyebazu, 15, was arrested for felony murder after his brother Jean, 17, was shot dead during a gunfight that erupted Monday when the two sons of Canadian Consul General Roxanne Dubé attempted to rob Miami drug dealers. The incident occurred when the brothers went to purchase marijuana but allegedly planned to rob the dealers instead, resulting in Jean's death and the arrest of both Marc and Anthony Rodriguez, who was wounded in the shootout.

Dr Omar Saadi Al-Atraqchi, a 42-year-old family doctor working at Custom House Surgery and other practices in North London, admitted secretly filming men in gym showers by cutting holes in Lynx shampoo bottles to conceal his iPhone inside. Al-Atraqchi pleaded guilty to four counts of voyeurism and was fined £500, but now faces being struck off the medical register after a tribunal found him guilty of misconduct. The doctor could lose his ability to practice medicine entirely due to his voyeuristic behavior, which involved sliding the modified shower gel bottles under cubicle partitions to secretly record unsuspecting men.

John T. Booker Jr., a former U.S. Army enlistee from Kansas, was arrested Friday for attempting to detonate a car bomb at Fort Riley military base, believing ISIS wanted him to carry out the suicide bombing attack. The bomb plot was thwarted by FBI confidential informants who provided inert materials for the device, ensuring Fort Riley's security was never breached and no one was in danger. A second man, Alexander Blair, faces charges for failing to report the felony after knowing about Booker's bomb plot and even lending him money for storage space.

Swedish scientists who analyzed more than 10,000 families found that children who experience stressful events such as death or illness in the family, divorce, or separation could be three times more likely to develop type 1 diabetes. The study followed children aged two to 14, and of the 58 children who were subsequently diagnosed with type 1 diabetes, many had experienced significant stressful events during their formative years. While the exact causes of type 1 diabetes remain unknown, researchers suggest that damaging childhood events could affect insulin-producing beta cells and increase insulin demands due to elevated stress hormone levels.

Fifteen-year-old Jamar Nicholson is suing Los Angeles for $20 million after being shot in the back by LAPD officer Miguel Gutierrez when police mistook his friend's toy gun for a real weapon. The incident occurred in February when officers from the LAPD's criminal gang-homicide unit approached the teenagers in a South LA alleyway, with Nicholson's attorney arguing that "the LAPD shot first and then asked questions later." Despite the toy gun having an orange tip indicating it was fake, the police fired on the group, leaving Nicholson injured and traumatized by the encounter.

At Domodedovo Airport in Russia, passengers waiting to collect their luggage from the baggage reclaim were shocked to discover a man asleep on the conveyor belt, with the passenger circled around as other travelers appeared more amused than concerned while claiming their bags. This isn't an isolated incident, as similar cases have occurred including an inebriated Chinese passenger who wandered into a train station and fell asleep on the luggage belt, and another man at Rome's Fiumicino Airport who decided to relax and snooze on the conveyor after climbing over a check-in desk.

For the first time in its 100-year history, Cadbury's is set to release a special edition Dairy Milk Spectacular 7 bar - a super bar containing seven different fillings in seven rows, including Dairy Milk Caramel, Fruit & Nut, Dairy Milk Whole Nut, Oreo, Daim, and Turkish varieties. However, only 50 of these bars have been created for a competition rather than general sale, as Cadbury worked with food artist Prudence Staite to encourage chocolate lovers to try new flavors beyond classic Dairy Milk.

Muhammadu Buhari, a 72-year-old former general who was Nigeria's harsh military leader 30 years ago, won the Nigerian presidential election in a historic peaceful transition of power, running on an anti-corruption platform that resonated with ordinary Nigerians exhausted by years of misrule and the failure to provide security against Boko Haram terrorism. The outgoing government's inability to effectively combat Boko Haram - whose major targets are actually Islamic population centers rather than Christians - and widespread corruption that has impoverished Nigeria's poor despite the country's oil wealth, led voters to support Buhari's promise to tackle both terrorism and corruption. Buhari's victory represents hope for reform in a country where the author observed during a visit that the government could provide security in some areas but utterly failed in others, while the Boko Haram terrorist emergency continuing in Muslim areas may have actually benefited the previous administration politically.

Disgraced comedian Daniel O'Reilly has resurrected his controversial "Dapper Laughs" persona and traveled to Australia, filming his journey to Sydney via Melbourne while chatting up air hostesses and mocking airport cleaners along the way. This comes after O'Reilly had previously declared "Dapper Laughs is gone" on BBC Newsnight following widespread criticism, including an open letter condemning O'Reilly signed by 44 comedians for his sexist comedy, and the cancellation of his ITV show after over 60,000 people petitioned for it to be axed. Daily Mail Australia has contacted Daniel O'Reilly for comment regarding his latest controversial antics in Sydney.

Nine British Muslims, including Waheed Ahmed, the 21-year-old son of Labour councillor Shakil Ahmed, were caught trying to cross into Syria and arrested in Turkey. Labour's Simon Danczuk said the family should not be welcome back in England, arguing it was unacceptable for people prepared to join ISIS to return to civilian life without facing terror charges. The family, consisting of Councillor Shakil Ahmed's son Waheed, his cousins, aunt and four children, are expected to return to the UK from Turkey this week.

Avril Lavigne has revealed she has Lyme disease, a debilitating bacterial infection contracted through a tick bite that left her bedridden for five months with symptoms so severe she thought she was dying. The 30-year-old singer told People Magazine "I had no idea a bug bite could do this," describing symptoms that range from extreme fatigue and weakness to inability to stand or shower. The disease, which infects around 65,000 people in Europe and 25,000 Americans annually, was only diagnosed after months of emergency room visits, and Lavigne now wants to raise awareness about the condition that can cause symptoms ranging from headaches to paralysis if not treated early.

An Egyptian court has sentenced 71 people to life in prison for their role in the August 2013 burning of the Virgin Mary Church, a Christian church in Giza province that was torched and looted by a mob who chanted against Coptic Christians. The attack on the church was part of a broader wave of violence that targeted at least 42 churches across Egypt that August. Separately, former Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy was sentenced to 20 years in prison on charges related to violence, though he was acquitted of murder in the deaths of protesters.

Australian police arrested five young men Saturday in Melbourne as part of a major counterterrorism operation targeting an ISIS-inspired terror plot planned for Anzac Day ceremonies. Two suspects have been charged with conspiring to commit terrorist acts, with the planned attack specifically targeting police officers during the national commemoration. Prime Minister Tony Abbott referred to ISIS as the "Daesh death cult," using a handle the terrorist group is known to despise.

Aston Villa player Carles N'Zogbia drew attention for his flamboyant flowery outfit when he arrived for training on Tuesday, prompting teammate Shay Given to ridicule his attire on Twitter as "the worst ever." The fashion incident comes as manager Tim Sherwood, who became famous for his penchant for wearing a gilet during his time at Tottenham, has put fashion choices in the spotlight at the club. Despite the wardrobe controversy, N'Zogbia has featured regularly under Sherwood since the manager's appointment in February.

British photographer Laura Stevens created the photo series "Another November" after her own painful break-up, directing friends and women she met to pose and portray the emotional stages of losing love and grief following the breakdown of relationships. The series refers to the month she separated from her partner and captures intimate moments of adjustment, showing how a break-up may involve moving out of shared homes and the various stages of heartbreak. Laura wanted to create a therapeutic project that helped her process her own emotions while documenting the universal experience of lost love through staged performances by different women in Paris.

Andy Murray looked understandably nervous as he arrived at Dunblane Cathedral on Friday for his wedding rehearsal, ahead of marrying his long-term girlfriend Kim Sears in his hometown on Saturday. The former Wimbledon champion visited the cathedral to run through the wedding service with friends, family, and his fiancée, with both Murray and Sears appearing somewhat overwhelmed by the occasion. The couple, who have been together for 10 years, will be wed at Dunblane Cathedral with local businesses joining in the celebrations of their returning hero.

Hummelstown police Officer Lisa Mearkle, a female Pennsylvania police officer, has been charged with criminal homicide for fatally shooting unarmed motorist David Kassick in the back on February 2. The shooting, which involved Mearkle firing two bullets into Kassick's back as he lay face down on the ground, was captured on video by her stun gun camera. Mearkle's lawyers are now trying to prevent the video from being released or shown in court, while prosecutors consider it their strongest evidence in the case.

Mick Schumacher, the 16-year-old son of seven-time F1 world champion Michael Schumacher, made his pre-season test debut in German Formula 4 with Van Amersfoort Racing just weeks after being involved in a 100mph crash. During the test session at the Oschersleben circuit, he was pictured accidentally turning into gravel and going off the track. The teenager is following in his father's footsteps as he progresses through junior racing categories, with Formula 4 serving as a stepping stone for drivers hoping to reach the top levels of motorsport.

Following his Diane Sawyer 20/20 interview, TV viewers will be able to follow Bruce Jenner's journey as he transitions into a woman in his forthcoming eight-episode docu-series on E! starting July 27. However, his sons Burt, Brandon and Brody Jenner, along with stepdaughter Kim Kardashian, are reportedly concerned that the upcoming reality show might "de-class" what he accomplished with the well-received ABC interview, urging him to slow down on revealing too much publicly. While Bruce's six biological children and four stepchildren are proud of him and supportive of his transition, they worry about the potential negative impact of continuing to share his personal journey on reality TV.

The RSPCA is considering abandoning its controversial policy of pursuing fox hunting prosecutions after the collapse of its latest case against William Bryer of the Cattistock Hunt, leaving the animal charity with no remaining legal actions under the Hunting Act. Following criticism for spending £22.5 million on prosecutions last year, the RSPCA is reviewing whether to continue bringing hunting offences cases to court, particularly as fox hunting groups now legally operate using trail hunting methods where they drag artificial scents rather than chase live animals. Critics argue the charity should return to its core mission of animal rescue and rehabilitation rather than pursuing what they call "pointless prosecutions" through the courts.

Darren Stanton, a former police officer who has become the UK's top human lie detector and body expert, appeared on ITV's This Morning to demonstrate his skills in detecting deception. Contrary to the popular belief that liars can't look you in the eye, Stanton explains that liars often stare and can be identified through micro-expressions and body language signals. He successfully caught both presenters Amanda Holden and Philip Schofield fibbing during the show, detecting Holden's lie through a slight mouth flick and Schofield's through a raised eyebrow.

The article explains the significance of Holy Week and Easter weekend, focusing on the Easter Triduum - the three-day period from Good Friday (when Jesus was crucified) through Holy Saturday to Easter Sunday (celebrating the resurrection). The author notes that many people, even Christians, don't fully understand this progression that begins with Maundy Thursday when Jesus celebrated the Last Supper, continues through Good Friday's crucifixion, and culminates in Easter Sunday where resurrection implies total transformation beyond the physical realm. Easter embraces the mystery of spiritual renewal and represents a universal pattern of moving through suffering and darkness into hope and light that all humans experience repeatedly in their lives.

Facebook has opened up its Messenger Platform to allow developers to create apps that integrate seamlessly with the messaging service, with the Camoji app being one of the first to take advantage by enabling users to create and share animated GIFs with filters and text directly through Facebook Messenger. This move represents Facebook's strategy to transform its Messenger service into an independent platform that can compete with fast-growing messaging apps like Snapchat and WeChat, while also allowing consumers to use text messages for services like restaurant reservations and shopping notifications. The integration allows for a more seamless user experience compared to other messaging platforms, as recipients can easily launch Camoji from within Messenger conversations to reply with their own GIFs.

Labour leader Ed Miliband admitted his party made mistakes on immigration and announced that everyone coming to Britain should learn English, while pledging a new crackdown on illegal exploitation of migrant workers through a 100-staff Home Office task force. Miliband said exploitation drives low-skilled migration and holds down wages for British workers, but Conservative immigration minister James Brokenshire criticized that nothing in Miliband's plans would actually help control immigration numbers. The Conservatives argued that Miliband's proposals would risk undermining existing immigration controls, particularly with a potential Labour-SNP coalition.

Police pulled over Wendell Steiner, his wife, and their four children in Akron, Ohio during a 300-mile journey after concerned drivers called 911 about four terrified puppies strapped in a cage on the van's roof. The puppies belong to Steiner's father and were being transported to Pennsylvania, with the cage's rear left exposed to the wind. The incident drew comparisons to Mitt Romney's controversial 2012 campaign story about transporting his dog on his car roof, though the Mennonite family claimed they didn't know transporting animals this way was wrong since they view puppies as livestock rather than pets.

Louis Smith will represent Great Britain for the first time since his double Olympic medal-winning performance at London 2012, where he won pommel horse silver and team bronze, after being selected for the European Championships squad. The British gymnast earned his spot by winning gold on the pommel horse at the recent British Championships, marking his return to international competition for GB since the London Games. Four-time Commonwealth Games champion Claudia Fragapane leads the women's team for the European Championships taking place in Montpellier from April 15-19.

New York taxi driver Mohammed Dahbi was ordered to pay $10,000 in damages after he discriminated against actress Kassie Thornton and her TV executive partner Christy Spitzer by telling them to stop kissing in his cab and "keep that behavior for the bedroom." Dahbi was accused of discrimination and also verbally abused the lesbian couple with slurs when they refused to pay the fare, leading to the financial penalty and mandatory anti-discrimination training.

Newcastle midfielder Jonas Gutierrez, who has twice beaten testicular cancer, was dropped from the squad following a fallout with head coach John Carver and is now set to be released at the end of the season. Carver said Gutierrez was left out for "selection reasons" after a heated training-ground disagreement, and the clause that would have guaranteed Gutierrez a contract extension after eight starts this season cannot now be activated. Gutierrez spoke critically of Newcastle's treatment of him during his cancer battle, saying he won't be able to forgive how the club handled his illness when they told him to find another club upon his return in 2013.

ISIS militants entered the Yarmouk Palestinian refugee camp in Damascus, marking their deepest infiltration into the Syrian capital, while Jordan closed its only functioning border crossing with Syria following heavy clashes between rebels and government forces. The jihadis took control of large parts of the Yarmouk camp following clashes with Palestinian groups, potentially giving ISIS a base to threaten Damascus and challenge President Assad. Separately, gruesome images emerged showing ISIS militants stoning a man and woman to death in Mosul, Iraq, after accusing them of having sex before marriage.

South Carolina mother-of-four Amanda Peake Glover died Saturday after collapsing moments after completing the Palmetto Half Marathon. The devoted fitness enthusiast and co-owner of a fitness center had just finished the race when she suddenly collapsed and was pronounced dead at a nearby hospital. She is survived by her husband Benjamin and four children, leaving behind a shocked community who remembered her as a dedicated mother, youth ministry teacher, and choir singer.

Labour's shadow chancellor Ed Balls was left briefly stumped by a basic maths question after giving a speech in Leeds today, taking a ten-second pause before correctly answering that seven times six equals 42. The incident occurred during a Q&A session, coming after Balls had previously confessed in a TV interview that he relies on his mother-in-law, a maths teacher, for help with mathematics and was relieved not to be asked maths questions live on television.

Alastair Cook and Jonathan Trott became the sixth English pair to achieve 10 century partnerships together, with Cook being part of three such successful partnerships including previous collaborations with Strauss and Pietersen. During the match, Cook was involved in an incident where his pull shot hit fielder Jermaine Blackwood, while Trott faced challenging fast bowling from Shannon Gabriel who reached speeds of 94.3mph. The achievement marks a significant milestone for England's batting partnerships in Test cricket.

Manhattan-based Skin Laundry offers a popular laser facial treatment that promises to tighten skin and reduce scarring in just ten minutes, but clients must sign an extensive waiver that includes releasing personal information to funeral directors and coroners due to potential risks like burns, scarring, and even death. Despite the ominous legal language and risks, the treatment has proven so popular that the clinic has extended hours and expanded to six locations, with many clients becoming regular customers who claim the treatment works effectively for improving their skin.

Tickets for Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao's eagerly-anticipated weigh-in on May 1 in Las Vegas sold out within minutes on Friday evening, with all 10,000 tickets available from MGM property box offices being snapped up as fight fans queued around the block. The MGM Resorts Box Office was overwhelmed with calls and phone lines crashed due to the massive demand for #MayweatherPacquiao weigh-tickets. Friday's sale came after tickets for the main mega-fight had already sold out within a minute on Thursday night, with some tickets immediately appearing on secondary markets for exorbitant prices.

Victoria's Secret Angel Alessandra Ambrosio is recovering at UCLA Hospital's Ronald Reagan Medical Center in Los Angeles after undergoing a medical procedure for constant headaches that she had been experiencing. The 34-year-old Brazilian supermodel was seen partying at the Coachella festival in California on Sunday, appearing healthy, but had scheduled the medical appointment two weeks prior due to her ongoing headache issues. A spokesperson confirmed that Ambrosio went to the doctor for a scheduled visit and is currently in good health, though they could not provide further details about her specific condition.

The Oxford University Women's Boat Race team were rescued from the Thames by the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) on Wednesday after their boat was swamped by choppy waters during training for the upcoming Boat Race. The rowers were training for the prestigious race, which takes place alongside the men's race on Saturday, April 11, when strong winds against the tide created waves that overwhelmed their boat's bilge pump. The RNLI Alternative Boat Race fundraising event is scheduled for April 10, the day before the main BNY Mellon Boat Race on the same stretch of the Thames.

Paris Saint-Germain playmaker Lucas Moura has lauded Lionel Messi ahead of his side's Champions League encounter against Barcelona, revealing he is "obsessed" with the way his fellow South American plays football. Despite the traditional rivalry between Brazilians and Argentines, the PSG star has singled out Messi for special praise, calling him "the best player in the world" before Wednesday night's clash at Parc des Princes.

Zayn Malik has been accused of cheating on his fiancée Perrie Edwards multiple times, with the most recent allegation coming from Swedish model Martina Olsson who claimed she slept with him in Thailand. This isn't the first time Zayn has faced cheating allegations, as he has been accused on four separate occasions since 2012, leading relationship expert Tracey Cox to warn that his young age and level of fame make such behavior concerning. Despite the ongoing accusations, Perrie and Zayn were recently pictured boarding a private jet for what's being described as a "make or break" holiday, with their relationship being compared to Cheryl and Ashley Cole's troubled marriage that ended due to infidelity.

The governors of Arkansas and Indiana were caught off-guard by the massive public and business backlash against their "religious freedom" bills, as companies prioritized their bottom line and support for social equality over potential discrimination against same-sex couples. With 72% of millennials nationwide supporting same-sex marriage and 90% of young people (ages 14-24) believing in creating less biased communities according to MTV's anti-bias campaign, businesses now face significant financial risks when they ignore or reject anti-gay bias concerns. America has crossed a threshold where discrimination wherever it occurs is no longer a viable business model or political strategy, as the country becomes increasingly diverse and millennials drive consumer spending with their strong support for equality.

TOWIE star and footballer Jake Hall scored a vital goal for non-league side Boston United on Monday during their 2-0 victory over Tamworth, impressing his on-screen girlfriend Chloe Lewis who was watching from the stands. Hall scored Boston's second goal with his first touch after coming off the bench, prompting his TOWIE co-star James 'Arg' Argent to excitedly try to climb over the barriers to celebrate. The goal helped keep Boston United on course for the Conference North play-offs, with Hall pointing to Lewis in the stands after scoring.

Active U.S. military personnel are on the ground in Iraq training Iraqi soldiers in the fight against ISIS, with Lt. Colonel John Schwemmer on his sixth tour leading these military training efforts. The U.S. military training is being supplemented by foreign volunteers and outside agencies working with Kurdish forces and militia in both Iraq and Syria, including a 28-year-old former U.S. army soldier who joined Syrian Kurdish forces. While over 100 American citizens are reportedly fighting with Kurdish militias opposing ISIS, U.S. law enforcement considers joining Syrian militias illegal, and some Kurdish forces prefer training assistance over foreign fighters on the front lines.

During the liberation of Bergen-Belsen Nazi concentration camp 70 years ago, a remarkable love story unfolded between British soldier Sergeant Norman Turgel, 24, and emaciated Polish prisoner Gena Turgel, 20, who was among the starving inmates where prisoners were dying at a rate of 500 per day from typhus and starvation. Despite the horrific conditions of the Holocaust camp where Anne Frank had recently died, Norman spotted beauty in Gena through her prison uniform and fell in love, with their romance facilitated by the kindness of British commander Major Leonard Berney who ensured they could stay in contact. The couple eventually married and had a 50-year marriage with three children, proving that love could triumph even amid the darkest chapter of human history.

A CNN reporter traveled to Gorkha, a town near the epicenter of Nepal's devastating earthquake, where the district hospital is overflowing with patients who sustained injuries including spinal injuries, broken bones, and deep cuts from the disaster. While the town itself shows relatively minor damage with some cracks in buildings, the hospital serves as a transit point for traumatized victims from remote mountain villages, with international medical teams working alongside local staff to treat the injured under challenging conditions. The situation highlights the massive humanitarian crisis facing Nepal, with many remote areas still inaccessible and in desperate need of aid.

Two Australian drug smugglers, Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran, are facing execution by firing squad in Indonesia for their roles as leaders in a failed heroin smuggling plot involving the "Bali Nine" group. The other seven members, including Scott Rush (who was captured at 19) and Renae Lawrence (the only woman, whose original life sentence was reduced to 20 years), received lengthy prison sentences, with some claiming Chan threatened their lives to force participation in the scheme. Indonesia's tough stance on drug smugglers under President Joko Widodo has cast doubt on clemency appeals, despite Australia's continued diplomatic efforts to prevent the executions.

Oxford scientists propose that Earth's formation involved a collision with a Mars-sized body similar to Mercury about 4.5 billion years ago, which would explain why Earth's core generates heat for its magnetic field and why the planet's crust and mantle contain higher ratios of rare-earth elements like samarium and neodymium than typical meteorites. This Mercury-like object, rich in sulfur but poor in oxygen, could have provided the radioactive materials needed to drive Earth's molten iron core, and researchers suggest this same Mars-sized body may also be responsible for the moon's formation. The theory builds on current models of planetary formation where smaller bodies coalesced to form larger planets like Earth, but addresses previously unexplained aspects of our planet's composition and internal structure.

Red Bull has struggled since their Formula One dominance ended in 2013, falling behind Mercedes last season and slipping even further this season. Ahead of this weekend's Chinese Grand Prix, Daniel Ricciardo practices martial arts with a trainer at Guyi Garden in what appears to be a PR event to help kick-start his disappointing 2015 season. While the martial arts training won't provide the speed needed to challenge Mercedes at the front of the grid, Ricciardo looks like he's trying to find any edge possible after a slow start to the season.

An unidentified drone carrying small traces of radioactive material landed on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's official residence in Tokyo, prompting police and bomb squad response. The drone, found to contain traces of a radioactive substance believed to be caesium, is suspected to be part of a protest against Japan's nuclear energy policies. Police officers secured the area and launched an investigation into the incident, while Prime Minister Abe was away attending a conference in Indonesia at the time.

An internal ISIS report detailing its organizational structure reveals that while ISIS presents itself as a global religious organization, it has actually thrived because of a local cause - Sunni rebellion in Iraq and Syria - and is largely led by former secular Baathist officers from Saddam Hussein's army who use radical Islam as a tool for power and control. Reports suggest that people living under ISIS rule are growing disenchanted with the brutal theocratic dictatorship, as no one has ever voted ISIS into power anywhere, and ISIS might find its greatest threat comes from within its own territory rather than external enemies. Despite the significant threat ISIS poses through its sophisticated messaging and recruitment machine that attracts alienated young Muslims worldwide, the group's main focus appears to be building a caliphate in the Middle East rather than directly attacking the West.

Following a political leaders' debate, internet users created numerous memes featuring the participants, with Labour leader Ed Miliband superimposed over London rapper Plan B issuing a call to "come at me bruv" in reference to his challenge for Prime Minister David Cameron to debate him one-on-one. Since David Cameron and his deputy Nick Clegg did not participate in the debate, they were humorously superimposed over characters from the TV show Gogglebox, sitting on the sofa as if watching from home. The memes also featured other creative references, including Miliband in Titanic poses and the debate participants as Power Rangers characters.

A handful of Manchester City fans were ejected from Old Trafford during Manchester United's 4-2 derby victory for allegedly mocking the 1958 Munich Air Disaster, where Manchester United's plane crashed killing 23 people including former Manchester City goalkeeper Frank Swift. Despite the ejections and eight arrests for minor offenses, police praised the overwhelming majority of the 75,000+ fans for their good behavior during the match.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has admitted his academy players are not ready for first-team football, suggesting City may need to buy homegrown talent from rival clubs to meet Premier League quota requirements. With James Milner potentially leaving City for Liverpool and Raheem Sterling reportedly unwilling to sign a new contract at Anfield, Pellegrini's assertions indicate City may target English players like Sterling to fill their homegrown player quota. The timing is significant as Sterling has spoken about his contract situation at Liverpool, making him a potential target for City's transfer strategy.

A 28-year-old pregnant Jehovah's Witness woman named Jenny-Lee, who was diagnosed with leukaemia seven months into her pregnancy, died along with her unborn baby after she refused a blood transfusion required for a caesarean section and chemotherapy treatment. Although doctors told her she could give birth via caesarean and undergo treatment, she refused both options on religious grounds, believing the treatment would harm her unborn child. Her family defended her decision, saying she put her baby's life above her own, though the baby ultimately died in utero and Jenny-Lee died 13 days after diagnosis from stroke and multi-organ failure.

Mohammad Liaqat launched a racist tirade and racially abused teachers at Mount Carmel Catholic School after Muslim pupils were banned from growing beards, even assaulting the headmaster during his rampage in front of shocked parents. After being arrested, Liaqat continued his rant at another nearby school where he also assaulted that headteacher when asked to leave. The 34-year-old was found guilty of assault and racially aggravated behavior, despite the original beard issue having already been resolved by the school.

Chinese police arrested more than 133,000 people and seized 43.3 tons of illegal narcotics during a six-month anti-drug campaign, while authorities also handled 115,000 drug-related crimes and 606,000 cases of drug use. Despite Liu Yuejin saying drug trafficking groups have "suffered a heavy blow," he noted that online drug trafficking remains an increasing problem, prompting the ministry to launch a three-month online campaign starting in April targeting drug-related Internet crimes. The crackdown has extended to the entertainment industry, with Beijing authorities banning drug use and numerous celebrities being arrested, including Jackie Chan's son Jaycee Chan who was sentenced to six months in prison.

A new species of glass frog named Hyalinobatrachium dianae has been discovered in the mountains of eastern Costa Rica, featuring distinctive translucent skin on its underside that makes its heart, liver, and other internal organs clearly visible. The creature is distinguished from other glass frogs and tree frogs by its unique metallic whistle-like call, black and white eyes, and forward-facing eye orientation. This small amphibian, measuring just one inch long, adds to the 149 known species of glass frogs in Central and South America.

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have returned to Kensington Palace to prepare for the birth of their second child, due on Saturday, after spending the weekend at Kate's family home in Berkshire with Prince George. Kensington Palace revealed that Prince William has completed his air ambulance pilot training earlier than expected, allowing him to take six weeks of paternity leave (two weeks paid, the rest unpaid) to be with his wife during and after the birth. Prince Harry will also return from his deployment in Australia to attend the London Marathon and potentially meet his new niece or nephew before the child becomes fourth in line to the throne.

Maurice Thibaux, a 67-year-old French resident living next to the Carriageworks venue in Sydney's inner city, stormed onto the catwalk during Sunday night's opening show of Sydney's Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week while designer Kym Ellery was taking her bow. Despite using noise-cancelling headphones, Thibaux was disturbed by the rumbling bass from the music, which he compared to a jumbo jet taking off, prompting him to crash the stage with his hands over his ears before being escorted away by security. Other neighbors also complained about the noise being disturbing, though the designer appeared unfazed by the incident and continued her runway appearance.

FBI Chief James Comey has introduced compulsory fitness tests for all 135,000 FBI agents following concerns about expanding waistlines and declining physical fitness among the force. The annual tests require agents to meet specific standards for running, sprinting, push-ups, and sit-ups, with failure noted on performance reviews and potential reassignment from physically demanding duties. The initiative comes as much of the FBI's work has shifted to desk-based cyber crime and intelligence gathering since 9/11, contributing to reduced fitness levels amid America's broader obesity crisis.

Volcano Calbuco in southern Chile suddenly erupted without warning after lying dormant for over 40 years, forcing approximately 1,500 people to flee from nearby towns as a massive ash plume filled the sky. The volcano, considered one of Chile's three most dangerous among its 90 active volcanoes, last erupted in 1972, and the unexpected eruption created an exclusion zone and sent ash clouds visible up to 100 miles away. Chile sits on the Pacific "Rim of Fire" where volcanoes occur at the edges of tectonic plates, making it home to the world's second-largest chain of potentially active volcanoes after Indonesia.

David Cameron took on Church of England bishops after they questioned the morality of his austerity and welfare policies, insisting in an Easter message that the Coalition had spent five years "trying to lift people up" by making work pay and encouraging responsibility. The Prime Minister defended his policies as being based on "clear values and beliefs," arguing that just because some disagree with the policies doesn't mean they lack moral content. Meanwhile, UKIP claimed that Christians in Britain face dismissal and argued that 16-17 year olds should not vote in any EU referendum due to concerns about Brussels "propaganda" in schools.

Freddie Gray died from a severe spinal cord injury after being arrested by Baltimore police on April 12, when officers spotted Gray and he began running, leading to his arrest and subsequent death while in police custody. Five of the six officers involved in Gray's arrest have provided statements to investigators, but protesters are demanding answers about what happened during the 30 minutes Gray was transported in a police van. The case has sparked ongoing protests in Baltimore, with demonstrators calling for charges against the officers, while the police union defends the officers and criticizes protesters for demanding charges without knowing all the facts of the ongoing investigation.

Brandon Afoa, a 33-year-old airport worker, was awarded $40 million in compensation for a freak runway accident at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport that left him paralyzed from the waist down over seven years ago. The incident occurred when Afoa was operating a tug to push aircraft and the brakes and steering failed, causing him to crash into a luggage lift. After years of legal battles, a King County jury awarded the compensation, with the Port of Seattle being held 25% responsible for failing to maintain a safe workplace.

Manchester United boss Louis van Gaal revealed he is set to have lunch with Sir Alex Ferguson soon, hoping to discuss genuine progress as the Premier League table looks increasingly favorable for United. Van Gaal says United could leapfrog Manchester City into second place with a victory over Aston Villa on Saturday, as successive wins over Tottenham and Liverpool have put them in strong position for a top-four finish. The current form has given Van Gaal reason for optimism ahead of his meeting with Ferguson, who has been waiting for tangible progress since leaving the club.

A passenger flying from Newcastle Airport to Gatwick on an EasyJet flight was stopped by security after airport staff discovered six tubs of pease pudding in his hand luggage and thought it resembled Semtex plastic explosive. Security staff told the traveler that his pease pudding could technically be classed as Semtex due to its consistency, though he was ultimately allowed to board with a warning to pack such items in hold luggage next time. The incident highlights how airport security scanners regularly pick up unusual items, with other airports like Stansted having confiscated everything from furry handcuffs to large vegetables in similar security mix-ups.

The West Indies have named a 14-man squad for the first Test against England in their three-match series, with uncapped duo Shai Hope and Carlos Brathwaite included after the islanders cut six players from their training camp. The squad features 21-year-old wicketkeeper-batsman Hope and one-day captain Jason Holder, while Denesh Ramdin will continue as Test captain for the series starting Monday in Antigua.

Rejean Hermel Perron has been accused of holding a woman captive for five days and subjecting her to multiple sexual assaults after police say he held her at gunpoint when she tried to leave his Toronto home. A dog walker named Peter Hamilton rescued the kidnapped woman, who emerged from the house bound by handcuffs and naked from the waist down, by using nail clippers to free her restraints. Police claim Rejean Hermel Perron held the 27-year-old sex trade worker against her will and subjected her to repeated sexual assaults, leading to charges including sexual assault with a weapon, kidnapping, and forcible confinement.

Jane Horrocks and her teenagers embarked on a classic American road trip, navigating Route 1 (Pacific Coast Highway) from San Francisco to Los Angeles over three weeks. Starting from San Fran's iconic Golden Gate Bridge, they explored the City's hills via cable cars before driving through California's spectacular coastal scenery, including Big Sur, Santa Barbara, and Hearst Castle. Their journey concluded at the Huntington Beach Hyatt Regency, where they enjoyed three-and-a-half miles of uncrowded white sand known as Surf City.

A major political row has erupted between the Liberal Democrats and Conservatives after Lib Dem minister Danny Alexander released details of what he claims are secret Tory plans to cut Child Benefit and Child Tax Credits. Alexander accused David Cameron of plotting to "slash support for families," revealing previously confidential coalition discussions about welfare cuts, while the Conservatives have angrily denied the specific proposals and dismissed them as "desperate stuff" from the Lib Dems. The controversy centers around Tory Chancellor George Osborne's promise to cut £12 billion from the welfare bill after the election, though he has refused to specify where the cuts will fall, leading to accusations that the Conservatives are trying to hide their true intentions from voters just days before the election.

Sergio Garcia insists he is focused on winning his first PGA Tour title since 2012 at this week's Shell Houston Open, despite the upcoming Masters at Augusta dominating headlines. The Spaniard is concentrating on ending his victory drought in Houston rather than thinking ahead to next week's major championship. Garcia has also expressed that he's comfortable with the possibility that he may never win a major, stating it wouldn't make him sad if he finishes his career without one.

The Nepali Pranksters, who create videos showing people's reactions to pranks that challenge cultural norms, were shooting an episode about Nepal's ban on plastic bags near Nepal's famed Central Zoo when a magnitude-7.8 earthquake struck. One video shows the pranksters walking up to strangers for awkward handshakes, but during this particular video shoot, they kept cameras rolling for 18 minutes as they documented the earthquake's destruction and helped coordinate emergency response efforts through the devastated streets of Nepal.

Fashion designer Max Azria, who founded the popular BCBG Max Azria brand, has put his luxurious 30,000 square foot Los Angeles mansion in Holmby Hills on the market for $85 million. Azria purchased the house for $14.4 million in 2005 and invested an additional $30 million in renovations, transforming it into an opulent estate featuring 17 bedrooms, 22 bathrooms, a movie theater, tennis court, and multiple themed gardens. The mansion, originally built in 1939 for Old Hollywood stars, now showcases extravagant amenities including a crystal chandelier made of 150,000 crystals and sits on three acres in one of LA's most affluent neighborhoods.

Driver Mei Ru, 50, accidentally killed her husband Song Ming, 53, when she reversed over him while parking outside a supermarket in Fuzhou, China, during a shopping trip. Song had exited the passenger side and walked behind the car when Mei Ru suddenly reversed, knocking him down and running over his body. He died at the hospital from massive internal bleeding and broken ribs, while his grief-stricken wife is being treated for shock.

NBC News has changed its account of the 2012 kidnapping of chief foreign correspondent Richard Engel in Syria, now saying he was most likely taken by Sunni rebels who tried to convince their victims they were government militants. The broadcaster previously reported that Mr Engel's five-day captivity was carried out by forces associated with President Bashar al-Assad, but further investigation revealed the kidnappers were likely a criminal gang taking hostages for money and propaganda purposes. NBC was prompted to reassess the circumstances after the New York Times raised questions about the attackers' identities.

Lidia Quilligana, a nanny, was arrested in Danbury, Connecticut after police viewed video footage that allegedly showed her choking and beating a 3-year-old girl in her care. The video also caught her burning the child's legs, arms, and hands on a hot stove as the girl screamed in pain. Quilligana has been charged with first degree assault of a child under 10 years old and her bail has been set at $1 million.

During a White House Take Our Daughters and Sons to Work Day event, a little girl named Anya Brodie asked Michelle Obama her age, and when Obama replied that she was 51 years old, the girl exclaimed that she looked "too young" for her age. Michelle Obama was so flattered by Anya Brodie's compliment that she asked the girl to come on stage for a hug. The event included children of White House employees, kids from the Boys and Girls Club, and children from D.C. Child and Family Services.

Philip Garrod, 43, a paramedic with the Welsh Ambulance Service, was caught speeding at 105mph on his powerful Suzuki motorbike and subsequently struck off for faking a 999 emergency call-out to try to avoid a driving ban. After being caught speeding, Garrod lied to magistrates claiming he was rushing to respond to an injured cyclist, even creating false patient records to support his story. When ambulance bosses investigated and found no record of any emergency call on that date, Garrod was found guilty of misconduct and removed from the professional register.

Vin Los, a 24-year-old Canadian man, has defied expectations by turning his extensive body art into a successful modeling career, despite most people believing that being covered in face tattoos would make it impossible to land a job. His unique ink includes 24 tattoos on his face alone, along with Sharpie-like tattoos covering his head, neck, chest, and arms, featuring phrases like "fame" prominently displayed on his forehead and even tattooed-on chest hair. Vin's unconventional look has now earned him a lucrative underwear modeling campaign with Garçon Model, proving that his distinctive appearance can be a professional asset rather than a hindrance.

At 85 years old, legendary racing driver Sir Stirling Moss, who won 212 races during his 14-year career, was reunited with his refurbished Austin-Healey Sprite training car for a new documentary. The car was the same vehicle he drove just one month before the career-ending crash at Goodwood on Easter Monday in 1962, and Sir Stirling appears to have retained his racing skills as he took the restored car for a spin around the track more than 50 years later.

Taylor Lynn Fast, 21, was arrested after her 17-month-old daughter Layla was found beaten to death at their home in Festus, Missouri. Fast allegedly claimed that a spider bite led to the fatal injuries and severe bruising found on the child, though police said the wounds were consistent with the worst child abuse they had ever seen. Paramedics determined that Layla had been dead for several hours when they arrived, and Fast has been charged with endangering the welfare of a child.

Officer Jared Forsyth, 33, a member of the Ocala Police Department since 2012, was accidentally shot by a coworker during firearms training at a gun range at the Lowell Correctional Institution. Despite being rushed to surgery at Ocala Regional Medical Center in critical condition, Forsyth died from his injuries several hours later. The Florida Department of Law Enforcement is investigating the accidental shooting incident.

Police are investigating a series of suspected arson attacks on three Melbourne Catholic churches linked to paedophile priests, including St Mary's in Dandenong where Father Kevin O'Donnell allegedly molested children from 1958-1986, and St James in Brighton where Father Ronald Pickering sexually abused boys between 1960-1980. At least five victims of Pickering's abuse later committed suicide, and the former priest was officially named by the Catholic Church in 2013 as guilty of sexually abusing children before he died without facing justice. Police have released an image of a bearded man they want to question in connection with the fires, while Catholic churches are increasing security measures in response to the attacks.

Shaquille Omar Hallisey, 20, was jailed for four years at Cardiff Crown Court after pleading guilty to wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm for hitting stranger Matthew Leeke, 38, over the head with a bottle in Cardiff. The attack left Leeke with a fractured skull and required paramedics to treat cuts to his head that needed gluing and stapling at the hospital. The judge described Hallisey's assault as "a savage demonstration of violence in a public place" and noted the profound impact on the victim, who now suffers from anxiety, dizziness, and headaches.

A new study reveals that pets love watching TV, with the average pet spending 21 hours a week in front of the screen, while over a third of owners say their pets watch three hours per day when left alone. Cats, dogs and pigs show a clear preference for animal-focused programming, with "For the Love of Dogs" being their top choice and Springwatch ranking as pets' third favourite show. Owners often spend hours watching with their animals and leave the TV on for company, with some micro pig owners allowing their pets to watch up to four hours of shows per day.

More than three years ago, Claire, Emily, Christine and Lily Vincenti were taken from their Italian home by their mother to Australia, sparking a custody dispute that ended with their dramatic return to Italy in 2012. The four Vincenti girls, who were forcibly removed from Australia amid scenes of distress, are now living settled lives with their father Tomaso in Italy, though they miss Australia and speak to their mother nightly. Despite the traumatic custody battle, the two eldest sisters Claire and Emily have moved on from the ordeal and are thriving in their Italian home near Florence.

Former teacher Mary Kay Letourneau and her student-turned-husband Vili Fualaau spoke about their controversial relationship in a Barbara Walters interview on the eve of their 10th wedding anniversary, revealing how their sexual relationship began when he was just 12 years old. Letourneau was arrested and gave birth to their first daughter while on bail, then gave birth to their second daughter while serving a seven-and-a-half-year prison sentence. After Letourneau was released from prison in 2004, the couple got married in 2005 and have remained together since, despite facing various personal struggles over the years.

Carl Froch's planned fight with Julio Cesar Chavez Jr in Las Vegas was cancelled after Chavez lost to Andrzej Fonfara, leaving Froch's promoter Eddie Hearn exploring other options including potential fights with James DeGale or Gennady Golovkin. Hearn's hopes to stage a Carl Frampton-Scott Quigg fight this summer have collapsed after Frampton's team failed to respond to multiple offers, including a £1.5m guarantee, with Quigg now set to fight on July 18 instead. Meanwhile, Anthony Joshua will face Rafael Zumbano Love on May 9 in Birmingham as part of his busy schedule leading up to bigger fights later in the year.

Nine-year-old Annabel Beam fell 30ft headfirst down a hollow tree in 2011, and after an emergency fire crew managed to harness her to safety, she survived the fall with only minor injuries despite doctors preparing for the worst upon her arrival at the hospital. Her mother, Christy Wilson Beam, was amazed when Annabel, now 12, claimed she "went to heaven and sat in Jesus's lap" while unconscious and miraculously woke up cured of a rare digestive disorder that had plagued her childhood. The family believes Annabel's religious vision during the fall was connected to her remarkable physical healing and survival.

Bradford Bulls have launched an investigation after three cars were broken into and damaged in the Richard Dunn Sports Centre car park during Sunday's Ladbrokes Challenge Cup fifth-round defeat by Hull KR at Odsal. The club is working with Bradford Council, the sports centre, and West Yorkshire Police to find those responsible, with stadium manager Mark Leadbeater noting that similar incidents have occurred recently in local car parks throughout the area. The Bulls are appealing for witnesses and pledging to ensure the Richard Dunn Sports Centre car park remains a safe place for supporters to park on game days.

A mid-air altercation broke out on Oman Air flight 102 from London Heathrow to Muscat when one passenger objected to another moving seats, escalating into a brawl where one passenger allegedly attacked another with a shoe. The Oman Air cabin crew intervened to contain the situation, and the pilot alerted Muscat Airport, where one man was taken away for questioning upon arrival. This incident is part of a broader pattern of "legroom wars" on flights, including similar disputes on United Airlines and other carriers where space-related disagreements have led to flight diversions.

An Iranian military observation aircraft flew dangerously close to an armed U.S. Navy helicopter over the Persian Gulf this month, making two passes within 50 yards before the helicopter moved away. The incident, which occurred while the U.S. and other world powers were negotiating a deal limiting Tehran's nuclear program, has raised concerns among U.S. officials that local Iranian commanders may not be under full control of higher authorities. U.S. military officials believe the aggressive maneuver may have been locally ordered rather than sanctioned by top Iranian leadership, as Iranian forces have generally conducted operations professionally in recent months.

A survey of 2,000 pet owners created Britain's ideal dog by combining features from different breeds, including an English bulldog's coat, a border collie's body size, a King Charles spaniel's ears, and a labrador's snout. Regional preferences varied significantly, with Londoners preferring small lap-sized dogs while residents in East Anglia favored larger breeds like Great Danes. A quarter of owners said their perfect dog would live as long as they did, rather than the typical 10-13 year lifespan.

Two British soldiers, 25-year-old Scots Guard Shaun Smith and 22-year-old Welsh Guard Jason Collins, walked free from court despite carrying out a brutal drunken attack that was captured on CCTV, during which Smith stamped on a victim's head 18 times while Collins repeatedly punched the man's body. Both soldiers were found guilty of actual bodily harm and could have faced up to ten years in prison, but received lenient sentences instead - Smith got a 12-month suspended sentence while Collins received a 12-month community order. The judge called his decision to show mercy "extraordinary" and "exceptional," citing glowing character references and the Army's desire to retain both men.

West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has defended Leicester City boss Nigel Pearson ahead of their Premier League game on Saturday, calling him "his own man" despite Pearson's controversial incidents this season, including grabbing Crystal Palace midfielder James McArthur by the throat. Allardyce, who previously worked with Pearson at Newcastle in 2007, believes his former colleague has done an "unbelievable job" even though Leicester sits at the bottom of the Premier League table. Despite speculation that Pearson may be sacked, Allardyce feels the Leicester manager's performances don't warrant their lowly position and that they've simply failed to convert chances into results.

Eighteen-month-old twins drowned after their mother, Alexis Keslar, let go of their stroller while trying to fend off a bee during a walk along a canal Friday, causing the stroller to roll into the water, Arizona police said. Despite Keslar's rescue attempts and efforts by the irrigation district to slow the canal's flow, the twins were found dead after more than an hour of searching. Authorities warn that paths along Yuma canals, while popular with joggers and bicyclists, can be dangerous due to swift currents and steep embankments.

Terry McCarty suffered third-degree burns to 70 percent of his body at six years old in a childhood accident involving kerosene, enduring 58 operations and extended hospitalization. Despite facing his fears and cruel bullying throughout his recovery, McCarty overcame his trauma by becoming a firefighter at age 29, proving to himself and others that he could conquer anything. After two years of firefighting, he now dedicates his life to helping other burn victims through his work with the Burned Children Recovery Foundation.

A fund-raising campaign launched by forces charity Help for Heroes to help keep Second World War veteran Robert Clark in his own home has already raised £10,000 in just four days, after Brent Council refused to continue paying for his live-in carer. The charity has now set a new fund-raising target of £15,000 to help Mr Clark remain in his home of over 50 years, as he faces the prospect of being moved to a care home despite having already spent £50,000 of his life savings on his care.

Conservative party offices in Aberdeen, Scotland were vandalized with graffiti including a swastika, the word "scum," and the letter "Q" sprayed in white paint, which a Tory councillor blamed on "nationalists." The incident occurred six months after similar defacing of buildings and polling stations during the Scottish Referendum campaign, with Labour offices also reportedly targeted with a "Q" symbol.

Lucas Matthysse (37-3) won a majority decision against Ruslan Provodnikov (24-3) in a 12-round super lightweight bout on Saturday night, using his three-inch reach advantage to keep the Russian's powerful left hook at bay despite Provodnikov landing two hard right hook-left hook combos in the fourth round and managing to stagger Matthysse in the 11th. Matthysse celebrates after the hard-fought victory, with Provodnikov graciously admitting his opponent was the better fighter on the night.

Ferrari team principal Maurizio Arrivabene uses a "carrot-and-stick" psychological approach with Kimi Raikkonen amid speculation that Lewis Hamilton could replace the Finnish driver at Ferrari next season. At Sunday's Bahrain Grand Prix, Raikkonen delivered his best performance of the season, finishing second behind race winner Hamilton and earning his first podium in 26 races. While Arrivabene praised Raikkonen's performance and suggested he deserves contract renewal, he emphasized keeping the driver motivated by maintaining some uncertainty about his future with the team.

A study of 108 world countries by Expert Market found that Jamaica is the country where you're most likely to have a female boss, with nearly 60% of managers being women, while the United States ranked within the top 20 countries at 15th place with 42.7% female managers. At the opposite end of the spectrum, Pakistan ranked as the worst country in the world for female management representation, with only 3% of managers being women.

Australian teenager Violeta Tupuola joined the viral #kyliejennerchallenge by putting lip gloss on her lips before using a shot glass to create a vacuum that caused her lips to swell to extreme proportions, leaving her shocked at the bizarre duck-like result. The dangerous trend, which causes lips to turn purple and creates painful effects lasting hours or days, has countless teens sharing disturbing results on social media as they attempt to emulate Kylie Jenner's plump lips, despite Jenner denying she has had plastic surgery. The method works by creating an airlock that increases blood flow and causes severe swelling, often resulting in bruising and lasting damage around the mouth area.

Defiant Stuart McCall on Thursday night urged Rangers to show an immediate response after the Ibrox side crashed to a second Championship defeat of the season at Palmerston, losing 3-0 to Queen of the South. McCall insisted that confidence would not be dented by his first defeat as Rangers manager and called for his players to bounce back in their upcoming home match against Raith Rovers on Sunday.

The LAPD is searching for a vandal who tagged police horse Charly with graffiti while the horse was patrolling Venice Beach with his handlers on Tuesday. The incident involved someone spray-painting "RBS" and an arrow on the horse's flank in broad daylight, with a witness posting images of the aftermath to Instagram. Police are hoping to track down the perpetrator using the cryptic "RBS" tag and have requested public assistance in identifying the person responsible.

Tony Fernandes spoke of his despair after his Queens Park Rangers team twice threw away a lead against Aston Villa in a 3-3 draw at Villa Park, with the Rangers chairman watching the match from Malaysia on his iPhone. Despite QPR taking the lead twice through Matt Phillips and Charlie Austin, Christian Benteke's hat-trick for Villa denied them a crucial victory in their relegation battle. Fernandes expressed mixed emotions about the performance and hinted at potential changes regarding his future at the club.

Harry Kane tops this week's EA Sports Performance Index as the Premier League's best player after scoring his third goal in Tottenham's 3-1 win at Newcastle United, bringing his tally to 20 Premier League goals this season. The 21-year-old striker, who has now scored 30 goals in all competitions and is nominated for both PFA Player of the Year and Young Player of the Year awards, earned a Game Index score of 55.1. The top 10 rankings feature several Tottenham players, with Leicester's Esteban Cambiasso also making the list after winning seven tackles in their victory over Swansea.

A protective dad created a t-shirt featuring his muscly torso with the message "Stay Clear Boys, This is my dad!" to keep boys away from his daughter, though she appears unhappy about wearing it. The image was first shared on Reddit under the headline "Dad security" and later went viral when Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu champion Kit Dale shared it on his Facebook page. By Wednesday, the image had been liked by 370,000 Facebook users and shared over 45,000 times, generating mixed reactions from commenters who either applauded or ridiculed the father's approach.

An unnamed New York woman's body was left dangling from a third-floor fire escape for more than an hour Sunday after she hung herself outside her Crown Heights apartment building. The woman's body was discovered around 8:20am hanging outside a neighbor's window, with witnesses describing the traumatic scene as looking like a "horror movie." The woman's identity has not been released pending family notification, though neighbors described her as social but struggling with mental health issues.

Full back David Raven stabbed home the winner to take Inverness Caledonian Thistle to the Scottish Cup final, defeating Celtic in the semi-final at Hampden Park. Celtic subsequently wrote to the SFA complaining about not being awarded a penalty, with Celtic captain Scott Brown among those appealing to the referee during the match. The author criticizes Celtic's actions as arrogant and argues that a club like Celtic writing such a letter spoiled Raven's career highlight, while also suggesting that Scottish football overall needs major restructuring due to declining standards and attendance.

Despite Real Madrid's Champions League final win against Atletico Madrid last season, Real has failed to win any of their last seven games against their city rivals, with Atletico emerging victorious four times including a 2-0 win courtesy of goals that featured Fernando Torres scoring winning goals. Real Madrid drew 0-0 with Atletico Madrid last week in the first leg of their Champions League quarter-final, setting up Wednesday night's Champions League quarter-final second leg as the eighth meeting between the teams since Real's final triumph. Atletico's dominance over Real has included multiple victories across different competitions, with their most emphatic being a 4-0 win that marked Real's heaviest defeat in over four years.

The impressive Ile Louët, a secluded lighthouse island in Morlaix Bay, Brittany, offers accommodation for up to 10 guests in a renovated 19th century lighthouse keeper's cottage for just €200 (£145) for two nights. This unique retreat requires boat transport to reach and offers basic amenities with spectacular ocean views, though guests must sacrifice modern comforts like hot running water. The lighthouse island is so popular that it's fully booked for 2015, with bookings now being taken for 2016.

Boobesh Palani, a 26-year-old Indian student, passed away at Wellington Hospital with his friends by his side after being rescued from Wellington Harbour by two teenage girls. Police were initially unable to identify Mr Palani and posted pictures of him lying in his hospital bed online, which led to a New Zealander in Sri Lanka recognizing him and helping police establish his identity. Thanks to the successful public appeal to identify Mr Palani, his family and friends were able to be with him during his final moments.

Scientists at the University of Bath and Yale University have developed a breakthrough in clean hydrogen power by creating a newly designed molecular catalyst that can efficiently split water to produce storable hydrogen fuel. While producing hydrogen typically requires huge amounts of energy, this new catalyst dramatically reduces energy losses during the water electrolysis process, making hydrogen-powered applications more economical and environmentally friendly. The technology could enable better storage of renewable energy from solar and wind sources by converting it into hydrogen fuel that can be used on demand.

Ed Miliband made his first appearance on the campaign trail in three days, campaigning in Bristol after going to ground over the Easter weekend to spend time with his family. While the Labour leader spent Saturday through Monday away from active campaigning, his political rivals including David Cameron continued drumming up support with just a month to go before polling day. Cameron was particularly active, embarking on a whirlwind tour of all four UK nations while Miliband remained largely out of the public eye.

Saudi Arabia conducted airstrikes in Yemen targeting a military base in Ibb province, but the strikes hit a nearby school, injuring at least six students and reportedly killing three others. The Saudi bombing campaign has destroyed dozens of buildings across Yemen, though airport terminals have remained largely untouched by Saudi bombs while surrounding structures were blown apart. The United States has supported Saudi Arabia's military intervention by promising to resupply Saudi weapons stocks used in the two-week bombing campaign against Houthi rebels.

Julieane Jablonski, 38, was charged with providing marijuana to a minor and witness tampering after her 19-year-old son Austin Essig jumped out of a third-story window following consumption of a pot brownie, with the Fort Collins Police Department booking her on suspicion of these crimes. Essig suffered non-life-threatening injuries from the fall and later commented on the Fort Collins police department's Facebook page about his experience, while authorities allege his mother told him to lie about where the marijuana came from. The incident highlights ongoing concerns about high THC levels in Colorado marijuana edibles and their effects on inexperienced users.

Divock Origi, the Belgium striker who was signed by Liverpool in a £10million deal after the 2014 World Cup but loaned back to Lille, said the progress of young players like winger Jordon Ibe and Raheem Sterling has heightened his excitement about joining Liverpool. Origi praised manager Brendan Rodgers' ability to develop young talent and believes the challenging season at Lille has made him mentally stronger and better prepared for his move to Anfield.

ESPN sports reporter Britt McHenry, who presents herself as a champion of women's rights and encourages women to have "a voice" rather than focus on appearance alone, was suspended for one week after a video surfaced showing her verbally attacking a towing company employee with classist and body-shaming comments. Despite being warned that she was being filmed, McHenry continued her tirade, telling the clerk to "lose some weight" and making derogatory remarks about her education and job. A petition has been launched calling for McHenry's termination, arguing that retaining her sends a message condoning cruel behavior, while the towing company has stated they have no interest in seeing her suspended or fired.

Scottish illustrator Johanna Basford has sold more than 1.4 million copies of her adult coloring book called "Secret Garden," which has been translated into 22 languages and sparked a global trend of adults simply coloring for relaxation and creativity. The phenomenon has become so popular that adult coloring books are now outselling cookbooks in France, with adults forming coloring circles and using the activity as a way to disconnect from technology and reduce stress. Basford's success demonstrates a growing desire among adults to engage in analog, creative activities that provide therapeutic benefits without the pressure of being productive or screen-based.
