In 2014, the NHS handed out 404,500 prescriptions for suncream costing £13 million and 4.7 million prescriptions for indigestion pills costing £29 million, with GPs routinely prescribing everyday items like toothpaste, Calpol, and Vaseline that are cheaply available over-the-counter. Critics have branded this spending "ludicrous" during the NHS's financial crisis, with doctors reporting that patients eligible for free prescriptions come to their surgery every week wanting prescriptions for basic household items instead of buying them from chemists. The controversy highlights concerns about system abuse while the NHS faces an £8 billion budget shortfall and has been forced to ration cancer treatments and routine operations.

Mark Vanhoenacker's book "Skyfaring" offers a timely perspective on aviation following the Germanwings tragedy where troubled co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed flight 9525 into the French Alps. The British Airways senior first officer, who coincidentally started his career flying the same Airbus 320 model as Lubitz, focuses on his passion for flying rather than dwelling on plane crashes either accidental or premeditated. Vanhoenacker particularly celebrates the Boeing 747, which he admires like a sculptor might view a perfect human torso, explaining why pilots like flying 747s for reasons ranging from their aesthetic beauty to practical comforts like foot heaters.

Crystal Palace manager Alan Pardew insists Manchester City can still come from behind to snatch the Barclays Premier League title from Chelsea, despite being six points behind with Chelsea having a game in hand. Pardew points to City's recent history of dramatic late title wins, including when they overtook Liverpool with one match to go to win the Premier League title last season, and Sergio Aguero's dramatic injury-time winner against QPR in 2012 that sealed City's first Premier League title win. The Palace boss believes the Premier League title race is never over, as his team prepares to host City on Monday.

Manchester United midfielder Michael Carrick, 34, has revealed he wants to pursue a career in Formula One motorsport when his football playing days are over, despite currently enjoying a renaissance season and hoping to play for many more years. The former West Ham player, who has been talking to United assistant Ryan Giggs about longevity in the sport, says he wouldn't swap football for anything except maybe being an F1 driver, as he's a massive fan of the sport. Carrick is focused on maintaining his fitness and form at 33-34 years old, learning from legends like Ryan Giggs to extend his career while keeping his future motorsport ambitions in mind.

Wood Green animal charity has partnered with a cleaning app to offer a cat fostering service that helps homeowners tackle mouse infestations by lending them cats for temporary stays. The charity claims that the presence and scent of cats from their collection of over 200 animals is enough to scare away unwanted rodents without the cats needing to actually catch mice. The article also mentions that Amazon offers a separate goat rental service for lawn maintenance, where goats can eat various types of vegetation including invasive plants.

At this year's Coachella festival, celebrities and attendees wore increasingly outlandish outfits that showcased abundant exposed skin, with stars like Reality star Kylie Jenner sporting nude hotpants and see-through bodysuits, Paris Hilton wearing bizarre rose-petal cat ears, and Singer Katy Perry opting for a tent-like dress with chunky tribal jewelry. The festival-goers wore ever more extreme looks including neon accessories, gold lamé pieces, excessively-adorned veils, and some attendees ditched the outfit-choosing hassle entirely by wearing costumes like a full mummy bodysuit. The Coachella festival has become notorious for its over-the-top fashion choices, with this year's attendees pushing boundaries even further with clashing prints, minimal clothing, and bizarre accessories.

Sandringham's trophy room has undergone a complete transformation, with all 62 hunting memorabilia items including stuffed rhino heads, tigers, and tusks removed from public display and replaced with "trinkets and bric-a-brac," while the blood-red walls have been repainted white to mark a clear break from the past. Questions were raised about the legality of some unworked ivory and animal items under European Council regulations, creating particular embarrassment for animal welfare crusader Prince William who has previously denounced the illegal wildlife trade. The museum now displays items like ashtrays and cycling club badges instead of the magnificent animals that once dominated the space, with officials citing the need to update exhibits in line with changing times.

Britain has long seen prosecco as the second choice to champagne, but last year UK sales of prosecco overtook champagne for the first time, reaching £181.8 million compared to £141.3 million for champagne. The tank method of producing prosecco bubbles keeps production costs down compared to champagne's more expensive bottle fermentation process, making prosecco more affordable and accessible. In 2009, the area allowed to produce wine under the prosecco DOC name was expanded significantly, with higher-quality wines from certain regions commanding premium prices, though most prosecco remains reasonably priced between £6-£15.

Former Adelaide doctor Tareq Kamleh, who fled Australia to join ISIS, appeared in the latest terrorist propaganda video encouraging foreign medical professionals to join the Islamic State in Raqqa to help launch their health service. Despite his public support for the terrorist cult and appearance in the recruitment video, Dr Kamleh remains registered to practice medicine in Australia until September 30, as the Medical Board has refused to deregister him. If he returns to Australia, he could face up to 25 years in prison for his involvement with the terrorist organization.

A tragic head-on crash occurred on Saturday evening on NSW's Central Coast when a car carrying a grandmother and three children aquaplaned and collided with a ute, killing siblings Piper Kulk, 8, and her brother William, 9, while their older brother Daniel remains hospitalized in stable condition. The accident also left passengers in the ute with severe injuries, including Michelle who suffered broken bones and her mother Glenda who sustained a fractured neck. The crash happened around 5:15pm on Wyee Road near Doyalson, trapping all seven people involved in the wreckage before emergency services could free them from the vehicles.

Former Italian police officer Dino Maglio has been found guilty of raping a 16-year-old Australian girl after luring her to his home through Couchsurfing.com and drugging her drink with a tranquilizer. While Maglio claimed the sex was consensual, he admitted to spiking her Baileys liqueur, and prosecutors argued that the sedative made her unable to resist, leading to his conviction and six-and-a-half-year prison sentence. An investigation revealed that over a dozen alleged victims came forward with similar accounts of being drugged and sexually assaulted by Maglio after staying at his home through the host-traveler website.

In a quiz for Cosmopolitan magazine, Ed Miliband said sexting is "not advised for politicians" while Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg called sending sexy text messages "risky if you are young, dodgy if you are older." Their cautious responses reflect the political downfalls of colleagues like Tory MP Brooks Newmark, who became embroiled in two sexting scandals and is stepping down from his position, demonstrating how salacious messages have damaged several politicians' careers when revealed in the press.

Tracy Walters, 48, died after her husband Ian's car veered off the M1 motorway last year, with Ian Walters now accused of murdering his wife by deliberately crashing their vehicle into a tree at 84mph. The prosecution claims Walters purposely crashed to show his wife "who was in charge" after their marriage collapsed due to sexual conflicts and alleged abuse. Walters denies murder, claiming he may have fallen asleep at the wheel due to antidepressants that made him drowsy.

Manchester Airport temporarily halted all flights for about 20 minutes today after a potential drone sighting raised fears of collision with passenger aircraft, causing departing flights to be delayed and incoming flights to be diverted to other airports. Police helicopters searched the area around Manchester Airport but found no evidence of a drone operating in the airspace. The incident highlights the growing problem of drones flying too close to airports, which pose significant safety threats to commercial aviation.

China's cybercensors have developed a new cyberweapon called the "Great Cannon" that attacks servers outside China's borders, including in the United States, representing a powerful attack capability that goes beyond their traditional "Great Firewall" which monitors tons of traffic to block content. Study authors found that Beijing used this weapon to target services like Greatfire.org (run by Chinese expats bent on fighting censorship) and GitHub through massive distributed denial of service attacks, using unsuspecting web users' browsers as unwitting participants. While the Great Firewall passively monitors and blocks traffic, the Great Cannon actively weaponizes internet traffic to attack foreign servers, marking a significant escalation in China's cyber capabilities.

Ciudad Real Airport in Spain, which was built in 2009 for over €1 billion to handle overflow from Madrid's Barajas airport, is now being sold for just one pound after closing in 2012 when airlines stopped flying from its terminals. The airport, featuring a 4,000-meter runway that must be painted with yellow crosses to warn pilots they cannot land, was designed to serve 5 million passengers annually but became a financial white elephant when its parent company fell into difficulties. Despite the nominal sale price, new owners will need to pay off hundreds of millions in debt for this redundant airport that stands as a symbol of Spain's economic overreach.

NYPD Detective Patrick Cherry apologized on NBC 4 New York after being caught on video screaming at and berating an Uber driver, leading to him being stripped of his shield and gun and placed on administrative duty. The incident, which went viral with over three million YouTube views, showed the officer shouting at the driver, threatening arrest without cause, and making inappropriate comments about the driver's accent and English skills. NYPD Police Chief Bill Bratton condemned the behavior, stating that "no good cop should watch that video without a wince" as Cherry's case was transferred to the Civilian Complaint Review Board for investigation.

Former Manchester United goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar is convinced that Louis van Gaal will bring the glory days back to Old Trafford, as Van Gaal's United head to Chelsea on Saturday in top form after winning six successive matches. Van der Sar admits the title is probably beyond United's grasp this season, but believes that with some summer signings and continued faith in van Gaal's philosophy, Manchester United can return to where they belong and potentially challenge for the championship next year.

Bournemouth drew 2-2 with Sheffield Wednesday in a dramatic match where they trailed early, equalized, then took the lead through Matt Ritchie's spectacular free-kick before conceding a stoppage-time penalty. Manager Eddie Howe was left frustrated after Simon Francis was sent off for two yellow cards and felt his team was denied a penalty when Callum Wilson appeared to be fouled by Lewis Buxton, suggesting referees may be reluctant to award more penalties after Bournemouth has already received 15 this season. The draw represented a missed opportunity for Bournemouth to maintain their position at the top of the table in what has been described as an "absurd season."

18-year-old Billy-Anne Huxham was reportedly abducted at knife-point by her 32-year-old ex-partner Carl Garry Chapman from her Caboolture home, during which Ms Huxham sustained wounds to her leg and facial bruising from the violent attack. After escaping her captor, she contacted family members who then contacted police, leading to her being found safe by authorities at 9:45pm in Maroochydore. Chapman has been charged with multiple offenses including assault, torture, and deprivation of liberty in connection with the abduction.

Southampton manager Ronald Koeman's message to his players is clear: focus on yourselves and start scoring goals, as the Saints have struggled in front of goal recently, scoring just seven times in their last 10 Premier League matches. Despite their scoring woes, Southampton sits seventh in the Premier League with 53 points and are chasing European qualification, with striker Graziano Pelle particularly struggling to reproduce his early-season form. The Saints face Hull City on Saturday as they look to rediscover their scoring touch, with Koeman potentially recalling Sadio Mane to address their attacking problems.

Teller Lake in Boulder, Colorado has been invaded by 3,000 to 4,000 goldfish after someone dumped four or five of their pets in the water two or three years ago. The invasive goldfish are now threatening native species by consuming their resources and potentially spreading diseases. Wildlife officials are considering draining the 12-acre lake or using electrofishing to remove all the goldfish and restore the natural ecosystem.

Tim Howard has rejected claims that Europa League participation is to blame for Everton delivering what could be their worst Premier League season in nine years, with Roberto Martinez's side potentially finishing in the bottom half for the first time since 2006. Despite playing 10 Europa League games this season, Howard argued that Champions League teams face similar fixture congestion without using it as an excuse, stating that Everton have simply had an unlucky campaign where things haven't gone their way. The team is currently 25 points worse off than at the same stage last season, having dropped from targeting Champions League qualification to chasing a top-10 finish.

The Atlanta Hawks crushed the Brooklyn Nets 131-99 on Saturday night to match a franchise record with their 57th win, with Al Horford and DeMarre Carroll each scoring 20 points. However, the victory was marred by the loss of forward Paul Millsap, who suffered a right shoulder injury in a collision during the first half and did not return to the game.

Mobile phone companies boasted that new 4G mobile phone services would be 'five times faster' than existing 3G networks, but a study by Ofcom says 4G speeds in the UK are slower than promised, delivering only 2.5 times faster speeds on average (14.7 Mbit/s compared to 5.9 Mbit/s for 3G service). The 4G speed data comes from Ofcom's research showing EE had the fastest average download speed at 18.6 Mbit/s, followed by Vodafone as second fastest at 16.4 Mbit/s, with speeds potentially declining further as more users join the networks.

Jimmy Anderson was presented with a special silver cap after reaching 100 Test matches for England, joining an elite group of fast bowling centurions. Meanwhile, West Indies' best batsman Chris Gayle chose to prioritize the lucrative IPL over representing his country in Test cricket, scoring only 21 runs for Royal Challengers Bangalore. The cricket world also paid tribute to the late Richie Benaud with a minute's silence and black armbands during play in the West Indies.

Ellia Beasley, who has more than 20 tattoos, lived to regret featuring Lost Prophet lyrics "scream your heart out" tattooed on her belly after the band's lead singer Ian Watkins was sent to prison for 35 years in 2013 for child sex offences. After multiple tattoo artists told her the bold lyrics couldn't be covered, she finally found specialist Kevin Paul who successfully created a new tattoo design featuring a giant owl that completely obscured the unwanted text. The experience has made her reconsider having lyrics tattooed on her body in the future unless they have personal significance.

Taxi driver Teng Jiazhi, known as "Uncle Teng," from Shenyang, North China, has entered the Chinese record books by taking 30,000 selfies with passengers in his car over the past ten years. The 58-year-old driver, who picks up as many as eighty passengers daily, started this unique practice as an alternative to accepting tips and now takes selfies with at least twenty passengers each day. Passengers comment on how Uncle Teng's infectious smile brightens their journeys, and his selfie photos have made him one of the most recognized faces in the region through social media.

Mindy Kaling has denied knowing about her brother Vijay Chokal-Ingam's controversial claim that he pretended to be black to gain admission to medical school in 1998, with her representative stating she has been estranged from him for years and was unaware of his decision to apply under a different race. Chokal-Ingam, who is promoting his new book "Almost Black," claims he transformed his appearance and interviewed at eleven prestigious medical schools including Harvard and Columbia as a black man, arguing this exposed flaws in affirmative action policies. Critics have denounced Chokal-Ingam's experiment as insulting and irresponsible, arguing that he ignores how ongoing racism makes affirmative action absolutely necessary and fails to acknowledge the structural barriers that keep black applicants marginalized at elite institutions.

Julie McKenzie's nagging back pain was initially attributed to scoliosis by her GP, but a private MRI scan revealed a malignant spinal tumour in her coccyx that required surgical removal. The case highlights experts' concerns that chronic back pain is often dismissed as "non-specific low back pain" without proper investigation, potentially missing treatable conditions including spinal tumours. While 80% of people experience severe back pain, only 8% develop chronic pain, yet many of these cases could benefit from early MRI scanning and proper diagnosis rather than being written off as muscular problems.

A disgruntled French Bulldog was caught on camera continually honking a car horn after being left alone in a vehicle in Eureka, California. Ryan Burns went to investigate the persistent beeping sound and discovered the dog standing with its front paws pressed firmly on the horn, refusing to stop even when filmed. The video, which Burns uploaded online, has been viewed over one million times, though the dog's owner claims the pet was only left briefly and is well-cared for.

Anthony Barbour, a 33-year-old photographer from Liverpool, has turned typical British locations including parks, villages and beaches into surreal individual "planets" using mind-bending 360-degree photographs. His pictures showcase locations like Sefton Park and Liverpool One shopping centre in Liverpool, along with various sites across Dorset, the New Forest, and North Wales, created by finding the right location and spending hours taking 50 images while slowly rotating in one spot. Barbour finds photography serves as an artistic escape while dealing with a recent illness diagnosis of Ulcerative Pan Colitis, keeping himself creatively occupied through intricate editing techniques.

Waheed Ahmed, the 21-year-old son of Labour councillor Shakil Ahmed (who has been pictured with Ed Miliband), was arrested at Birmingham Airport on suspicion of terrorism offences after being stopped at the Turkish-Syrian border with eight relatives. Along with five other family members who were arrested at Manchester Airport and in Rochdale, Waheed has now been released without charge after police found no evidence of an imminent threat to the UK.

A 32-year-old Massachusetts man, Carlos Colina, is facing murder charges in connection with another man's remains that were discovered Saturday in Cambridge. Police found human remains in a duffel bag along a walkway, and surveillance video led them to discover additional body parts at a nearby apartment building. The victim has been identified as 26-year-old Jonathan Camilien, who knew Colina according to authorities.

In-form winger Aaron Murphy scored twice in Huddersfield's dominant 38-14 Super League victory over Catalans Dragons, helping end their three-match losing streak in a seven-try romp. The 27-year-old former Wakefield Wildcats star has now scored six tries in his last five appearances, continuing his excellent recent form. Huddersfield's comprehensive win was built on strong attacking play, with Murphy's second try coming from a Danny Brough kick that caused problems for the Catalans defense throughout the match.

At least three suspects attempted to carjack a driver at a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday morning, and when he refused and ran away, they poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger and set it on fire while two passengers were still inside. The incident occurred around 12:15am at a 76 station in California, completely torching the vehicle's front end, though fortunately no one was injured. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the case as arson while the suspects remain at large.

According to StatusPeople.com, the oldest publicly available Twitter-auditing tool, only 44 percent of Hillary Clinton's Twitter followers are real people who actively participate on the platform, with at least 15 percent (over 544,000) being completely fake. This contrasts sharply with President Barack Obama's Twitter followers, where just 4 percent are considered fake. Clinton's campaign also faces scrutiny over Facebook followers, with over 46,000 listing Baghdad as their hometown, suggesting potential digital manipulation of her social media presence.

Andrea Dossena, a 33-year-old former Liverpool player who scored memorable goals against Real Madrid and Manchester United, has been arrested on suspicion of shoplifting at Harrods in London. Police arrested Dossena and a 31-year-old woman on Tuesday at the Knightsbridge store, with both individuals later bailed pending further enquiries. Dossena, who Liverpool once paid £7million for, now plays for League One strugglers Leyton Orient after signing with them in November.

Animal Rescue Corps workers helped free 97 dogs from deplorable conditions in a blacked-out barn in Manchester, Tennessee, where the animals had been living in complete darkness surrounded by their own waste, with 10 dead dogs piled in a wheelbarrow covered in maggots. The rescued dogs, who displayed overwhelming fear after their ordeal, turned their heads and noses toward the sun when brought outside for the first time. The property owner, 64-year-old Caroline Irby, was charged with 10 counts of animal cruelty following the rescue operation.

Michael Easy, 29, from Southampton, sparked a nationwide police manhunt after going on the run and taunting police by posing on Facebook in Dame Edna-style glasses and a platinum wig. He has now been jailed for four months after breaching a restraining order involving his former girlfriend and assaulting two male prison officers at Winchester Prison, causing facial swelling to one guard. Easy, a serial offender with over 27 convictions, had previously been imprisoned for attacking his pregnant former girlfriend at a party.

Harold Ekeh, an 18-year-old Long Island senior who moved from Nigeria to Long Island 10 years ago, has been accepted to all eight Ivy League schools plus five other prestigious universities. His success stems from his compelling essay about his family's struggle with emigrating to America and his exceptional academic record, including a 2270 SAT score and straight A's. With Yale accepting only 6.3 percent of applicants, Harold's achievement mirrors that of another Long Islander, Kwasi Enin, who chose Yale last year after similar acceptances, and Harold tells his younger brothers that "the sky isn't the limit" for their future accomplishments.

David Cameron and his wife Samantha have revealed they were "falling apart" from the pressure of caring for their son Ivan, who was born with Ohtahara Syndrome, a rare brain disorder that left him wheelchair-bound and suffering from severe epileptic fits. In intensely personal interviews, both parents described how the round-the-clock care required for Ivan, who died at age six in 2009, pushed their relationship to "breaking point" and left them "totally shattered" within the first year. Samantha Cameron spoke of the "nightmare" of learning about Ivan's condition and the isolation of caring for a severely disabled child, while praising her husband's strength in helping them find a way through the ordeal.

Frustrated listeners have complained to the BBC's Radio 4 programme about the vital last minutes of numerous shows being cut off on the iPlayer service, branding the problem 'irritating' and 'frustrating'. The BBC blames the issue on its automatic recording system, saying that live sections of radio stations cause programme times to shift, confusing the system. Despite this being a known problem since 2012 that handles audience complaints, the BBC says it is now adding two minutes to recordings to prevent future issues.

This article describes today's CNN Student News program from April 3, 2015, which covers international headlines, California's drought, religious holidays, and U.S. National Parks topics. The page provides access to the show's transcript and includes a Roll Call section where teachers and students can request to be mentioned on the next CNN Student News by commenting with their school information. CNN Student News will be selecting schools from previous show comments for the Roll Call feature.

Daniel Sturridge faces a fight to be fit for Liverpool's FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa on Sunday after being left out of Monday night's Barclays Premier League clash against Newcastle due to an injury problem sustained against Blackburn Rovers. Manager Brendan Rodgers will monitor the striker's fitness throughout the week ahead of the crucial Wembley semi-final, which represents Liverpool's last chance for silverware this season. Meanwhile, Manchester United's 4-2 victory over Manchester City has put Liverpool in a position to close within four points of fourth place in their pursuit of Champions League qualification.

Thomas Buckett, now 21, suffered life-changing head injuries including ten skull fractures when he plunged 15ft through a school roof in 2010 after breaking into the tuck shop with friends and being dared to jump on a glass skylight. His family unsuccessfully sued Staffordshire County Council for not adequately securing the school premises, arguing the council had ignored ongoing trespassing problems. The court ruled against the family, ordering them to pay £150,000 in legal costs to the council, with the judge stating that the incident was Thomas's fault and that few reasonable measures could have prevented the trespass.

Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho believes he is improving in every aspect of his job as a manager, having won league titles in all four countries he has managed (Portugal, England, Italy and Spain). However, Mourinho regularly finds himself in trouble with the Football Association due to his candid comments to the media, including being fined £25,000 for claiming there was a campaign against his side. The former Real Madrid manager admits his one weakness is that he cannot be a hypocrite when facing the press, insisting on being truthful despite the consequences.

Two black candidates were elected to the Ferguson City Council in the first municipal election since officer Darren Wilson fatally shot 18-year-old Michael Brown, tripling African-American representation on the six-member council. The election means that half of Ferguson's city council will now be African-American in a town where two-thirds of residents are black, with Wesley Bell winning the 3rd Ward race, Ella Jones taking the 1st Ward, and white former mayor Brian Fletcher winning the 2nd Ward race. This historic election came just over a month after a Justice Department report detailed systemic racism in Ferguson's government and police force, representing a significant step in the community's healing and rebuilding process.

Chelsea will face Paris Saint-Germain in a pre-season friendly in North Carolina on July 25, meeting the French team that knocked Jose Mourinho's side out of the Champions League this season. The match is one of three games Mourinho's team will play in the United States, including fixtures against New York Red Bulls on July 22 and Barcelona, as Chelsea prepares to defend their likely Premier League title after building a 10-point lead over Arsenal. The tour is part of the International Champions Cup, which Manchester United reached the final of in 2014.

Burnley manager Sean Dyche is calling on his teammates to share the goalscoring burden as striker Danny Ings continues his goal drought, having not scored since February 11 in a run of eight matches that has left the Premier League club bottom of the table. The 23-year-old Ings, who is strongly linked with moves to Manchester United or Liverpool when his contract expires in summer, missed Burnley's best chance in their 1-0 defeat to Everton on Saturday. Dyche insists it's unfair to pin the club's Premier League survival hopes solely on Ings, emphasizing that players like David Jones and others must step up to help keep Burnley in the top flight.

English photographer John Chapple has traveled the world creating stunning panoramic landscape images using a specialized film camera, capturing diverse scenes from major US cities like downtown Los Angeles and Santa Monica, California, to sandy beaches in Australia and grassy fields in England. Despite failing art in school, the self-taught Chapple transitioned from news and showbusiness photography to landscape work, using a unique Linhof Technorama 617s III camera that produces large 6x17 centimeter negatives. His photography is motivated by a desire to document the changing world for future generations, particularly after becoming a father and recognizing the need to preserve these landscapes for his children and grandchildren.

Madonna's new black crocodile handbag has caused controversy for its seemingly drug-related slogan "dealer" spelled out in diamond lettering, while singer Rihanna has also made headlines carrying gun-themed bags and in 2013 was spotted with clutches decorated with cannabis leaves. The article explores how celebrities are increasingly carrying statement bags with controversial designs, including weapons, explicit imagery, and offensive slogans, with other examples ranging from Grayson Perry's anatomically-inspired designs to problematic luggage stickers created by Vancouver designers.

ABC's World News Tonight with David Muir has officially overtaken NBC's Nightly News in the ratings war for the first time in more than five and a half years, ending NBC's 288 consecutive week winning streak. The ratings shift comes two months after NBC anchor Brian Williams received a six-month suspension for misleading viewers about his Iraq War coverage, with veteran Lester Holt serving as substitute anchor during Williams' absence. ABC attracted 84,000 more viewers than NBC for the week ending April 3, marking a significant milestone in the competitive evening news landscape.

Robert Downey Jr has been accused of making a racist remark about Oscar-winning Mexican director Alejandro González Iñárritu, saying "for a man whose native tongue is Spanish to be able to put together a phrase like 'cultural genocide' just speaks to how bright he is" when responding to the director's criticism of superhero movies. The comments sparked a furious backlash on Twitter with people calling it racist and ignorant. This controversy adds to other issues during the Avengers: Age of Ultron press tour, including co-stars Jeremy Renner and Chris Evans being forced to apologize for calling Scarlett Johansson's character derogatory names, and Downey Jr walking out of a separate interview when asked about his past drug abuse.

A leaked police report claims that another prisoner in the van with Freddie Gray told investigators that Gray was "banging against the walls" and "intentionally trying to injure himself" before dying from spinal cord injuries, though Gray's family attorney disputes this account and questions the accuracy of police reports. Six police officers involved in Gray's arrest and transportation are currently suspended pending investigation by the Baltimore Police Department, with Commissioner Anthony Batts claiming Gray had the capacity to walk when entering the van but acknowledging that officers ignored his requests for medical help. The investigation findings are expected to be turned over to the state's attorney by Friday, though officials warn that no immediate resolution should be expected despite growing public pressure and nationwide protests over Gray's death.

Never-before-seen photos from Sir Paul McCartney's 2002 wedding to Heather Mills have emerged, showing the former Beatle's daughters Stella and Mary looking unhappy in the wedding party picture, foreshadowing the bitter divorce that would follow when the couple separated in 2006. The images from the secret Irish wedding reception include Sir Paul performing a mock striptease for his bride and show memorabilia like the invitation featuring Sir Paul giving Ms Mills a piggy-back. These photos, belonging to the family of Sir Paul's late housekeeper, are now being auctioned after being kept private for over two decades.

Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel achieved his first victory with the team at the Malaysian Grand Prix, ending Ferrari's 35-race winless streak and his own 20-race drought. The four-time world champion returned to a hero's welcome at Ferrari's Maranello factory, where the win allowed Ferrari to revive long-standing traditions not seen since their previous triumph in 2013, including raising a Ferrari flag at the factory entrance. Vettel expressed determination to ensure this stunning win is not a one-off, as he prepares for the Chinese Grand Prix while acknowledging Mercedes' strong competitive position.

Iona Costello, 51, and her daughter Emily, who went missing last month from Long Island, have been found safe and well at a hotel in New York City's Upper West Side. The mother had been under stress due to a legal battle over her late husband George's estate, who died from a heart attack in 2012, with his adult children from previous marriages challenging the will that left everything to Iona. The case involved a complicated family situation, including Iona's stepson George Costello Jr, who has a history of drug arrests, and her brother-in-law John Costello, who is facing vehicular manslaughter charges.

When a Nigerian Christian began praying for his life on a sinking rubber dinghy carrying around 100 African refugees across the Mediterranean, Muslim migrants ordered him to stop and ultimately threw 12 Christians overboard when they refused, resulting in their deaths. This tragic incident occurred amid reports that 10,000 refugees fleeing war and persecution in Africa have been rescued by Italian ships in the past week, though over 900 migrants have died or gone missing this year, including 400 who died in two shipwrecks last week. Italian police arrested 15 people suspected of the killings, including the identification of one perpetrator through a bite wound on his toe from a victim.

Four-month-old baby Evan Summerfield died from meningitis just 12 hours after laughing for the first time, devastating his teenage parents who were shocked by how quickly he fell ill. Evan developed a high temperature and rash that stretched from his head to his belly button, and despite being rushed to Derriford Hospital in Plymouth, he was diagnosed with meningococcal septicaemia and died soon after. The tragic death highlights the rapid progression of meningitis, a disease that affects around 3,400 people annually in the UK and Ireland, with symptoms that can develop extremely quickly and prove fatal.

A 24-year-old Chicago Cubs fan named Krista Dotzenrod from Minnesota managed to catch a foul ball in her cup of beer during a game against the San Diego Padres on Saturday afternoon in Chicago. After making the lucky catch, which she described as "pure luck," Dotzenrod celebrated by chugging the beer with the ball still inside the cup to the delight of surrounding fans. The Cubs won the game 7-6 in 11 innings, and Dotzenrod's remarkable catch quickly gained attention on social media.

Dominika Petrinova from the Czech Republic was devastated when her boyfriend Erik Meldik pranked her by claiming he had accidentally put her beloved pet dog Sam in the washing machine, only to later reveal it was just a joke that he filmed and posted online. In revenge, Petrinova decided to get back at her boyfriend by gluing wax strips to a chair and tricking him into sitting on it naked and blindfolded, causing him excruciating pain when he tried to free himself. The painful prank was Petrinova's way of teaching her boyfriend a lesson after she was genuinely upset thinking her dog Sam was harmed.

Hull City are targeting QPR centre-back Nedum Onuoha, who may leave Loftus Road if the club is relegated, though Everton, West Ham United, and Stoke are also interested in the 28-year-old defender. Additionally, Hull City are showing interest in West Bromwich Albion striker Victor Anichebe, who is expected to be sold this summer. QPR are meanwhile in talks to sign Catania defender Nicolas Spolli, who has been on loan at Roma.

London's latest single-item restaurant trend continues with the opening of Oshun Café, which serves £6 bowls of Brazilian superfood acaí berries in four variations including the Oshun Maya (made with acaí pulp, raw cacao, cinnamon, orange and avocado) and Oshun Native (made with acaí pulp, banana and honey). This follows other specialized eateries like the UK's first cereal cafe featuring 120 cereals that opened in Brick Lane, the Porridge Cafe serving 25 types of porridge, and upcoming establishments like Melt Room (serving toasted sandwiches or "melts") and Black Milk Cereal Dive in Manchester.

The St Ivan Rilski Church stands as the only remaining evidence of the settlement of Zapalnya in south-east Bulgaria, where residents were forced to leave their homes in the 1960s when the Communist regime built a dam that submerged the town. The church, built in 1895 and located about 175 miles east of the capital Sofia, now sits partially submerged in the Zhrebchevo reservoir after the settlement and surrounding area were flooded in 1965. According to Radio Bulgaria, the church was once the heart of life in the valley, and the now-vanished town of Zapalnya was known for rose oil production during the Ottoman Empire.

Real Madrid demolished Granada 9-1 in a dominant La Liga performance, with Cristiano Ronaldo scoring five goals including a seven-minute hat-trick, while Karim Benzema added two goals and Gareth Bale also found the net. James Rodriguez returned to the starting lineup and contributed to the rout, with Javier Hernandez coming on as a substitute for Benzema during the match. The massive victory helped Real Madrid bounce back from their El Clasico defeat to Barcelona and represented one of the biggest wins of the La Liga season.

Everton hosts Southampton at Goodison Park on Saturday, with both teams facing key injury concerns as Everton striker Romelu Lukaku will undergo a late fitness test for a hamstring problem while Southampton midfielder Steven Davis is doubtful with a groin injury. Roberto Martinez's Everton side will be looking to improve their poor recent form, having won just eight of their 30 Premier League games this season, while Southampton could equal their best ever Premier League points tally with a victory in this fixture where the historical head-to-head record shows Everton leading with 39 wins to Southampton's 24.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is still considering whether to join Premier League leaders Chelsea this summer after the club made a £4 million offer for the Japan international, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. Chelsea would look to loan Muto to partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season, but the 22-year-old wants to join a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho has admitted he is aware of Muto and acknowledged that commercial interests play a part in the club's transfer policy.

Kick It Out has welcomed the successful prosecution of John Wild, who was found guilty of racially abusing former Wales goalkeeper Jason Brown during a football match last October and received a three-year banning order along with other penalties. While Brown welcomed the court outcome, he criticized several organizations including Kick It Out, The Football Association, and the Professional Footballers' Association for not providing adequate support during the incident. Kick It Out responded by detailing their involvement in the case, stating they met with Brown immediately after the incident and offered ongoing support, though Brown did not respond to follow-up attempts for assistance.

Scott Turner Schofield will become the first transgender man to have a recurring role on a daytime soap opera when he appears on the popular show The Bold and the Beautiful starting in May. Schofield, a performer and author known for addressing transgender issues, will be playing Nick, a mentor to the character Maya Avant who is struggling with her gender identity. This groundbreaking casting comes just days after Bruce Jenner's high-profile interview with Diane Sawyer, marking another significant moment for transgender representation on television.

Researchers warn that children should not be encouraged to play rugby at school due to safety concerns, with as many as 1 in 8 school children expected to suffer injuries serious enough that they need to miss at least seven training sessions or matches, including fractures, concussion, and other serious harm. Professor Allyson Pollock argues that many countries, including the UK, have inadequate child injury surveillance systems and calls for better monitoring of rugby injuries compared to population data before increasing school participation in the sport. While the Rugby Football Union maintains that rugby's benefits outweigh the risks, critics want safer modifications like eliminating tackles and scrums where most injuries occur.

Tiger Woods gave golf lessons to retired Chinese basketball star Yao Ming, the 7ft 6in former NBA player, at Nike's headquarters in Shanghai, where golf's former world No. 1 was dwarfed by the towering athlete as he helped him work on his swing. Meanwhile, Woods confirmed his return to the PGA Tour at the Players Championship on May 7, allaying fears about a wrist injury he suffered at the Masters and coming back earlier than expected after speculation about when he would feature in tournaments again.

Andy Murray advanced to the Miami Open semi-finals after defeating 21-year-old Austrian Dominic Thiem 3-6, 6-4, 6-1, though not before receiving a scare when Thiem pushed the match to 4-4 in the second set. Murray pumped his fist after securing the victory and described his opponent as a "strong guy" who hits the ball hard, making it a very physical match. The world No. 4 now has unfinished tennis business to attend to before his upcoming wedding next week.

Vincent Kompany, the Manchester City captain and winner of two Premier League titles, has revealed that his mother prevented him from joining Manchester United when he was just 17 years old while playing for Anderlecht. Kompany admits his mother insisted he finish school before moving to England, which delayed his Premier League move until 2008 when he eventually joined Manchester City instead. The Belgian defender says "everything has played out perfectly" despite missing the opportunity to join United under Sir Alex Ferguson as a teenager.

Leading author Margaret Atwood has dismissed the Duchess of Cambridge as an 'uneventful' dresser, saying the 75-year-old believes Kate hasn't lived up to the fashion icon reputation of her husband William's late mother, Princess Diana. Atwood suggested that Kate is cautious with her clothing choices and likely has advisers telling her what to wear, though she added that the duchess is probably right not to follow in Diana's footsteps. Despite this criticism, Kate's fashion influence remains strong, with items like a £46 Seraphine dress she wore for her first official family portrait with William and Prince George selling out within hours of being photographed.

Martyn Uzzell, a 51-year-old experienced cyclist, died instantly after being thrown from his bike by a four-inch deep pothole during a charity ride from Land's End to John O'Groats, landing in the path of an oncoming car. His widow Kate Uzzell has won a six-figure payout from North Yorkshire County Council, who had been warned about the dangerous pothole by police a month before the fatal accident but failed to repair it. The coroner ruled that the poor road condition was directly responsible for the tragic incident that killed the cyclist who was raising money for Macmillan Cancer Support.

Real Madrid star Cristiano Ronaldo made headlines across Spanish sports papers on Monday after scoring five goals for the first time in his career, leading his team to a dominant 9-1 victory over Granada on Sunday. Ronaldo's five-goal haul included an impressive eight-minute hat-trick, helping Real Madrid keep their title hopes alive. Meanwhile, league leaders Barcelona maintained their four-point advantage at the top by defeating Celta Vigo 1-0 courtesy of Jeremy Mathieu's diving header.

Holland manager Guus Hiddink criticized his own supporters for booing Spain midfielder Andres Iniesta during Holland's 2-0 victory over Spain on Tuesday night, calling their behavior a "disgrace." Spain coach Vicente del Bosque fielded an experimental side, with Iniesta entering as a substitute in the 76th minute to a chorus of boos from the home fans at the Amsterdam Arena. The friendly win provided a much-needed morale boost for Hiddink, who had struggled in his previous seven matches as Holland's national coach.

Hillary Clinton's most trusted aide Huma Abedin was spotted enjoying a family day out at a Mexican restaurant in New York with her husband, disgraced former congressman Anthony Weiner, and their two-year-old son Jordan. This outing came just days after Abedin accompanied Clinton on a campaign stop at Chipotle in Iowa, which generated media attention when they failed to leave a tip. The family meal represents a brief moment of normalcy before the intensity of Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign fully begins.

The third annual Football Shirt Friday took place with celebrities including Rob Lee and Clare Balding donning football shirts to support The Bobby Moore Fund for Cancer Research UK in the fight against bowel cancer. The event honors the memory of 1966 World Cup-winning captain Bobby Moore, who died from bowel and liver cancer in 1993 at age 51. Fans were encouraged to wear any football shirt and donate to the cause during Bowel Cancer Awareness Month in April.

Quinton 'Rampage' Jackson returns to the UFC after two years with Bellator to face Fabio Maldonado at UFC 186 in Montreal, following a stressful legal battle that allowed him to compete. The former light-heavyweight champion and Maldonado faced off during the UFC 186 weigh-in on Friday, with their fight set as a catchweight bout at 215 pounds on Saturday night.

A pregnant woman and her partner were rescued from the water off Dungeness Point, Kent, after their trimaran vessel capsized yesterday. The alarm was raised when a member of the public spotted the couple in the water a mile from shore, prompting the dispatch of a rescue boat and coastguard response. The woman's partner heroically dived under the overturned vessel to retrieve an emergency flare to alert rescuers to their position, and both were successfully rescued and taken to hospital, cold but unharmed.

Cassandra C., a 17-year-old diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma in September, completed her chemotherapy treatment and left Connecticut Children's Medical Center on Monday after being held there since December under state custody. The teen had initially run away to avoid treatment, but a judge ordered her into state care to ensure she received the life-saving chemotherapy that doctors said gave her an 85% chance of survival. State officials said they were responsible to save Cassandra's life under these circumstances, and she is now healthy and moving forward with her life.

Pierre Collins was arrested Monday on suspicion of second-degree murder in the death of his 10-year-old son, Barway Edward Collins, whose body was found in the Mississippi River over the weekend. The Minnesota boy had been missing for nearly a month before his body was discovered by Boy Scout searchers on Saturday. Police say they have electronic evidence placing the 33-year-old father in the area where the child disappeared, and he had previously been identified as the primary suspect in what is now being treated as a homicide investigation.

Following Saturday's devastating magnitude-7.8 earthquake in Nepal that killed over 4,000 people, mass cremations are taking place along the Bagmati river in Kathmandu as families attempt to honor their dead according to Hindu tradition. The Pashupatinath Temple is receiving approximately 500 bodies per day compared to the usual 30, with volunteers helping to burn victims on pyres at overwhelmed cremation grounds throughout the city. The tremor, which was Nepal's worst in eight decades, has created shortages of wood needed for the thousands of pyres and limited space for conducting proper cremation rituals for the earthquake fatalities.

A horse named Cody got stuck in thick mud after wandering into a bog in Belvedere, south-east London on Friday afternoon. Animal rescue experts and fire crews spent more than an hour rescuing Cody from the watery ditch, working from 1:30pm until 2:55pm to bring the distressed animal to safety. Despite being covered in mud and shaken by the ordeal, Cody was otherwise unharmed and was taken back to the stables to be examined by a veterinarian.

Karen Bell, 42, from Hull, has been jailed for 12 months after blackmailing a man she met on the free dating website Plenty of Fish by threatening to post footage of their sex trysts online unless he paid her £55. Bell met the victim through the dating site and after engaging in sexual activity at her home, she claimed her son had secretly recorded their encounter and demanded money to prevent the footage from being published on Facebook and local websites. Despite the relatively small amount involved, the judge sentenced Bell to 12 months in prison after she pleaded guilty to blackmail, stating that such serious offenses warranted custodial sentences.

Following his inspired charity work, Chelsea forward Didier Drogba has been awarded the Barclays Spirit of the Game trophy for establishing the Didier Drogba Foundation in Africa, which aims to inspire the next generation of footballers in Africa. The 37-year-old, who scored against Leicester on Wednesday, created the foundation to provide educational and health support including school supplies and medical clinics in his hometown of Abidjan, Ivory Coast. The foundation recently raised £400,000 at a charity ball attended by Chelsea stars to help complete a medical clinic and finance mobile clinics for those too sick or poor to travel to the capital.

Senior Islamist party official Mohammad Qamaruzzaman was executed in Bangladesh after being convicted of crimes against humanity for his role in the 1971 independence war, where he headed a militia group that collaborated with Pakistani forces and was responsible for killing around 120 unarmed farmers. The execution took place after he refused to seek presidential clemency and the Supreme Court rejected his final appeal against the death sentence he received in May 2013. His supporters have denounced the execution and called for protests, while international organizations, including the UN, had urged against carrying out the death sentence, citing concerns about fair trial standards.

The article follows a journalist's exploration of Washington D.C. through the lens of the hit US TV series House of Cards, which features Francis Underwood played by Kevin Spacey, visiting political power spots like the Capital Grille where real senators hold meetings. The piece highlights how Washington's political culture mirrors the show's dark portrayal, while also showcasing the capital's tourist attractions including the Washington Monument and places frequented by US President Barack Obama like Ben's Chili Bowl restaurant. Despite facing competition from New York, Washington offers numerous public monuments and the world-renowned Smithsonian museums, making it a compelling destination that blends political intrigue with American history.

Eight-year-old Leo Bernal was released from the hospital on Friday, five days after being shot in the head by an armed intruder at his home in Culver City, California. The boy required surgery to remove the bullet from his skull and now has 23 staples holding his scalp together. Despite his traumatic ordeal, Leo is recovering well, though he remains scared to return home where the shooting occurred.

A suicide bomber detonated his explosives near a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker who was among those injured. The suicide attack hit the protesters around 10 a.m. local time as they were on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor in Khost city. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has so far claimed responsibility for the bombing.

The third World Happiness Report, released by the Sustainable Development Solutions Network for the United Nations, identifies the world's happiest countries based on factors like life expectancy, social support, generosity, and freedom to make life choices. The report stems from Bhutan's focus on "Gross National Happiness" and its Prime Minister's 2011 proposal to the United Nations for a World Happiness Day, which became an officially designated happy date. Switzerland topped the list, followed by Iceland (which jumped from ninth to second place), Denmark, Norway, Canada, Finland, Netherlands, Sweden, New Zealand, and Australia, with each country offering unique cultural attractions and natural wonders in their capital cities and beyond.

Four-year-old Austin West passed away last Saturday after drowning in a pool while chasing a bumblebee, with the shock of cold water and the boy's chronic asthma causing him to go under despite knowing how to swim. When Austin's grandfather Jeff West attempted to set up a GoFundMe campaign for funeral costs, he discovered scammers had already created fake fundraising pages using the child's name. The family has since established a legitimate campaign hoping to raise $10,000 for funeral expenses, though they've only collected $315 so far after the fraudulent pages were removed.

National Front founder Jean-Marie Le Pen, 86, pulled out of regional elections after his daughter Marine, the party's current leader, accused him of "political suicide" following his controversial remarks calling the Holocaust "a detail of history" and praising Marshal Petain. Le Pen announced he wants his granddaughter Marion Marechal-Le Pen, 25, to replace him as a candidate, which she confirmed she would pursue. The family rift has deepened the divisions within France's far-right National Front party ahead of the December regional elections.

Andrew Getty, the 47-year-old grandson of oil tycoon J. Paul Getty, died Tuesday afternoon in his Los Angeles home under circumstances that appear to be from natural causes or an accident. His parents Ann and Gordon Getty requested privacy during this difficult time, while investigators found medication at the scene and are working with a female friend who was present at the home. Gordon Getty, Andrew's father and son of the late oil magnate J. Paul Getty, is worth $2.1 billion according to Forbes.

Getty Images photographer Matthew Lewis won the Wisden–MCC Cricket Photograph of the Year 2014 with his stunning image of West Indies player Dwayne Bravo taking a spectacular full-length catch during the ICC World Twenty20 competition in Bangladesh. The short-list featured diverse cricket photographs from around the world, including professional matches like Twenty20 International games and dramatic moments such as England bowler Stuart Broad being hit in the face and England batsman Michael Carberry's bat snapping in two during his defensive stroke. The collection showcased both elite cricket action and amateur players, demonstrating the global reach of the sport from professional stadiums to children playing on rubbish tips.

A new Reddit thread asking users to submit the most horrendous baby names they have ever come across attracted more than 18,000 comments in just 24 hours. FEMAIL compiled the worst examples from the submissions, including shocking names like "Orgasm" (submitted by the daughter of a midwife), "Obamaniqua," "I'munique," "Like" (named after Facebook), and "Britney Shakira Beyonce." The thread revealed numerous examples of questionable parental naming decisions, from creative spellings like "Airwrecker" (for Erica) to bizarre combinations and inappropriate choices.

The number of hayfever sufferers in the UK is predicted to reach 20 million this summer, up a third from last year, with five million people expected to experience symptoms for the first time due to warmer weather and high pollen counts that can trigger hayfever in previously unaffected individuals. The average hayfever season is becoming longer, now typically stretching from April to the end of August, with symptoms including streaming eyes, sneezing, and throat irritation caused by allergens in the air. Experts recommend that sufferers prepare by stocking up on antihistamines and other treatments to manage their symptoms during the extended pollen season.

Raheem Sterling has turned down a new £100,000-per-week contract offer from Liverpool and postponed talks until the summer, with his current £35,000-a-week deal having two years remaining. The article traces Sterling's remarkable journey from a tough upbringing in Jamaica and north London to becoming a key player for Liverpool, training at their Melwood headquarters under manager Brendan Rodgers. Liverpool manager Rodgers now faces the challenge of convincing the 20-year-old England international to commit his future to the club, as Sterling has demonstrated his understanding of his market value and negotiating position.

TV star Karren Brady, who is also an Apprentice judge and the government's small business ambassador, helped David Cameron announce 16,000 new apprenticeships at companies including Costa, Morrisons, and the National Grid, though she ended up relegated to helping the Prime Minister with his jacket during the event. Cameron highlighted that the government has already created 2.2 million apprenticeships since 2010 and pledged to create 3 million more high quality apprenticeships over the next five years if the Conservatives win the election. The announcement was made at a National Grid training centre in Newark, Nottinghamshire, as part of Cameron's campaign to make apprenticeships "level-pegging" with university degrees.

Extreme skier Oscar Hübinette performed a death-defying ski run down the icy slopes of the still erupting Tolbachik volcano on Russia's Kamchatka Peninsula, while his photographer friend Fredrik Schenholm captured the dramatic scene with the 12,000-foot tall volcano's burning hot lava bubbling furiously behind him. The Tolbachik volcano, which suddenly erupted in November 2012 after lying dormant since 1976, created extreme temperature contrasts with air temperatures around -25°C while lava temperatures reached over 1,000°C. This dangerous stunt took place on one of 160 volcanoes in the region, with 29 still active, as the photographer finally achieved his five-year goal of capturing a skier against an active volcanic eruption.

Newcastle head coach John Carver says he will use a "whip" to motivate his players ahead of Sunday's Tyne-Wear derby against Sunderland, after admitting that Sunderland have out-worked his team and wanted victory more in their last four matches. The Magpies have lost the last four games against their North-East rivals, and Carver is determined to end this poor run in what will be a crucial Premier League campaign fixture. Carver acknowledged that Sunderland's greater desire for victory has been the difference in recent derbies, but he's committed to ensuring his players are properly motivated to beat Sunderland this time.

The Scottish Football Association failed in their attempt to increase the punishment handed to Rangers goalkeeper Steve Simonsen for breaching betting laws, after he admitted to breaking the SFA's zero-tolerance gambling rules by betting on 50 games over a year. Simonsen originally received a one-game suspension, but the SFA's appeal to impose a harsher penalty was rejected by an appellate tribunal. The SFA compliance officer had argued that Simonsen's punishment was "unduly lenient," but his legal team confirmed that the appeal against the Steve Simonsen suspension failed.

Newcastle keeper Tim Krul congratulated Sunderland striker Jermain Defoe at half-time after Defoe scored a brilliant goal in their derby match, drawing criticism from pundits like Jamie Carragher who lambasted Krul for showing inappropriate sportsmanship during the game. The author defends Krul's gesture by comparing it to the famous 1970 embrace between Bobby Moore and Pele, arguing that football should still have room for acknowledging great technique and acts of sportsmanship, even during intense rivalries. The article suggests that those who commend Krul for his decent behavior represent the better values of football, while questioning whether the criticism would have been as harsh if an English player had made the same gesture.

President Barack Obama and his wife Michelle paid more than $93,000 in federal taxes last year on an adjusted gross income of over $477,000, according to tax returns released Friday by the White House. The Obamas lowered their 2014 tax bill through nearly $160,000 in itemized deductions, including $70,712 in charitable donations to 33 different charities, donating nearly 15 percent of their income. The 38-page document includes the couple's Illinois state income tax return, showing the president made nearly $395,000 in wages plus additional income from book sales.

Saracens have announced that 31-year-old Argentina centre Marcelo Bosch has signed a contract extension with the club. Bosch was the hero of Saracens' European Champions Cup quarter-final victory over Racing Metro, kicking a last-minute penalty to secure a 12-11 win in Paris. The international centre, who joined Saracens in 2013, has been praised by the club's rugby director for his hard work and improvement since arriving at the club.

High-powered human rights lawyer Amal Clooney held a press conference in Washington DC today calling for the release of imprisoned former president of Maldives Mohamed Nasheed. Nasheed, the first democratically elected leader of the Indian Ocean archipelago, was sentenced to 13 years in prison last month under anti-terror laws in what human rights activists describe as a politically motivated "sham trial." Clooney, who is part of Nasheed's international legal team, said she will not rest until he walks free and plans to appeal to the US government to pressure the Maldives for his release.

Paula Radcliffe, who has won the London Marathon three times and set a world record in 2003, will run Sunday's 26.2 mile race with the masses rather than the elite field as she battles back from injury that prevented her from competing in the London 2012 Olympics. After undergoing surgery in 2012 for a foot problem that doctors feared might end her running career permanently, the 41-year-old mother-of-two is delighted to participate in what she calls a "really special" final marathon, despite being unfit and unprepared compared to her previous elite performances.

Aaron Ramsey has scored 25 goals for Arsenal since last season, including a crucial extra-time winner in the 2014 FA Cup final against Hull City that ended Arsenal's nine-year trophy drought. Ramsey recently dedicated his goal against Burnley to his late grandmother Eileen, who passed away a few weeks ago and had been a major source of support throughout his career. Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger's team is now preparing for another FA Cup semi-final against Reading, with Ramsey expressing optimism about the club's improved form and potential for more silverware.

Teenager Lily Sharp from the UK decided to prank her mother by faking her own kidnapping through text messages, beginning with an innocent message about a decorator before escalating to demands for £4,000 ransom. Lily's mother tried to stay calm but became increasingly panicked and called the police before Lily revealed it was all a trick. Although her mother was not amused by the elaborate prank, Lily's Twitter post of the conversation received thousands of retweets and favorites.

More than 10,000 migrants have arrived at Italy's islands from North Africa since last weekend alone, part of a massive influx that saw over 140,000 migrants arrive in 2011 after Gadhafi's overthrow removed controls on migrant flows from Libya. Italy decided to launch a major search-and-rescue program called Mare Nostrum in 2013 to rescue migrants after a tragic boat accident, but ended it in 2014 due to EU criticism that it was encouraging migrants to make the dangerous Mediterranean crossing. The EU's replacement mission, Frontex's operations, has a much smaller budget and limited resources, leading to concerns about inadequate response to the ongoing migration crisis.

Sam Allardyce responded to West Ham co-owner David Sullivan's criticism that the team's last 12 games have been "exceedingly disappointing" by telling Sullivan not to judge the season based solely on their 2015 results. Despite West Ham picking up only 11 points since the turn of the year, Allardyce feels the season as a whole has been a success, pointing out that the club has already surpassed last year's point total with seven games remaining.

A study by Lancashire's Edge Hill University found a direct link between anxiety ahead of taking exams and poor performance during the school exam season, with worried students more likely to achieve lower grades. To help combat this, education expert Michael Ribton says parents should actively engage in their children's revision by creating structured timetables and using techniques like "Spaced Learning sessions," which consist of three identical learning inputs separated by brain gym activities. Student Fatima Sharif, who is currently revising for her A Levels, emphasizes the importance of setting goals and using revision aids like flashcards to stay motivated during the stressful exam period.

Scotland international centre Matt Scott has been ruled out for the rest of the season after requiring a second shoulder surgery in a year, dealing a major blow to Edinburgh's European Challenge Cup semi-final hopes and making him doubtful for September's World Cup. Scott picked up his latest injury while on Scotland duty against Ireland in the final Six Nations match, and his absence could leave Scotland coach Vern Cotter with a significant gap to fill at centre for the World Cup. Edinburgh will now face Newport Gwent Dragons in Friday's semi-final without their key player, relying on less experienced centre options for the remainder of their European campaign.

The divorce between chef Bobby Flay, 50, and actress Stephanie March has become contentious after Page Six claimed Flay has been having a three-year affair with his 28-year-old assistant Elyse Tirrell, which allegedly led to the breakdown of their marriage. Flay filed for divorce from March in April, citing that their 10-year marriage has "irretrievably broken down," while March is now challenging their prenuptial agreement. Flay's business partner has denied the affair allegations, and the couple appears headed for an increasingly bitter legal battle.

Emma Louise Connolly, girlfriend of Made in Chelsea's Ollie Proudlock, models Ann Summers' first bridal wear lingerie collection, which features underwear and loungewear in ivory and nude palettes priced between £14 and £85. The collection includes items like cut-out bras, nightgowns, and silk and lace sets designed for brides. Emma, who started dating Ollie in October last year, serves as the current face of Ann Summers for this debut bridal line from the brand known for mainstream erotic lingerie.

The UN's World Meteorological Organization's Hurricane Committee deemed the name Isis inappropriate for future Pacific hurricane names in 2016 and removed it from the official list, replacing it with Ivette, due to its association with the ISIS militant group that stands accused of committing brutal atrocities against civilians. The committee also retired the name Odile at Mexico's request after the destructive hurricane hit Baja California in 2014, during a season that saw 14 out of 20 tropical storms become hurricanes, making the hurricane total the second highest on record for the basin.

Game of Thrones fans leaked the first four episodes of the show's fifth season online before the official premiere, with the episodes appearing on torrent sites Saturday night and being downloaded over 550,000 times by Sunday morning. HBO confirmed that the leaked episodes originated from within an approved group that received advance review copies, representing nearly half of the upcoming season being released early through piracy.

Nicola Sturgeon today launched her party's manifesto setting out demands as the price for propping up a Labour government, but a new ComRes poll for ITV News reveals 54 percent want her kept out of the next UK government and 59 percent want the SNP as a whole to play no part in running the country. While polls in Scotland put the SNP on course to make huge gains and potentially force Labour into a coalition arrangement, Prime Minister David Cameron warned that an SNP-Labour deal would be a "match made in hell" for the British economy. The SNP got the biggest thumbs down among potential coalition partners, making them by far the least popular option for sharing power despite their likely kingmaker role in a hung parliament.

Jeremy Scott's spring/summer 2015 Moschino collection sent human Barbie dolls down the runway in Milan wearing Barbie doll inspired dresses to Aqua's "Barbie Girl," nearly breaking the internet. To test whether the Barbie-inspired Moschino collection works in real life, journalist Olivia Phillips took to the streets of Dubai dressed like the iconic doll, complete with heavy eyelashes and pink leather outfits. Her experiment revealed that the look generated universal smiles, helpful strangers, and social media attention, though she admits to becoming "Insanity Barbie" at times, concluding that Scott's whimsical designs fit perfectly with our Instagram-filtered existence.

Chelsea are planning a victory parade for May 25 should they win the Premier League title, with Jose Mourinho's side currently nine points clear at the top of the table ahead of their match against Arsenal at the Emirates. A letter from Hammersmith and Fulham council outlines Chelsea's plan for the possible Chelsea Football Club parade, which would take place around Stamford Bridge if the club wins the Premier League. The parade would be funded by Chelsea and follow a specific route through Fulham, lasting approximately one hour from 12pm to 1pm.

Jack Henry Doshay, 22, the son of a prominent San Diego businessman, was arrested last week and appeared in court on Friday after allegedly attempting to kidnap a 7-year-old girl from Skyline Elementary School in Solana Beach. Prosecutors are accusing Doshay of grabbing the girl and trying to cover her mouth with packing tape before teachers and parents heard her screams and he fled the scene. Doshay was allegedly arrested at a residential facility where he was seeking treatment for depression, and he pleaded not guilty to charges including kidnapping and child cruelty.

Sri Lanka's sports minister has requested that Kumar Sangakkara reconsider his decision to retire from limited overs cricket and continue playing for another year, following Sangakkara's farewell after the team's World Cup quarter-final defeat. Sangakkara, who scored four successive centuries during the Cricket World Cup before bowing out, had announced his retirement from one-day cricket on March 18, expressing disappointment with the quarter-final loss but satisfaction that Sri Lanka was in a better position than when he joined in 2000.

Nicola Sturgeon declared yesterday that raising the retirement age is unfair on Scottish pensioners because they die younger than those in other parts of the UK, demanding the retirement age be frozen in a move that would cost billions of pounds. The SNP leader argued the rising retirement age particularly disadvantages pensioners in Scotland due to lower life expectancy, and also called for the flat rate pension to increase from £113 to at least £160 per week. Her proposals would take Scotland's specific circumstances into account but raise concerns about creating a more expensive pension system across the UK that would primarily benefit Scotland.

Kentucky judge Olu Stevens is facing calls to be sacked after he criticized a couple's victim impact statements during the sentencing of Gregory Wallace, who robbed their home and held their 3-year-old daughter at gunpoint. The couple called for Wallace to be sent to prison and stated their daughter was now "in constant fear of black men," but Stevens accused the parents of fostering racist stereotypes and granted Wallace probation instead. Judge Stevens said Wallace deserved the opportunity to redeem himself, though he claimed his criticism of the family's statements had no bearing on his sentencing decision.

Mysterious cardboard signs with messages of love and apology, written in black marker pen, have appeared throughout the Surrey village of Milford, sparking speculation about the unknown author's identity and the reason behind their public declaration. While most people say sorry with flowers, chocolates, or romantic dinners, this lovelorn individual chose to plaster heartfelt messages like "please forgive me" and "I love you" on lampposts and street signs across the village. This public apology follows a similar incident in Manchester where a man was spotted wearing a sandwich board to show he was exceedingly sorry to his partner.

Five Chinese feminist activists have been detained by police for more than a month facing charges of "picking quarrels and provoking trouble" after being arrested before International Women's Day while preparing to distribute leaflets about sexual harassment. The women - Li Tingting, Wei Tingting, Wang Man, Zheng Churan, and Wu Rongrong - face up to five years in jail if formally charged, prompting their families to issue a plea to authorities for their release. The case has drawn international criticism, with the U.S. and other countries calling for the women's freedom, while China's authorities defend their actions as upholding the rule of law.

More than 10,000 Australians and New Zealanders gathered on Turkey's Gallipoli peninsula for an Anzac Day dawn service to mark the 100th anniversary of the bloody Gallipoli landings that began on April 25, 1915. The formal ceremony honored the diggers who fought and fell during the eight-month Gallipoli land campaign, with Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott, New Zealand Prime Minister John Key, Prince Charles, and Prince Harry among those in attendance. During the commemorative service, leaders spoke of how the Anzacs who landed at Gallipoli became the founding heroes of modern Australia and New Zealand, with about 130,000 men dying during the campaign including thousands of Australian and New Zealand soldiers.

Fernando Torres scored his first ever league own goal as Atletico Madrid drew 2-2 with Malaga in La Liga on Saturday, inadvertently heading a corner into his own net to pull Malaga back into the game before half-time. Antoine Griezmann scored twice for Atletico to help salvage the draw, while Torres continues to struggle for goals since his January return to the Vicente Calderon with just four goals total. The result leaves Diego Simeone's side in third place in the league table.

Danny Lennon's interim appointment as Scotland Under 21 coach has officially ended, with reports suggesting he will be named as Alloa Athletic boss on Tuesday. The former St Mirren manager took charge of the Scotland Under 21 side for one match, securing a 2-1 victory against Hungary last month. The Scottish FA thanked Lennon for his professionalism and wished him the best of luck for his future challenges, while confirming that a permanent appointment for the Under 21 coach role will be made in due course.

The wreckage of a bus and train used to film the iconic crash scene from 1993's "The Fugitive," where Harrison Ford's character escaped from a prison transport moments before it was struck by an oncoming train, now lies abandoned in the Great Smoky Mountains in North Carolina. Director Andrew Davis used 13 cameras to capture the $1.5 million sequence, with three cameras destroyed in the process, creating one of Hollywood's most memorable action scenes using real vehicles rather than CGI. The trashed prison bus and train have become a popular tourist attraction over two decades after filming, still bearing the "Illinois Dept. of Corrections" lettering from the movie.

Greg Gibbins, a 28-year-old rugby player, died after suffering an unprovoked knife attack outside a pizza store on Easter Monday, going into cardiac arrest and later dying in hospital. A 25-year-old friend who tried to help Gibbins also suffered stab wounds during the confrontation and required surgery. Police have charged a 20-year-old man with murder in connection with what they describe as a spontaneous attack that may have been related to an earlier incident where Gibbins had helped a woman being harassed.

A new Reddit thread asked users to share their experiences with mail-order brides, focusing on brides from Russia and the Philippines, and has garnered over 10,000 comments revealing surprising insights about these relationships. Many men reported that while their foreign brides would offer sex, cook, and clean, the relationships often lacked genuine emotional connection and sexual chemistry, with some describing their wives as treating intimacy like a chore.
