The discussion highlighted both the booming nature of the mail-order bride industry, which can cost between $10,000-$50,000, and the complex dynamics between men who struggle socially and women seeking better lives abroad.

Manchester City goalkeeper Joe Hart described Sunday's 4-2 derby defeat to Manchester United as "one of my worst in a Man City shirt," acknowledging that City's bid to retain their Premier League title was over. Hart was unable to keep out goals from United's Ashley Young, Marouane Fellaini, Juan Mata and Chris Smalling, leaving City four points behind their rivals United and 12 points behind league leaders Chelsea. The England number one admitted United "know what they are doing" and "took their chances" after City had initially taken the lead in the dominant early stages.

A Northern Territory mother and labourer, Noeleen Foster, was shocked when she spotted a phallic-shaped cloud during her work break last week above Zuccoli, 25km southeast of Darwin. Ms Foster, who loves photographing clouds, said she couldn't believe her eyes when she captured the X-rated cloud formation and noted that "even mother nature has a sense of humour." This isn't the first famous phallic cloud to make headlines, as a similar suggestively shaped cloud was photographed in Derbyshire, England last year.

Loren Mathieson filmed her pet Boston Terrier, Gizmo, performing a gravity-defying stunt of paw-stand walking one day at home after he put on new booties. Footage shows Gizmo taking steps forward before planting his front feet and launching his back legs vertically in the air, then walking forward on his front paws until he reaches laughing Mathieson on the floor. Mathieson said Gizmo performed the circus-like trick because he was unsure how to walk in his new black boots, and like Mathieson, many of the 80,000+ viewers were left smiling at the amusing display.

Porto, the only undefeated side in the Champions League, will face Bayern Munich in their quarter-final first leg at Dragao on Wednesday night, with Porto manager Julen Lopetegui set to go up against his former Barcelona teammate Pep Guardiola. However, Julen Lopetegui has warned that despite Porto's impressive record, the team still has room for improvement and "hasn't stopped growing" since adding many new players last summer. The match will pit the two most prolific scoring sides in the tournament against each other, with Porto having scored 24 goals while conceding only five in their Champions League campaign.

Nine-year-old Frankie Franz successfully emulated Barcelona star Martin Montoya by scoring an audacious 27-yard goal into a basketball hoop after watching the Spanish right-back pull off the trick shot in a video recorded at Barcelona's training ground. Schoolboy Frankie decided to attempt the challenging feat in his garden and amazingly succeeded on his first try, then repeated it again immediately after. The talented young academy player with Dagenham and Redbridge Football Club dreams of one day turning out for Real Madrid or Barcelona.

Financially-troubled CSKA Sofia's Latvian goalkeeper Maksims Uvarenko has not been paid for three months and has had to ask his parents to send him money to pay his rent. Despite the club's severe financial problems and unpaid wages, Uvarenko remains impressed by CSKA's unique and passionate fans who provide tremendous support at the team's home ground, the Bulgarian Army Stadium. The debt-ridden Bulgarian club is struggling to avoid expulsion from the top division due to mounting debts, though supporters have been making donations to help keep the historic 31-time champions afloat.

Pete Bennett revealed on the Jeremy Kyle show that he squandered his £100,000 Big Brother prize money on ketamine and is now homeless, demonstrating how fame can break Big Brother contestants' lives rather than make them. The article traces the varied fates of Big Brother winners from different seasons, including contestants who entered at ages 22, 23, 24, and 32, with some like transgender chef Luke finding success while others struggled. Notable winners mentioned include escort Helen Wood from Bolton, who gained fame after a threesome with Wayne Rooney before winning Big Brother, and several contestants who appeared on Ultimate Big Brother.

Crisis-hit club Parma pulled off the biggest surprise of the Serie A season by beating runaway leaders Juventus 1-0, with Jose Mauri scoring the only goal of the game on the hour mark. Despite being declared bankrupt last month and having unpaid players all season, Parma inflicted only the second league defeat of the campaign on Massimiliano Allegri's side. The victory was secured through Mauri's decisive strike and excellent goalkeeping from Antonio Mirante, though Parma remains in last place, 10 points from safety.

Photographer Simon Brann Thorpe created the "Toy Soldiers" project in the desert of Western Sahara, where he posed real soldiers from the Polisario Front to look like green plastic toy figurines against the harsh landscape backdrop. Thorpe would work with military commanders to position 50-60 soldiers at a time, then climb sandy mountains to capture wide-angle images that appear to contain toy soldiers but actually feature real troops from the long-disputed region's ongoing conflict. Thorpe hopes his striking images will raise questions about how people consume war imagery in an age of diminishing attention spans and media oversaturation.

A seven-year-old boy was raped and set on fire by two youths in Bhiwandi, a suburb of Mumbai, when he went to buy food, leaving him with 30 percent burns to his body. The incident is being investigated by police, who have registered a case under multiple sections including attempt to murder and sodomy. Police are working to identify and catch the accused while the boy receives treatment at Thane Civil Hospital.

Jurgen Klopp confirmed on Wednesday that he will leave Borussia Dortmund at the end of the season after seven years in charge, putting several Premier League clubs on alert. The 47-year-old manager stated that "Borussia Dortmund actually needs a change" and that he questioned whether he was still the right coach for the club, though he insisted he has had no contact with other clubs yet. Klopp's departure has made him the bookmakers' favorite to replace Manuel Pellegrini at Manchester City, while other top European clubs including Bayern Munich are also expected to show interest in the highly-rated German manager.

Sean McCabe, a 30-year-old father of three from Wales, was diagnosed with stage four Hodgkin Lymphoma and given just two months to live, prompting him to plan his own funeral at St David's Church and write goodbye letters to his children. In an extraordinary turn of events, his cancer went into remission, and he has now rebooked the same church for his wedding to his fiancée Lisa Williams. The couple, who have been together for 12 years, are set to marry in July 2025, surrounded by their three children who will serve as page boy and flower girls.

Two young brothers, ages 8 and 13, died after their family's car plunged into a Los Angeles harbor, with the 13-year-old pulled dead from the water at the scene and his younger brother dying a day later in the hospital. Their parents survived the accident and are in stable condition at the hospital. The cause of the incident remains unknown as authorities continue to investigate whether it was accidental or intentional.

Qatar's investment arm has significantly expanded its London real estate holdings by purchasing a 64% stake in hotel company Coroin, which owns luxury hotels Claridge's, The Berkeley, and The Connaught, in a deal reportedly worth up to £1.6 billion. This acquisition adds to Qatar's impressive property portfolio that already includes iconic London landmarks such as The Shard, Harrods, and Canary Wharf, with Constellation Hotels also recently buying the London Park Lane Hotel. Through various entities including Qatar Holding and Qatari Diar Real Estate Investment, the Gulf state has become one of London's largest property owners, owning more real estate than the Crown Estate.

Three children - one-year-old Bol and four-year-old twins Madit and Anger - died when their Sudanese mother, 35-year-old Akon Guode, crashed a Toyota Kluger into a lake at Wyndham Vale near Melbourne on Wednesday afternoon. The children's mother has been released from police custody after being interviewed as part of the ongoing homicide investigation, while the children's father has defended her, saying she is a "good mother" and innocent. A fifth child, five-year-old Awel, survived the crash and remains in serious condition at Royal Children's Hospital.

Scientists claim that computer keyboards could be a powerful new tool in battling Parkinson's disease, as researchers in Massachusetts believe a person's keystrokes may reveal crucial information about their motor skills. The researchers have developed an algorithm that can detect early Parkinson's disease by analyzing typing patterns, including how sleep deprivation impairs motor skills, potentially diagnosing the condition much earlier than the current timeline of five to 10 years after disease onset. This breakthrough could also be applied to evaluate patients with other diseases that affect motor function, with the team now working on smartphone apps to gather similar data from mobile devices.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers held a press conference previewing Saturday's match against Arsenal, but the focus shifted to Raheem Sterling's contract situation after the 20-year-old gave an unauthorized BBC interview stating he wasn't ready to sign a new £100,000-a-week deal and was "flattered" by Arsenal's interest. Despite Sterling edging closer towards an exit from Liverpool, Rodgers insisted the player would not be leaving in the summer, emphasizing that Liverpool is "one of the superpowers of football" and doesn't need to sell its best players. The press conference came after Liverpool's disappointing 2-1 loss to Manchester United that left them five points behind their rivals.

Stoke boss Mark Hughes has dismissed reports linking goalkeeper Asmir Begovic with a summer move to Spanish giants Real Madrid, saying he would "take that one with a pinch of salt" and expressing optimism that the Premier League keeper will sign a new contract with the club. Hughes said talks with Begovic's representatives are scheduled for the coming weeks, while 10th-placed Stoke continues working toward bettering their record Premier League points total after recently drawing 1-1 with West Ham.

Aston Villa secured a crucial 1-0 victory over Tottenham at White Hart Lane, with Christian Benteke scoring the winning goal with a header in the 35th minute to give Villa a major boost in their Premier League survival fight. The match featured key performances from Villa's Tom Cleverley in midfield and strong defensive play to contain Tottenham striker Harry Kane, while Villa manager Tim Sherwood celebrated ecstatically against his former club. Despite playing the final minutes with 10 men after Carlos Sanchez's red card, Villa held on for three vital points that significantly improved their chances of avoiding relegation.

Gerard T. "The Frenchman" Ouimette, a 75-year-old former mob enforcer with ties to New England crime boss Raymond Patriarca, died in his sleep at a federal prison in Butner, North Carolina, after being diagnosed with lung cancer. Ouimette was convicted of extortion in 1996 and sentenced to life in prison without parole under the federal "three strikes" provision, with authorities calling him responsible for up to eight gangland-style murders and control of a criminal network involved in gambling, loansharking, and extortion. His nephew Kevin Ouimette Lynch confirmed that Ouimette passed away on Sunday, ending a criminal career that spanned decades and included over 10 convictions.

After helping Sale Sharks to a 23-6 victory against Gloucester where Cipriani contributed 13 points from the boot, Danny Cipriani took advantage of a rare free weekend to jet off to Dubai for a short break. Steve Diamond's side faces four crucial final rounds of Aviva Premiership action against London Irish, Harlequins, Newcastle and Exeter as they look to secure a top-six finish and European Champions Cup qualification. The holiday break serves as perfect preparation for Cipriani, who has been integral to Sale's improved form this season and will return to action on April 12 against London Irish.

Owen Farrell, the Saracens and England international fly-half, hopes to return for Saracens' European Champions Cup semi-final against Clermont Auvergne on April 18 after being sidelined since suffering a knee ligament injury against the same opponents in January. Farrell missed the entire RBS 6 Nations campaign due to the injury, but reports his knee is feeling good after participating in full training activities. Saracens return to action this weekend against Leicester before facing Clermont in the semi-final seven days later.

North Charleston Police Officer Michael Slager, 33, is charged with murder after opening fire on Walter Scott, 50, during a traffic stop over a broken tail light in North Charleston, South Carolina. Slager is being held in isolation at Charleston County jail for his safety, as officials believe he would not survive in general population. Court records revealed that no warrant had been issued for Walter Scott's arrest at the time of the incident, despite him being $7,500 behind on child support payments.

Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino has confidence that goalkeeper Michel Vorm can overcome his Capital One Cup final disappointment and serve as an effective replacement for Hugo Lloris when they face Burnley on Sunday. With France international Lloris sidelined due to a knee injury, Dutchman Vorm will step in as goalkeeper at Turf Moor. Pochettino praised Vorm's professionalism and character, expressing no doubts about his ability to perform despite being left out of the League Cup final.

Uber customer Jaimie Hessel was shocked to receive a $16,000 bill for a 35-minute nightmare car ride where her UberX driver was distracted, on his phone, and drove dangerously through New York traffic. After Hessel complained about the initial $56 charge and poor service, Uber mistakenly sent her a billing statement saying she owed over $16,000, though the company later said this was a clerical error and she was never actually charged the outrageous amount. Uber has since apologized and provided a full refund, but Hessel says she no longer trusts the service.

A cloud formation resembling the global Wi-Fi symbol appeared recently in the sky above Xiangtan city in Hunan Province, central China, creating what locals are calling the world's largest "Wi-Fi cloud." The unusual formation was spotted by a student from Hunan University of Science and Technology last Friday evening and has since gone viral on Chinese social media, with users joking about the giant wifi cloud's coverage and password. The phenomenon has drawn comparisons to other unusual cloud formations previously seen across China, sparking humorous speculation about "God's router" providing wifi coverage from the sky.

Arsenal midfielder Jack Wilshere met Brazil legend Pele at the launch party of 10Ten Talent, where he had the opportunity to interview the three-time World Cup winner who scored 77 goals in 92 games for Brazil. Pele described Brazil's 7-1 World Cup semi-final defeat to Germany as a "disaster" that nobody could explain, saying "Brazil could lose, 1-0 or 2-0, but to lose 7-1... it's something only God can explain." Wilshere tweeted about the meeting, sharing photos and expressing his excitement about interviewing the legendary Pele.

Italy is experiencing a surge of desperate migrants from Africa and the Middle East, with the Italian coast guard rescuing 8,480 migrants from Friday to Monday alone after receiving SOS calls from 20 boats in distress. Save the Children reports that a ship carrying 550 people may have capsized in the Mediterranean, potentially leaving 400 migrants missing, though the Italian coast guard has not yet found evidence to confirm this incident. Italy has registered over 10,000 migrants arriving in the first three months of 2015, highlighting the ongoing crisis of migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean seeking refuge in Europe.

Saracens flanker Jacques Burger has been cited for alleged foul play during last Sunday's European Champions Cup quarter-final game against Racing Metro, which Saracens won 12-11. European Professional Club Rugby said that Burger is alleged to have struck Racing scrum-half Maxime Machenaud midway through the match, with the complaint made by match citing commissioner Eugene Ryan. The 31-year-old Namibia international will face a disciplinary hearing on Thursday and could face a ban ranging from two weeks to 52 weeks depending on the severity of the offense.

Chile's Calbuco Volcano erupted for the third time since last week on Thursday, prompting the evacuation of about 1,500 people and maintaining a 20-kilometer exclusion zone around the crater. The explosion produced an extensive ash plume that has spread across the region and into Argentina, with volcanic debris accumulating up to 2 feet deep in some areas. While Thursday's eruption was described as spectacular, it was reportedly less severe than the previous two eruptions that occurred on April 22 and 23.

Six people have been arrested at Dover on suspicion of Syria-related terrorism offences, West Midlands Police said, with four men from Birmingham in their 20s, plus a 26-year-old man and 23-year-old woman of no fixed abode detained in the port's departure zone. The suspects are currently being questioned at a West Midlands police station while searches are taking place at Birmingham addresses as part of an ongoing investigation. Police confirmed the suspects posed no immediate public safety risk and were not a family group.

Philadelphia Union secured their first MLS victory of the season with a dramatic 2-1 win over New York City FC, with Vincent Nogueira scoring the winner in stoppage time after NYC goalkeeper Josh Saunders collided with a Philadelphia player in the box. Former Spain international David Villa had equalized for City in the 55th minute, scoring from close range after reacting first to a rebound. In other MLS action, Houston Dynamo ended their scoring drought by defeating Montreal Impact 3-0, with Giles Barnes opening the scoring in the 15th minute.

A church preacher, Eric Isaiah Adusah, is being held on suspicion of murdering his pregnant British wife, Charmain Adusah, 41, in a hotel room in Ghana. Hotel staff discovered Charmain's body face down in a bath after she had been lying there for four days, while her husband had allegedly left the hotel hurriedly on the day she is believed to have died. The self-proclaimed prophet and evangelical preacher is now in police custody in Ghana facing murder charges for his three-month pregnant wife's death.

Ethan Czahor, a former aide to Jeb Bush who was fired after his offensive tweets became public, has launched an app called 'Clear' that removes social media posts that might cause problems with current or future employers. The app uses IBM's Watson supercomputer to analyze users' tweets and assigns them a safety rating between 0 and 100, helping people scrub embarrassing messages before they can damage their careers. Czahor developed the app after experiencing firsthand how old posts made years ago can resurface and cause professional consequences.

Justin Rose arrived at Augusta National struggling with form, having missed the cut in three of his previous five tournaments, but finished second at the Masters with a 14-under-par total that has only been bettered six times in Masters history. Rose wants to follow Rory McIlroy's example from last year, when McIlroy had a dominant summer winning streak, and hopes his strong Masters performance will kickstart his season for the upcoming major tournaments from April to September.

An unidentified college student avoided punishment for drinking underage at the Texas-based Chilifest music festival after three police officers who caught her allowed her to play a game of Rock Paper Scissors to determine her fate. The student won by choosing "rock" while one of the officers chose "scissors," and the entire incident was captured on video and posted to Vine, where it received over 500,000 views. The three officers involved then walked away without issuing any citation, surprising many who noted that police at this festival are typically strict about underage drinking violations.

Victoria Police are desperately searching for 14-year-old Sally Gordon-Smith, who was last seen leaving her school in Keilor East around 3pm on Friday afternoon. Police confirmed she was still missing early on Saturday morning and expressed concern for her wellbeing due to her age. Authorities have appealed for anyone who has seen Ms Gordon-Smith to immediately contact police.

Crystal Palace manager Alan Pardew insists he is not interested in raiding his former club Newcastle for goalkeeper Tim Krul and is disappointed by reports linking him to such a move. Pardew maintains he is happy with current Eagles No 1 goalkeeper Julian Speroni and denies any contact with Newcastle, Krul, or his agent regarding a potential transfer. The manager is planning a busy summer in the transfer market but states that a goalkeeper is not currently a priority position for Palace.

British photographer John Daniels, 61, from Surrey, has captured adorable images in a picture-perfect photo shoot featuring puppies, kittens, and other little animals using clean white studio backgrounds and comedy props. The puppy photographer John Daniels experiments with unusual animal pairings, such as puppies with ducks and chicks, creating heart-warming shots where cats and dogs appear to be best friends. Many of the animals come back to the studio for multiple shoots and seem to remember what to do, with Daniels noting that timing is crucial to get each animal at the right age for his charming photographs.

Hilary Border, 54, stole £20,000 from her 83-year-old dementia-stricken mother Dorothy while having power of attorney over her affairs, using the money for herself instead of paying care home fees. Care home staff tried to contact Border about an outstanding debt before reporting her to police when payments for her mother's care became late or stopped entirely. Border was sentenced to 16 months in prison, suspended for two years, after pleading guilty to fraud at Nottingham Crown Court.

David Suchet, best known for playing Poirot, is fighting for better NHS treatment for his grandson Todd, who was diagnosed with the rare genetic illness Tuberous Sclerosis Complex shortly after birth. Todd, the son of Suchet's son Robert, has the incurable genetic disease that can cause tumors, epilepsy, and learning difficulties, but Suchet criticizes NHS "disorganization" for blocking access to potentially helpful medications. The actor has launched a #Fight4Treatment campaign and filmed a video urging people to contact MPs about improving access to rare disease treatments.

Yorkshire have signed India international Cheteshwar Pujara until the end of May after cancelling the contract of Younis Khan, who was originally set to be Yorkshire's overseas signing for 2015 but made himself unavailable due to Pakistan international commitments. The Indian batsman Pujara will join Yorkshire temporarily until Australian Aaron Finch becomes available after completing his Indian Premier League commitments with Mumbai Indians.

US Army Staff Sgt Julian McDonald welcomed 4-year-old Layka, a Belgian Malinois, into his Columbus, Ohio home this week after fighting for two years to adopt the heroic military dog who saved his life in Afghanistan. Layka lost her front leg after being shot four times while protecting McDonald and his team during a mission to clear a Taliban compound in 2012. McDonald told ABC that Layka has adapted well to civilian life and quickly became best friends with his son.

For years medical experts have warned about the dangers of too much salt and that excess salt contributes to thousands of deaths annually, but new research is now questioning conventional wisdom and warning instead of the dangers of too little salt. Some scientists argue that the average American salt consumption rate carries no risk and that current salt guidelines lack valid basis, with skeptics suggesting people can safely consume up to 6,000 milligrams of salt per day while warning that consuming below 3,000 milligrams also raises health risks. This emerging research challenges decades of federal guidelines and American Heart Association recommendations that have long advocated for strict sodium limits.

A DEA report released by the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform revealed that several DEA agents were taking part in alleged sex parties with prostitutes funded by drug cartels in Colombia starting as early as 2001, years earlier than previously known. This follows a separate report from two weeks prior that found at least 7 agents admitted sleeping with prostitutes while on overseas assignments. The inspector general investigated allegations of sexual misconduct and found a wide range of sex-related offenses across multiple federal agencies, including sex with prostitutes and other serious violations.

A 36-year-old Louisiana sheriff's deputy named Burt Hazeltine was shot three times while directing school buses on US 90 near Louisiana Street in Paradis, just west of New Orleans. The shooting occurred after a road rage incident when the deputy refused to stop traffic to allow the suspect to make a turn. Hazeltine was hospitalized in stable but guarded condition following the ambush attack.

Lord Janner signed a letter requesting to remain a peer just one week before being ruled unfit to face child sex charges due to Alzheimer's disease, sparking controversy from abuse campaigners who question how he can be deemed too frail for court but well enough to participate in the House of Lords. Director of Public Prosecutions Alison Saunders announced that Janner would escape prosecution over 22 sexual offences against children dating from 1969 to 1988, despite sufficient evidence to charge the suspected paedophile. Critics, including Pete Saunders from the National Association for People Abused in Childhood, argue this creates a contradiction and suggests an establishment cover-up, as Janner allegedly preyed on boys at care homes while serving as an MP.

Turkey has blocked access to Twitter and YouTube after they refused a request to remove pictures of prosecutor Mehmet Selim Kiraz, who was held hostage during a deadly armed siege last week by far-left militants. The 46-year-old prosecutor died in hospital after being taken captive by members of the Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front at a courthouse, with two of his captors also killed when security forces ended the six-hour standoff. A Turkish court imposed the social media blocks because the images of the siege were being shared online and deeply upset the prosecutor's family.

David and Victoria Beckham have won a planning battle against their neighbor over proposals to install air-conditioning in five rooms of their £31.5 million west London mansion, including the gym and wine cellar. Despite one neighbor's objections about potential noise and impact on the Victorian street's historic character, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Council approved the plans subject to minor conditions. Estate agents estimate the restored Grade II listed property could be worth as much as £42 million when completed.

California Gov. Jerry Brown ordered a 25 percent overall cutback in water use by cities and towns on Wednesday as the state faces a fourth summer of drought with no relief in sight. Photos taken on Saturday show the ongoing drought is already taking its toll on California's once lush landscape of green yards, emerald golf courses, and aquamarine swimming pools. The mandatory restrictions come after voluntary conservation efforts yielded mixed results, with some affluent communities using over 300 gallons per person daily while state reservoirs have only a year's worth of water remaining.

Universal's "Furious 7" is expected to make history by grossing $115 million or more at its North American opening weekend, which would set the record for the top April opening domestically. The movie is getting the widest release in Universal's history with approximately 4,003 theaters and is opening day-and-date around the world on 10,500 screens in 63 territories, with its global debut expected to exceed $250 million.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas continued his second-half-of-season struggles during Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland on Tuesday, raising concerns for manager Jose Mourinho as the team pursues the Premier League title. The Spanish midfielder, who looked set to break the Barclays Premier League record for assists earlier in the season, has seen his form significantly decline since Christmas, with fatigue from playing almost every minute appearing to take its toll. Despite Chelsea being on track for Premier League title success following their Capital One Cup win, questions remain about Fabregas' durability and ability to maintain peak performance throughout a long campaign.

Victims of a horrific U.S. medical experiment in Guatemala from 1945-1956 are suing Johns Hopkins University for $1 billion, claiming the university approved and helped plan a study that deliberately infected approximately 700 individuals with syphilis to test drugs and study the disease. The experiment targeted vulnerable populations including orphans, soldiers, prisoners, and prostitutes, with some victims dying from syphilis and others passing the disease to their children who were born with severe disabilities including blindness and brain defects. The study was run by Dr. John Cutler, who also conducted the infamous Tuskegee syphilis experiment, and the U.S. government only admitted to the Guatemala experiments in 2010.

Hip-hop star Nelly was arrested on drug charges in Tennessee after a state trooper stopped the private bus he was traveling in and noticed an odor of marijuana emitting from the vehicle. The trooper's search of the bus revealed methamphetamine, marijuana, drug paraphernalia, several handguns, and small bags commonly used for drug sales, leading to Nelly being charged with felony drug possession, simple possession of marijuana, and possession of drug paraphernalia. Nelly later posted bond and was released from the Putnam County Jail.

A Japanese woman got revenge on her cheating boyfriend by giving his entire Apple collection a "good wash" in the bathtub, including his iMac (which starts at £899), iPhone, iPad and accessories. The woman scorned took the trouble to give his expensive gadgets a single soaking, then photographed the damage and sent the images to him. While reactions on Twitter were mixed after the photos went viral with over 15,400 retweets, many supported the woman's methods as fitting revenge for infidelity.

Borussia Dortmund coach Jurgen Klopp conceded that Bayern Munich were the better team and deserved their 1-0 victory on Saturday, with Robert Lewandowski's header condemning his former club to defeat. The charismatic Dortmund manager admitted his side lacked punch in the final third and struggled to create chances against Bayern, who now sit 10 points clear at the top of the Bundesliga table. Despite Dortmund captain Mats Hummels disagreeing with his coach's assessment, Klopp maintained that Bayern deserved to win after being better in "many small moments."

President Barack Obama made a historic visit to Jamaica on Thursday, becoming the first U.S. president to visit the island nation since Ronald Reagan in 1982, where Jamaican Prime Minister Portia Simpson Miller expressed her love for Obama and told him how beloved he is by the Jamaican people. During his trip, President Obama signaled that he will soon remove Cuba from the U.S. list of state sponsors of terrorism, as he prepared for a significant meeting with Cuban President Raul Castro at the Summit of the Americas in Panama. Secretary of State John Kerry also held lengthy and constructive discussions with Cuban Foreign Minister Bruno Rodriguez in Panama City, with both sides agreeing they made progress toward resolving outstanding issues between the two countries.

Pope Francis reminded the world of the Vatican's diplomatic role during his traditional Easter Mass speech, where the Pontiff lamented the suffering in conflicts currently making headlines and called for peace worldwide. He specifically asked for humanitarian aid to reach those in need in Iraq and Syria, expressed hope for the Israeli-Palestinian peace process to resume, and mentioned various troubled regions including Libya, Yemen, Nigeria, South Sudan, and Kenya. The Pope also addressed economic oppression and ended his address by consoling the marginalized, poor, sick, and suffering while wishing everyone a happy Easter.

Russian supermodel Irina Shayk, 29, stars in Linda Farrow eyewear's Spring Summer 15 campaign alongside male model Jarrod Scott in a steamy poolside video shot in Los Angeles. The behind-the-scenes film shows stunning Irina slowly emerging from glistening water wearing Linda Farrow specs and metallic swimsuits, while getting close to Jarrod in various intimate poses around the pool. The campaign features the brand's new collection including standout pieces like Linda Farrow round frame gold plated sunglasses, with the newly-single model looking confident following her recent split from Cristiano Ronaldo.

A Polish prince, Janek Zylinski, whose father was a war hero who fought the Nazis in 1939, has challenged UKIP leader Nigel Farage to a sword fight over his anti-immigration stance. Zylinski posted the challenge online after declaring he had "had enough" of Farage's discrimination against Polish immigrants, specifically citing Farage's blame of migrants for traffic jams on the M40. The prince offered either a traditional sword duel in Hyde Park or alternatively a "duel of words" in a studio to settle their differences.

The Calbuco volcano in southern Chile erupted twice in spectacular fashion, forcing the evacuation of 4,000 people and covering nearby towns in thick ash despite being one of Chile's 90 active volcanoes that was not under special observation. Volcano Calbuco's last major eruption happened in 1961, and according to experts, equally violent eruptions at Calbuco have historically continued for up to a week, making it impossible to predict what will happen next. Volcanoes like Calbuco occur at the edges of tectonic plates, and eruptions occur when magma forces its way to the surface, creating dangerous conditions that require immediate evacuation of surrounding areas.

Barcelona defender Dani Alves, whose contract runs out at the end of the season, has been sounded out by Manchester United over a potential move to Old Trafford, though questions remain about whether United has really offered him a three-year deal given his continued negotiations with Barcelona. While a Premier League swansong at United could cap off his remarkable career, Alves is hopeful Barcelona make him an improved offer so he can stay at the Nou Camp, especially since Barcelona desperately needs him due to their FIFA transfer ban preventing new signings. The situation has created uncertainty about whether the Brazilian right-back will leave for United or remain with Barcelona on revised terms.

Kate Temple, a hairdresser, was jailed for 20 months after she admitted inflicting grievous bodily harm by ripping off part of victim Shelley Williams' ear with her teeth during a fight at a charity hog roast party. The attack occurred after Williams accused Temple of having an affair with her partner, leading to a scuffle that left the victim covered in blood. After the assault, Temple attempted to buy another drink from the bar but was refused service, and police later found the missing portion of Williams' ear the following day.

Jenson Button believes McLaren now have their rivals in their sights ahead of this weekend's Chinese Grand Prix, after the team made significant progress in Malaysia following a poor start to the new Formula One season in Australia. The British driver Button and McLaren driver Fernando Alonso both retired from the Malaysian race, but showed competitive pace against midfield runners, with the high temperatures in Malaysia particularly suiting their car. Button is optimistic about continuing this progress race by race, though he acknowledges the cooler conditions expected for the weekend's race in Shanghai could present new challenges.

Claudia Martins, 33, has been convicted of manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility after killing her newborn baby daughter by stuffing toilet paper in the infant's mouth. Martins gave birth alone at her sister's flat, having kept her pregnancy secret, and then hid the baby's body in a suitcase for three days before it was discovered. While she was acquitted of murder, the jury found her guilty of the lesser charge after evidence showed the toilet paper was deliberately inserted into the baby's mouth.

AP McCoy will ride Paul Nicholls-trained Mr Mole in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, with the horse installed as one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the seven-runner field. This will be McCoy's final ride in a Grade One race, with the announcement coming ironically after McCoy shocked the racing world by announcing his retirement following a victory on Mr Mole at Newbury in February.

A woman who couldn't swim had to be rescued from the River Cam in Cambridge after falling from a punt when it hit another boat, disappearing under water several times before being pulled to safety by friends and punt hire staff. The incident occurred during today's unseasonably warm Easter weather, with temperatures reaching nearly 21C - the hottest day of the year so far. Forecasters are predicting temperatures higher than Rome and Athens, with the balmy Easter weather expected to continue throughout the week, drawing crowds to parks, beaches, and popular punting spots like Cambridge.

West Indies batsman Marlon Samuels grafted his way to 103 against England in the second Test, demonstrating the discipline and character that new West Indies coach Phil Simmons is trying to instill in his team. The author argues that while Test cricket seems something of a throwback in today's instant gratification world, there is unparalleled satisfaction in the mental and physical challenges of five-day cricket that players will be remembered for, unlike the easier option of shorter formats like the IPL.

North Charleston police are facing accusations that killer cop Michael Slager would have gotten away with a cover-up had bystander video not emerged, as seven of Slager's fellow cops responded to the scene where handcuffed Walter Scott lay dead or dying with five bullet wounds to the back. While police reports claimed officers performed CPR on Scott's body, the video only shows officers checking Scott's pulse and standing over his handcuffed body, with one officer present when Slager retrieves his Taser and places it near Scott. The incident has raised serious questions about police conduct and potential cover-up attempts, with critics arguing this case fits a pattern of police abuse that would have been swept under the rug without the video evidence.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied media reports that she tried to take her own life over the weekend. Instead, Moric posted several photographs of her injuries on Instagram and explained that she collapsed due to low blood pressure and was treated in hospital after a domestic accident where she fell and hit her head. While Italian media reported that Ms Moric tried to commit suicide and was found by her mother in her Milan apartment she shares with her boyfriend, Nina reassured her fans that she only needed rest to recover from her fall.

Patrice Evra helped Juventus secure their first Champions League semi-final since 2002-03 by defending against Monaco at the Stade Louis II on Wednesday night, with Evra preventing Monaco's Yannick Ferreira Carrasco from creating chances in their 0-0 draw. Injury meant Paul Pogba sat out the Monaco clash, and Evra has urged his compatriot Paul Pogba not to rush his return from a hamstring injury that has sidelined him for 50 days. Evra described Juventus's defensive approach as playing "the Italian way - it's solid, it's ugly, but it works" in their victory over Monaco.

At Omaha's Henry Doorley Zoo yesterday, a little girl beating her chest at gorillas through a pane of glass prompted an aggressive response when one of the gorilla's friends in the background became agitated and charged at the enclosure. The massive silverback gorilla throws his entire weight against the glass with such force that it cracks on impact, terrifying the family who quickly fled to safety. The Nebraska zoo, famous for producing the first gorilla test tube baby in 1995, had to keep visitors away from the damaged enclosure following the incident.

Classic FM presenter John Suchet is mourning the loss of his wife Bonnie, who died peacefully on April 15, 2015, at age 73 following a decade-long battle with dementia. Suchet began noticing changes in his wife's behavior in 2004, and she was diagnosed with dementia in 2006, prompting him to become an advocate for dementia awareness and care. The couple, who described their relationship as a "grand passion" and "made in heaven," had been together since the late 1970s when they left their respective marriages to be with each other.

Ben and Shelby Offrink, who met in college in Michigan, are both battling rare forms of cancer while raising two young children. Shelby suddenly lost feeling in her legs due to a spinal glioblastoma and is now paralyzed, while Ben's Hodgkins lymphoma has returned after 15 years in remission. Despite Shelby's six-month prognosis and Ben's declining condition, Shelby's reaction remains determined as she continues her fight, refusing to give up and seeking clinical trials and advanced treatment options to help both of them survive for their family.

Spanish papers report that Real Madrid boss Carlo Ancelotti faces a "blessed problem" with his attacking prowess after scoring nine goals against Granada, as he must now choose between James Rodriguez and Isco for his preferred formation with all seven attacking stars fit and available for the first time since November. Meanwhile in Italy, Inter Milan continues to struggle with internal divisions between Italian and foreign staff, and in France, PSG's thrilling 3-2 win over title rivals Marseille has been praised as evidence of Ligue 1's improvement, keeping PSG atop the table just one point ahead of Lyon.

Floyd Mayweather will face rival Manny Pacquiao on May 2 in the highly-anticipated "Fight of the Century" at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas. During his preparation for Saturday's fight, Mayweather took time out of a training session at the Mayweather Boxing Club to pose for a picture with Motown legend Gladys Knight, who posted the photo on Twitter. The blockbuster boxing match saw tickets sell out within 60 seconds, with Mayweather expected to earn £120 million from what's being called the biggest event in boxing history.

Ed Miliband has hired a leadership coaching firm called ExtendedMind to help him overcome anxiety and develop his "inner voice" as he struggles to convince voters he is suitable for prime minister, having constantly lagged behind Prime Minister David Cameron in personal rating polls. The consultants drafted by the Labour leader claim to work with politicians using neuroscience and business psychology to build leadership skills, including coaching on authenticity and alliance-building that could prove useful in potential negotiations with SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon. When asked about the coaching firm's helpfulness during a press conference where he launched Labour campaign billboards, Mr Miliband deflected by saying he takes advice from various people and would let others judge the effectiveness.

Limousine company manager Raymond Townsend was found liable for sexual harassment against his 32-year-old dispatcher Geralyn Ganci after he fired her for refusing to have sex with him and sent her explicit texts for over a year. Townsend explicitly told Ganci in a text message that she lost her job because she "refused to have sex with the General Manager," and sent other inappropriate messages including claims about masturbating while thinking about her. A court ordered Townsend and US Limousine to pay more than $700,000 in damages and fees to Ganci for creating a hostile work environment.

Bayern Munich playmaker Thiago made his first appearance in over a year when he came on as a substitute during Bayern's 1-0 win against Borussia Dortmund at the Westfalenstadion on Saturday, after being sidelined since March 2014 due to a serious knee injury. The Spain international Thiago said the emotional reaction from the fans reminded him that "football is my life," though he admitted he felt tired after just 10 minutes on the pitch. Despite not being fully fit yet, Thiago remains focused on his goals to win games and titles as Bayern continues their pursuit of the treble.

David Cameron today accused the BBC of peddling "bollocks" after presenter Andrew Marr incorrectly claimed during a Sunday interview that the Prime Minister had said foxhunting was his favorite sport, when Cameron had actually only expressed support for country sports in general. The Tory leader hit back at the BBC while turning the clock back to ape John Major's election soapbox strategy, climbing onto a wooden pallet to address party faithful, though he was heckled by someone shouting "the NHS is dying." Marr later admitted his mistake on Twitter, calling it a "cock up not conspiracy," while Cameron promised to take to the streets to defend the Conservative record and urge voters to reject Labour and UKIP.

Gwyneth Paltrow participated in the #FoodBankNYCChallenge after being nominated by celebrity chef Mario Batali, showcasing groceries purchased for under $30 to live on a food stamp budget for one week based on the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Thrifty Food Plan. The challenge aims to raise awareness about food insecurity struggles following Congress cutting food stamps twice since 2013, requiring participants to survive on just $1.38 per meal for seven days.

Dozens of staff at Manchester United's Old Trafford megastore, including mascot Fred the Red who has been the club's official mascot since 1994, are uncertain about their job security as Nike's agreement with the club expires on July 31. The workers are concerned about their futures amid Manchester United's transition to a new £750m kit deal with adidas, with Nike currently in consultation with employees about the store management handover to the club. The timing is particularly challenging as it comes just before the new Premier League season begins on August 8.

Liverpool advanced to the FA Cup semi-finals after Philippe Coutinho eventually broke the deadlock with a decisive goal following 161 goalless minutes across two matches against Blackburn Rovers. Blackburn came close to equalizing when goalkeeper Simon Eastwood was denied in stoppage time, while their defense successfully kept dangerous Sterling quieter than most Barclays Premier League full-backs would. Coutinho was the star man in Liverpool's midfield, delivering an excellent performance that sent his team to Wembley despite the challenge posed by a determined Blackburn side.

A heart-warming new video poses the question of whether six children can recognize their mothers without seeing them, simply through touch and scent. The video shows six real-life women and their children participating in an experiment where the blindfolded children must identify their mother from a group of six women by moving along and touching their hands, hair, and faces. Created by Pandora to celebrate Mother's Day 2015, the emotional video has gone viral with 2.8 million views and demonstrates the unique bond between mothers and children.

Salford assistant coach Ian Watson is poised to come out of playing retirement at the age of 38 after the team lost multiple players to suspension and injury. Watson has stepped up his training and could be called upon for Sunday's match against Castleford, which would make him the oldest current player in Super League. The Red Devils are severely depleted with four players suspended and several others injured from their recent Challenge Cup defeat.

21-year-old Jordan Spieth took the first-day lead at the 79th Masters with a stunning opening round of 64, becoming the youngest first-round leader in Masters history after sinking a 25-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole to secure a three-shot advantage. Justin Rose made early progress with a 67 that equaled his best Masters score, while other contenders like Ernie Els also posted 67s to stay in contention. Meanwhile, Rory McIlroy appeared relaxed but recovered from a nervous front nine to finish at 71, limiting damage on what could have been a much worse round as he continues his quest for the career grand slam.

Alastair Cook must somehow shut out the distractions surrounding English cricket and focus on what has become one of the most important Test series of his career, as England faces West Indies in a three-Test battle beginning Monday. Despite the imminent first Test barely registering amid speculation about leadership changes and Kevin Pietersen's return to form (hitting 170 for Surrey), Cook knows he and coach Peter Moores cannot afford any slip-ups in what should be England's least challenging assignment. The England captain appears relaxed and in good touch during practice, but faces enormous pressure to win this series while navigating the seismic changes happening around English cricket.

The Pentagon announced plans to exhume and identify the remains of nearly 400 sailors and Marines who were killed when the USS Oklahoma capsized during the Pearl Harbor bombing on December 7, 1941. The ship sank after being hit by nine torpedoes in the Japanese surprise attack, killing 429 sailors and Marines onboard, with only 35 initially identified. Advances in forensic science and DNA technology now make it possible to recover and identify more of these servicemen's remains, which have been buried as unknowns in Hawaii's National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific since 1950.

YouTube entertainer Yousef Saleh Erakat disguised himself as a homeless man in a new video to see what would happen when he offered people money on the street, and discovered that most reactions were hostile and unkind. Throughout the experiment, Erakat offers cash to passersby who often respond angrily, with many refusing the money and some becoming confrontational, believing they are superior to someone they perceive as homeless. The video aimed to explore society's class dynamics and whether it's acceptable for the wealthy to help the poor, revealing that when the roles are reversed, people's reactions expose their true attitudes about social hierarchy and humility.

The grandmother of 18-year-old college student Anjelica "AJ" Hadsell, who has been missing since March 2, is criticizing police for not doing enough to find the girl and says her son Wesley Hadsell (AJ's stepfather) was unjustly arrested. Wesley Hadsell was taken into custody after breaking into a home where he believed his stepdaughter might be held, claiming he found her jacket there, though police are treating this as obstruction of justice. Police are currently searching a pond near Carrsville, Virginia for AJ's cell phone based on a new tip, while the case remains unsolved with no official suspects named.

Australian researchers have developed a drone running companion called Joggobot, designed to fly in front of joggers to help maintain pace and provide motivation during runs. The technology could track a runner's speed and direction, and researchers claim these robotic companions could be used for other physical activities such as cycling, cross-country skiing, and rowing. While runners may initially feel awkward with the drone companion, most found it effective as a "pace keeper" that created a sense of peer pressure similar to running with a human partner.

Matthew Bird from New Zealand quit his $70,000 a year job as an agricultural adviser to become a mechanic earning $38,000 annually to avoid a $600-a-month increase in child support payments. Under New Zealand's amended child support formula that took effect in April, Bird was expected to pay $1,900 per month, but by reducing his income, his payments dropped to $554 a month. The new formula has caused financial difficulties for other parents as well, with child support payments increased across the board.

British man Navinder Singh Sarao, 36, is accused of causing the 2010 Wall Street "flash crash" and making £26 million from illegal trades over five years, with US authorities having suspected him of making illicit trades as early as 2009. Despite being warned by officials in 2009, Sarao allegedly continued his market manipulation activities until this year, using automated trading software to place and cancel thousands of orders within seconds. Experts are expressing shock that it took six years for authorities to bring criminal charges against Sarao, who was arrested by Scotland Yard at the FBI's request and faces extradition to New York for trial.

Canadian expat Lisa Webb, who moved to France in 2009, was initially shocked when she first encountered kids eating whatever sophisticated meals were served at French schools, including dishes like rôti de boeuf and cordon bleu that she associated with fancy restaurants rather than children's food. When she sent her own vegetable-phobic three-year-old daughter to school in France in 2014, she feared the child would starve, but discovered that unlike the fast food culture back home, French children sit at tables with proper cutlery and eat three-course meals together without complaint. After observing her daughter's lunch breaks for a week, Lisa was amazed to see kids eating everything served to them using grown-up manners, leading her to praise the French public school system's approach to meals.

A survey conducted by YouNeedaBudget.com found that 64 per cent of adults think they spend far more money when they go shopping with friends compared to making purchases alone. The main reasons for this increased spending include peer pressure, the urge to show off in front of friends, and getting carried away by excitement while shopping together. Despite most people setting budgets before shopping, 95 per cent admitted they usually spend more than originally planned, with food and clothing being the top categories for overspending.

Phillip Schofield was left speechless during a This Morning interview when 22-year-old Ellie Grant, who has Tourette's syndrome, suddenly blurted out "silver fox" (Phillip's nickname) due to a verbal tic. Grant was appearing on the show to discuss how she developed Tourette's at age 21 and found love with her deaf fiancé Jordan, who simply turns off his hearing aid when her tics become disruptive, making them a perfect match despite their conditions.

The White House announced that Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American citizen who became al Qaeda's chief English-language propagandist, was killed in January during a U.S. counterterrorism operation in Pakistan. Gadahn had joined al Qaeda after converting to Islam in 1995 and moving to Pakistan three years later, eventually rising through the ranks to become one of the terrorist organization's most prominent members. In a separate operation, another U.S. citizen and al Qaeda operative Ahmed Farouq was also killed, along with American hostage Warren Weinstein who had been abducted by al Qaeda in Pakistan in 2011.

Formula One driver Jenson Button completed the 2015 London Marathon in an impressive time of 2 hours, 52 minutes and 30 seconds, though the 35-year-old McLaren driver jokingly expressed disappointment at finishing behind former Olympic rower James Cracknell. Running on behalf of Cancer Research charity, Button praised the "amazing atmosphere" and described the experience as "really really emotional" while celebrating the collective spirit of participating alongside 36,000 other runners.
